headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012

componenttext: The Roper Industries Fourth Quarter 2011 Financial Results call will now begin. As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan. And thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results for the fourth quarter and full year 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President a
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan. And thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results for the fourth quarter and full year 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we will take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll walk you through briefly how the fourth quarter looked, what our full year enterprise results for 2011 were and what some of those implications are for positioning ourselves in 2012. We'll go through the seg
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll walk you through briefly how the fourth quarter looked, what our full year enterprise results for 2011 were and what some of those implications are for positioning ourselves in 2012. We'll go through the segment detail in terms of how we see 2012 by segment, talk about our guidance for the coming year and then open it up for Q&A. 
So next slide here. With the overview of the fourth quarter. It was an all-time record quarter for us for any quarter in the history of the company. And that the most revenue, the most net earnings, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, operating and free cash flow. Total sales were up 9%, organic sales were up 7%. Frankly better organic sales growth than we would have expected back 6 or 7 months ago. So things to favorable in that arena. Gross margins were up to 54.9%, demonstrating or certainly not under a lot of a price pressure in the marketplace and then everything we're doing continues to work exceptionally well. EBITDA was $222 million in the quarter, which is beyond a spectacular number in our opinion. EBITDA margins were 30.1%. It's certainly a milestone for Roper. It speaks to the quality of the businesses that we have. Our earnings in the quarter were $1.23, we talked about that in the income statement here up from $1.10. Last year, fourth quarter and operating cash flow was another sort of a spectacular $193 million in the quarter, that represented 158% of net earnings on a conversion basis and represented 26% of sales. Free cash flow was $181 million. Same story, 149% of net earnings here for conversions. So it was quite a strong finish in the fourth quarter to what was a historic year for us. 
Next slide. Here if we look at the fourth quarter income statement, you'll see that bookings were basically flat. There are couple of reasons for that. Fourth quarter last year, our orders were up 23% over the prior year so it was an exceptionally unusual and difficult comp. And we had 3 things happen that we detailed. Last year, we had quite a substantial order for Neptune that tends to be a nonrecurring type of item when those happened, there are some unique shipments in the counter arena around some specific CapEx that was going on in China. And then we had Gaz de France project, that was largely both of them that was completed in the fourth quarter this year. So those over unusual headwinds that exceeded $30 million. The backlog is up though, as you can see by 5.5%. So backlog was $128 million, which is an all-time record for year ending backlog number for us. Net sales were up 9%, 7% organic. Gross profit as we covered was up 20 bps, operating income of $187 million was up 13% and operating margin was at above 25% here up 80 bps in the quarter. You can see the tax rate was a little bit of a negative headwind for us in the quarter compared to last year. We had a particularly favorable tax rate Q4 last year of 27.7% for us and the fourth quarter was 29%. So that cost us $0.02 a share. Nonetheless, we still are in that $1.23 debt.
Next slide. If you look at fourth quarter cash flow. It's, for us, just breathtaking accomplishment. $183 million of operating cash flow in the quarter and that's up dramatically last year, a record year was $155 million. And if you look at fourth quarter 2009, it was $120 million. So we just continue to pileup the cash. And if you look at the variances, it's up 24%, as you can see on this slide from the fourth quarter a year ago and 61% from 2009. 
Next slide. Here we'll start to look at the full year enterprise results. Next slide. We again achieved a record result on an annual basis, as well as a quarter. On an annual basis, again includes everything. Kitchen sink here, historic levels of orders, backlog, sales, net earnings, EBITDA, operating and free cash flow. Sales for the year were up 17%, organic growth for 2011 was 13%. Remember when we established guidance of the beginning of the year, we organic growth might be 9% or 11%, so substantially stronger than we had expected. Gross margin was up 8 bps to 54.4%, operating margin up at 200 bps to 23.6%, which is really an incredible achievement for all of our 28 P&Ls around the world that are so terrifically focused on margin and cash and growth. Our EBITDA for the year was up $164 million to $802 million. By the way, we had a remeasurement gain in the second quarter and that were excluding that from the $602 million number, otherwise it would have been $809 million, but that's not a recurring item. The EBITDA margin expanded to 28.7% for the full year and operating cash flow for the full year was $602 million or 22% of revenue. Free cash flow at $561 million was 20% of sales. So another terrific year for the Roper family of businesses. 
Next slide. Here if we look at the full year income statement, you'll see bookings were up 11% on the year. Net sales up 17%, organic 13%. Gross margin up 80 bps operating margin up 200 as we said it. Tax rate on the year came in at 29.4, which was a 130 bps headwinds compared to the prior year. So that cost us $0.08 a share. Despite that, we've reported debts of $4.34 and the one thing we point out there again is that re- measurement gain is at the GAAP number of $4.34. 
Next slide. Here if we look at our EBITDA growth, you can see the trends and performance in terms of capturing our gross margins in the form of EBITDA for our investors. We had EBITDA of $802 million as we mentioned, which is up $300 million from 2 years ago. Our EBITDA margin in 2 years ago were 24.5% and common question are how are you ever going to keep those margins? They've got to degrade nobody can have a margins like this. They are going to progress artificial S&P 500 companies are stuck with. But that's not the case here. As you can see our margins went up to 24.5% to 26.7% last year and just continue forward at 28.7% this year. That's a 420 basis point improvement in just 2 years in our EBITDA margins. 
Next slide. Our full year cash flow again tells the story of Roper's business model. $602 million in operating cash flow representing 22% of revenue. Free cash flow of 20% of revenue. Terrific execution throughout the enterprise. Networking capital still in our definition of inventory receivables less payables and accruals is like 6% or less. So just spectacular performance from the field here. And you can see that trend up from $367 million of operating cash flow in '09 to $500 million to $602 million, and we're forecasting continued growth in 2012. 
Next slide. We have a really terrific balance sheet. We closed the year a very strong position. You can see cash was up $68 million to $338 million. Our undrawn revolver is totally undrawn at $750 million last year. We had $520 million. And we get the benefit of trailing EBITDA coming up at $802 million. Last year it was $638 million. So we when you think about all those investment grade characteristics, and multiply times EBITDA and you look at the outer we have, we've got a really a spectacular balance sheet. Gross debt to capitalizations is 25.4. And when you look at the net debt number, we have about $1,085,000,000 in gross debt with the $338 million in cash, net debt of $747 million, against $802 million of trailing EBITDA. So it goes without saying that 2012 is likely going to be a strongly above average acquisition year for Roper and we're very excited about our prospects in that arena. 
Next slide. Here we'll get into the individual segments. All of them are just faithfully executed the business models that they drive. And you can see there's just no softness anywhere inside the full year activity. RF Technology's sales were up 17%, operating profit up 35% and margins up 300 bps. Industrial Technology was up 21%, OP up 29% and margins up 150. And boy, when you're up 150 and used 28.2% OP margin for industrial flow control businesses, I just can't take my head off another to the quality of people we have in advantages move to the service. Our Medical and Scientific Imaging sales were up 11%, OP was up 14 and margins were up 50. And then Energy Systems and Controls was up 19% with OP up 31 and margins up to 50. Overall, the team produced 13% organic growth. They feel good about going into 2012 and the broad-based margin expansion we enjoyed this year we think will continue next year. 
Next slide. So here we'll look with the smallest segment. As a function of the total of 21% of Medical and Scientific Imaging. They had an unusual fourth quarter just mathematically were talking about that. But really the story is that medical growth continues with even better prospects of Northern Digital than we originally identified. Got significant O&M business that we believe is coming online in 2012. We had organic sales decline in the fourth quarter really caused by 2 primary events. We had lower camera sales for which an original equipment manufacturing videoconferencing series of things that go on of 1 particular large clients and they were declined this past year in the fourth quarter really brought that to a hit. And then our Rugged Mobile computer shipments, which we've really talked about because it's certainly not key to our medical or scientific imaging businesses, they enjoyed unusual activity in the fourth quarter last year with their Rugged Mobile applications in the certain overnight shipping arrangements and those are really weighted this year in the fourth quarter. We had a very strong margin performance in the fourth quarter against an all-time record last year in the fourth quarter. So we wound up with 25% OP in the fourth quarter. For the full year, you can see sales were up 11%, OP 14, and margin up 50. As we look to 2012, what we've seen this is a medical growth we expected to continue. We have several new product launches that are recurring, generally starting in Europe and then coming into North America. We expect those to provide a lift in the second half of the year. We'll get the benefit of some growth from the Northern Digital acquisition in the first part of the year and that will turn into organic growth in the second. But we expect very strong first quarter from Northern Digital. We've got significant backlog in the Scientific Imaging arena, that supports the modest growth for the year. It certainly going to be the probably the low point of 2012 organic growth for Roper. But that said, given fierce around research funding, as we've gone through our planning reviews with people, people seem reasonably confident and certainly the physical signs aspect of this looks better than the nuclear and biological aspects does but on balance, it should be a net gain for us in 2012. And we are confident we are going to have a margin expansion from growth in the other arenas. 
Next slide. If we look at the energy systems and controls. Here you can see just virtually all the divisions here with the exception of Zetec's engine activity have had a very strong growth across the segment. They all have record margin performance. We continue to get our diesel engine system shut off that we talked about frequently continue to grow at a very rapid pace. We don't see any pullback in that area. We have had record results really for Compressor Controls and primarily due to the continuing expansion projects around the world. And you can see for the full year, our revenue was up 19%, OP up 31 and margin up 250. To have OP in the fourth quarter at 30.5% is really quite substantial performance. If you look at 2012, we don't really see any headwinds here. We would expect that this segment to grow the fastest of our 4 segments in 2012. It's got major drivers, none of which are waining in any way with the oil and gas markets remaining favorable. Compressor Controls has a backlog that assures its success for the year. And the bolt-on acquisitions, which we haven't talked a lot about because they're small United Controls down earlier this year, gives us access to very substantial OEMs that we haven't been involved within the past. We're company in the U.K. that's coming on board now. It's a modest revenue but it gives us a lot of technology and allow us to get compressor control even more and better than software activity. And then is a Chinese company, is our first Chinese acquisition that we acquired from. Is enjoying very nice growth probably everyone is aware of it. The manufacturing CapEx is doing well and the things that's it can do for us in China are similar to what we do in the U.S. We have a lot of new products coming online and having our own in-house manufacturing capability and distribution channel reached directly in China for the rubber industry is quite useful for us. 
Next slide. Here if we look at Industrial Technology. In the fourth quarter was up 20% in sales, 25% in OP, margins at 29.2%. Let's not be confused. Those are not gross margins of initial company. Those are the operating margins of our flow controlling businesses. Fluid handling, very rapid growth from new customers, expanding oil and gas markets here. Certainly frac-ing is driving a significant portion of our growth. Very important indicator for us, our Materials Test business that's headquartered in Denmark along with the Tinisco business I just mentioned were 2 of 3 indicators 2008 about the downturn for '09 that people are going to experience and they finished the fourth quarter of the very strong rate up over 20%. Very strong as well. So we haven't seen any sign of any deterioration and forward activity. Neptune is continuing to grow in the U.S. despite the concerns that we and others would have about the municipal market. And the fourth quarter was favorable for Neptune. And we delivered both growth and execution with these record margins. Full year you can see sort of similar 20% in the fourth quarter, 21 for the year, OP up 29, margin up 150 basis points. For this coming year, we really don't see anything that's going to arrest the trend, the major drivers. We get a big benefit from the Toronto project at Neptune, which will roll out more rapidly in 2012 than it did in '11. We don't see any pullback in any of our flow control businesses. And then we have a new products in material test that will allow that continue to grow. So it will do nicely at any high-end of any range we established for organic growth. 
Then we look at the RF Technology business. And here in the fourth quarter, we had sales of 4%, OP up 12% and a significant margin improvement up 190 bps. The organic was flatter, was far better than what it looks here because we had the completion of France Technolog Gaz de France automatic meter reading project, which was completed. So from a revenue it helped us all year but in the prior year it had been in the bookings. So that was certainly an artificial headwind on a comparative basis. We had very strong shipments that offset somewhat less project work in the tolling in the fourth quarter. But we continue to have growth in our Software-as-a-Service subscription and software maintenance businesses. We had really a terrific contribution throughout the year from our college campus software and integrated security solutions out of CBORD. They accounted for a significant portion of our growth and in the full year. And importantly, you can see the full year sales growth for RF was up 17%, OP up 35 and margin up 300. And we are encouraged by margin in general in RF. So when we look to 2012, what we see is continued growth in the software and SaaS businesses and that we have. We think toll project and maintenance growth will be stronger next year while tag shipments will be lower. We have this headwind that we have to get through with the Gaz de France project that won't reoccur although we have ongoing service with it. So that will be a drag into 2012. But the operating margin expansion that we expect to see by having software businesses becoming a bigger portion of the segments and the backlog that we have in this segment gives us confidence that we will produce both more cash and operating profit in 2012 in RF. 
Next slide.
Here as we get into the 2012 guidance. Next slide, the full year guidance for us is $467 million to $487 million and assumptions around that is that organic growth would be up from a 5% of the low end of the range of 8% or more at the high end of the range. Last year we said 9% to 11%, I believe that. This year, 5% to 8% given all the uncertainty the word seems like a rational approach to this. We're assuming currency is the same as it was January 31, 2012, the tax rate we're assuming is going to be about 30%. Share count creeps up a little bit from 98.5 million diluted shares to 99.5 million. First quarter, we'd see coming in between $1.01 and $1.05. And full year operating cash flow should exceed $650 million in 2012. I'm sure some people worry we haven't commented much about Europe in here. It's not overly significant for us. We don't see much difficulty in Europe. Our businesses there our exporters to emerging markets. So we remain pretty comfortable what's happening in Europe. 
Next slide. If you look at the 2011 summary then, we had an all-time performance record for orders and sales, net earnings, cash flow and EBITDA. We had terrific margin leverage. And when we looked back on the year, one of the things that I didn't cover that's worth really talking about in the income statement is, if we look at the difference, we were up operating income reached $661 million, up from $514 million, so that's $147 million up in operating income, while sales were up by $411 million. So you take that $147 million OP and divide it by an incremental $411 million in net sales, you get an operating profit leverage of 36%. So our leverage is still world-class, and we expect that to continue in 2012. 
Operating cash flow at $602 million speaks for itself, 20% free cash flow to sales. I don't think you can find people doing that. And our family of businesses and our end markets are continuing to look quite reasonable for 2012. So we expect to have another record year in 2012 and certainly are off to a good start. So with that, John, I think we're open for questions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, Frank, can you talk about in your oil and gas related businesses whether or not a reduction in gas rig counts, or increase in oil rig counts. Is that good for Roper, not good or are you guys indifferent to that and then I hav
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, Frank, can you talk about in your oil and gas related businesses whether or not a reduction in gas rig counts, or increase in oil rig counts. Is that good for Roper, not good or are you guys indifferent to that and then I have one follow-up?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Matt, we're probably indifferent to that. Although it's probably better for us on the oil side of that on the gas side. I mean, we have products that are used in both of those applications. And as Roper pump in particular, they continued to expand their n
componenttext: Matt, we're probably indifferent to that. Although it's probably better for us on the oil side of that on the gas side. I mean, we have products that are used in both of those applications. And as Roper pump in particular, they continued to expand their new products and in fact have worked with our business on some polymer technology for one of their power sections, which allows that to be utilized in downhole oil applications, as well as what they had been doing previously for gas applications. So were largely indifferent to that. And also remember, an awful lot of it is about building the base and expanding into some channels that we have not been before. So it's not only the growth in the drilling activity overall but also some good channel development that those guys have done.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then walk through the same thing to space really talking about Compressor Controls more around kind of the applications specific things that are driving what Brian seem to describe as a backlog that's -- gives you very good visibility through the year
componenttext: And then walk through the same thing to space really talking about Compressor Controls more around kind of the applications specific things that are driving what Brian seem to describe as a backlog that's -- gives you very good visibility through the year. Is this mostly -- is this more -- are you seeing good replacement, or retrofit activity or is this new capacity? And I guess can you talk about the what you've been doing maybe on the power side of that business as well?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, generally what happens with us is well we do OEM certainly very well manufacturers, most of our businesses is Aftermarket business. So we get a whole lot of several year out from new CapEx activity where people want to see us deploy better technolog
componenttext: Well, generally what happens with us is well we do OEM certainly very well manufacturers, most of our businesses is Aftermarket business. So we get a whole lot of several year out from new CapEx activity where people want to see us deploy better technology for their controls than perhaps they had in the original purchase. This is a phenomenon that's not unusual. So people who are looking for productivity or more throughput or less consumption in the gas and the pipeline, frequent they're going to choose us. That business we've really become quite effective in distribution channels around the world. And growing in China as well. And so we really have -- anybody who wants to have LNG operations that are as efficient as possible in getting the least consumption of the gas inside their gas turbines is likely to look to us as a solution provider. That reputation just continues to build. So from an aftermarket perspective, the projects that we get a bit on, it would be not the least but unusual for us to have 6 months of backlog at Compressor Controls and non service work that's going to fill things of it. So in fact, we completely redesigned our headquarters last year, created a much, much more engineering oriented facility that gives people an opportunity to work in teams in a very different way. It certainly, among our most exciting businesses, we've got just world class resources in that business. Early phases of our growth, frankly, and good heavens if we've got the exporting gas and LNG, it would be phenomenal what will happen to our business in that area.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to on Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.
componenttext: And next we'll go to on Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can we talked about the medical? Obviously, there's some weakness in the whole segment, but you had some tough comps. But what degree is that attributable to some product introductions? You mentioned new products rolling out in the back half. So does that
componenttext: Can we talked about the medical? Obviously, there's some weakness in the whole segment, but you had some tough comps. But what degree is that attributable to some product introductions? You mentioned new products rolling out in the back half. So does that keep people on the sidelines a little bit? And what gives you a. . .

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. These are not substitution products at all. These are entirely new products. We've had an ongoing ramp up on certain kinds of positioning devices for MRI technology. We've got new products in around the GlideScope. We have this hardscape product we la
componenttext: No. These are not substitution products at all. These are entirely new products. We've had an ongoing ramp up on certain kinds of positioning devices for MRI technology. We've got new products in around the GlideScope. We have this hardscape product we launch in Europe that we haven't brought it to U.S. We have a product that is AortaScan that is a phenomenal product. All these things are just ramping up. In fact, we have international sales meeting starting Sunday night with the Verifon people for trying to gear it up and we've had similar situation last week with our Citco people around growth opportunities outside the U.S. So we're quite comfortable with that. And really any -- this organic stuff in Q4 was really not affected medical much in any way. Medical is performing very well. We expect it will continue to do that. This is really much more about a business that we have stuck inside Scientific and Imaging because it just doesn't fit anywhere. And that business had a really strong Q4 last year, which is quite unusual. And it had it's more normalized weak results in this fourth quarter of this year. So the Rugged Mobile has for a long time and then a not the typical Roper business terms of performance. But we've got a lot of energy in that business and people are hopeful for a much brighter 2012.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. Moving to industrial. It actually accelerated growth versus the third quarter on a year-over-year basis. I assume a lot of that is due in large part of the fluid handling, material test. And then looking at material test, how much of that is
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. Moving to industrial. It actually accelerated growth versus the third quarter on a year-over-year basis. I assume a lot of that is due in large part of the fluid handling, material test. And then looking at material test, how much of that is automotive driven excuse the pun. And what do you see going into 12?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the derived demand for that business is really anyone who is utilizing or looking to understand their material content better. And so as one could imagine, that does include everyone, who is making steel or aluminum or other types of really
componenttext: Well, I mean, the derived demand for that business is really anyone who is utilizing or looking to understand their material content better. And so as one could imagine, that does include everyone, who is making steel or aluminum or other types of really hard surface materials. And so there is obviously, some impact from automotive production and for the supply chain even though we don't really sell very much to any of the automotive common driven the Tier 1 automotive suppliers there, we have some sales there but that's not the primary end markets. But clearly, the fact that automotive production has come back into 2011 is expected to grow again in 2012, I think is adding some benefit for our material test business.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012

componenttext: And is it safe to say that the non Neptune businesses playout Neptune in the quarter?

componenttext: No, I don't think that's fair. I don't think that's --

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Or maybe year-to-year.
componenttext: Or maybe year-to-year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: On an annual basis, the answer is yes. For the quarter itself, Neptune continue to do very well. And remember we are ramping up with the Toronto project, which did give us some additional revenue in the fourth quarter and that will continue into 2012 and
componenttext: On an annual basis, the answer is yes. For the quarter itself, Neptune continue to do very well. And remember we are ramping up with the Toronto project, which did give us some additional revenue in the fourth quarter and that will continue into 2012 and '13 and '14.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to Deane Dray with Citi.
componenttext: Next we'll go to Deane Dray with Citi.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: For the orders this quarter it's rare that we would see a book to bill below one. And Brian, the recall in the time this is happened hasn't happened for 10 quarters, you bring out these historical references about any timing you're below. One, you can see
componenttext: For the orders this quarter it's rare that we would see a book to bill below one. And Brian, the recall in the time this is happened hasn't happened for 10 quarters, you bring out these historical references about any timing you're below. One, you can see one-off comments but then look at the trend that comes back we didn't hear that this time, a little bit of the comp issue. But just put this in perspective about the order activity, bid activity and some of the leading indicators because this is a little bit of an anomaly to see you below one.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Not below one, Deane. What we've said is from 0.97 to 1.03 is a band that we would have. And routinely, I don't know, what percent is a very high percentage between 0.97 and 1.03. But we had some unusual situations in Q4 last year, large Mexico City
componenttext:
Yes. Not below one, Deane. What we've said is from 0.97 to 1.03 is a band that we would have. And routinely, I don't know, what percent is a very high percentage between 0.97 and 1.03. But we had some unusual situations in Q4 last year, large Mexico City project that we revealed to people in industrial in the fourth quarter from an order perspective and then obviously, wouldn't repeat in the fourth quarter this year. So that alone explains most of the book to bill in industrial. And then RF is lumpy situation. Book to bill in RF was weak at like 0.9 or something like that. But we're not really worried about that. We have huge backlog in RF and the non-toll project activity is quite robust going into 2012. So it's not much of a factor. If we had a poor book to bill in the first quarter then we would be talking more about that. But we wouldn't establish organic guidance in 5% to 8% or more if we are worried about book to bill. But it's a fair thing to point out because normally, we would expect it to be not be worse 0.97, this time it was 0.94. But there were this 3 unusual event with cameras and the Rugged Mobile and Mexico that aren't really core to the overall nature of activity. So the rest of it was much more in our wheelhouse. 
S

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: For my follow-up, we pay attention on how you craft the expectations regarding M&A and strongly above average year both in terms of firepower and in the balance sheet. But take us through what you're seeing in the pipeline, pricing. And in particular, if
componenttext: For my follow-up, we pay attention on how you craft the expectations regarding M&A and strongly above average year both in terms of firepower and in the balance sheet. But take us through what you're seeing in the pipeline, pricing. And in particular, if opportunities to add on medical. This big leverage bill will drop in a new medical line on into an existing sales force. And my question there is are you restricted at all as to what type of medical products that you need to be complementary to some of your existing surgical products or can you go in into some newer areas on the medical side?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we have 3 different sales forces that are available to us. So at the low end, you have the overnight delivery people with the consumables and telephony driven responses with hospitals around the world. And we're extreme confident and that area call
componenttext: Well, we have 3 different sales forces that are available to us. So at the low end, you have the overnight delivery people with the consumables and telephony driven responses with hospitals around the world. And we're extreme confident and that area call centers, right SKU, sorting all of the almost mini distributor function. And then we have the technical around radiation oncology, which is probably unique specific trait calling on a very small niche and in the hospital and has to really be joined at the hip with the major OEM manufacturers that are better involved in that equipment. And then, we have the third the sales force, which is the sales force, which is a more generic but they are selling products that are in the thousands of dollars, not the hundreds of thousand dollars, not really CapEx for the most part. Those people have very specific people they call on. It's organized into an acute care activity and private practice activity. It's easy for them to add things in those 2 areas, increasingly we're investing outside the U.S. in channel presence and that's doing really well. So it is certainly possible that we can do bolt-on acquisitions and take advantage of our existing salesforce in that area. But we look at a lot of things in medical. And I'd say a number of things we look at are in software and medical and we find those to be exceptionally exciting.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of expectations, how close you think you are to making some announcements on the M&A side?
componenttext: In terms of expectations, how close you think you are to making some announcements on the M&A side?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: You never know. I mean, we're sitting here with a lot of capacity, which is matched by a lot of patience. So our goal is to buy things at the right price at the right time and have the right people in place to monitor them. One of the things we did last y
componenttext: You never know. I mean, we're sitting here with a lot of capacity, which is matched by a lot of patience. So our goal is to buy things at the right price at the right time and have the right people in place to monitor them. One of the things we did last year, which is very important strategically is add 2 new very senior resources. We brought Neil Hunt in to focus on medical activity, Neil is an M&A pro, former CEO of publicly traded company running revenue business in medical, just a world-class guy. But we want to marry him up with a world-class software guy. We brought Joel B who worked and Sage for this carrier. Joe's domain expert around architecture, platforms and software and trying to get our software leaders more capable, doing more bolt on activities. So we have dramatically enhanced our internal capability to simulate both software and medical companies, which we really needed to do. I think the rest of us here in Sarasota, we are only interested in doing transactions that brought world-class management teams and didn't take too much more of our time. So now that we really beefed up our capability in this area, we have a lot more firepower intellectually than we did in the past and unfortunately that matches our balance sheet.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd like to just continue that last topic. You mentioned softwares being an area of focus and on acquisitions. And historically, Roper has acquired companies that were often converting from old analog technology to new digital technology. And that involve
componenttext: I'd like to just continue that last topic. You mentioned softwares being an area of focus and on acquisitions. And historically, Roper has acquired companies that were often converting from old analog technology to new digital technology. And that involve a lot of new software driven equipment. So software is an integral part of the equipment business that you were in. And that's starting with the CCC, which, by the way, I was happy to hear that you think you're still in the early phases of growth with given that you acquired it in almost 20 years ago in September of 1992, it was $17 million in sales. So this point, there 20 years, impressive to be in the early phases of growth. But it's a software driven mainly, very small part of it. So going forward, are you really going to go into standalone software or are you going to continue to acquire equipment businesses that have a high component of software. Could you clarify that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll do both. If there was sort of one core in Roper that unifies the enterprise, it would be algorithms. Every one of our businesses almost dependent on some kind of algorithmic technology and feedback mechanism for people for data. And so that's
componenttext: Well, we'll do both. If there was sort of one core in Roper that unifies the enterprise, it would be algorithms. Every one of our businesses almost dependent on some kind of algorithmic technology and feedback mechanism for people for data. And so that's almost always a core of something. But our recent acquisitions, many of them have been pure software plays, certainly iTrade and CBORD and Horizon back in '04 Freight Matching, which was core portion of what we wanted to acquired when we did that TransCore transaction, now split as a separate company, report another company pure software in Canada, pure software. Certainly a lot of acquisitions that were moving through the pipeline now are software driven things. I think every once in a while, we looked at that equipment business. But for the most part, the software businesses the digitization of analog businesses as you pointed out are more attractive in terms of shareholder return on the cash and cash basis.

componenttextpreview: No. That is true. We're not automation. No, we are not doing software for other people's products. When we're saying software, we're doing software for other people to manage that cash in their channel. So if you look at what CBORG does, it's a software t
componenttext: No. That is true. We're not automation. No, we are not doing software for other people's products. When we're saying software, we're doing software for other people to manage that cash in their channel. So if you look at what CBORG does, it's a software that's managing campus activity and not monetizing activity and showing people what the flow looks like when you're looking at Verizon, it's pure software products providing cash register support mechanisms and telling people about the supply chain. When you look at Freight Matching, it's pure software subscription model or thousands and thousands of people are looking every minute about available freight movement. When you look at iTrade, you're looking at the people sorting through supply chains so that vendors can sell to supermarkets. So we like networks as such and we continue to look at software companies that provide niche networks to people.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012

componenttext: Okay, thank you. Second question is this. EPS last year for you as a whole is up about 29.9% and that was well above your average rate. And of course you also had some headwinds like higher tax rate an so on. But guidance for this year is only 9.9%, less than 10% above 2011. Actually that's it's a little bit higher than the consensus, which was looking for a 9.5% increase. So it's not a big surprise. But one of the reasons could be that didn't make very many big acquisitions last year so you have to depend more on organic growth this year. But also are there any big headwinds -- could you just go over the things that made last year above average and might be responsible for making this year below average in terms of EPS growth? Because I think investors are kind of looking for a continuation of the long term trend, which is about 20%.

componenttext: Rolling in so much into 2012. Last 3 years, we've done about $1.125 billion in acquisitions and we generated cash about $1.4 billion. So it's obviously, with expect to well over $2 billion in cash in the next 3 years so that it's easy to see how that's when and that thus, let more revenue. So the overall revenue will be going up. So in any 1 year, you can look at that step change to look what it is over time. We don't see any disruption in any long-term trends around Roper. We'll just going to continue to have compound growth that's favorable just doesn't look like organic growth on an acquisition and so that a year later.

componenttext: No. I don't think -- I don't I wouldn't say month-to-month. I think they're activity throughout the year was strong didn't have that left over money and so we didn't see that dynamic that we frequently see. But I don't think it has anything to do with Q1 demand or 2012 demand. So I think it's just that it was so strong all year long that people didn't wait to buy things.

componenttext: As far as some of the other units you're asking about, Chris, Neptune continues to do extremely well during the year and continued to benefit out of current Toronto. Excluding Toronto, they were up in the mid-single digits in 2011 in the U.S. which I don't think most people looking at the municipal market would've expected something like that. And so very nice job there. And then of course with a high degree of recurring revenue that comes out of our TransCore total entropic business, that is a business that will naturally kind of be in the mid-single digits also and that's kind of what it did in 2011. And then the variation that we see in that business is largely due to the timing of shipments based upon when customers are going to replenish their inventory. They've done a very nice job outside the U.S. our total entropic business has with expansion of electronic tolling opportunities in Puerto Rico and continuing with the largest tolling project in the world in Dubai. So we have a nice global footprint there and a large installed base that gives us a lot of visibility and good recurring revenue.
