headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alan, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of the fourth quarter and full year 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President an
componenttext:
Thank you, Alan, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of the fourth quarter and full year 2011. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
If you could please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we will take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll walk you through briefly how the fourth quarter looked, what our full year enterprise results for 2011 were and what some of those implications are for positioning ourselves in 2012. We'll go through the seg
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. So we'll walk you through briefly how the fourth quarter looked, what our full year enterprise results for 2011 were and what some of those implications are for positioning ourselves in 2012. We'll go through the segment detail in terms of how we see 2012 by segment, talk about our guidance for the coming year and then open it up for Q&A. 
So next slide here would be an overview of the fourth quarter. It was an all-time record quarter for us for any quarter in the history of the company. And we had the most revenue, the most net earnings, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, operating and free cash flow. 
Total sales were up 9%, organic sales were up 7%. Frankly better organic sales growth than we would have expected back 6 or 7 months ago. So things still look pretty favorable in that arena. Gross margins were up to 54.9%, demonstrating that we're certainly not under a lot of a price pressure in the marketplace, and then everything we're doing continues to work exceptionally well. EBITDA was $222 million in the quarter, which is beyond a spectacular number in our opinion. EBITDA margins were 30.1%. It's certainly a milestone for Roper. It speaks to the quality of the businesses that we have. 
Our earnings in the quarter were $1.23. We talked about that in the income statement here, up from $1.10 last year. Fourth quarter and operating cash flow was another sort of a spectacular $193 million in the quarter. That represented 158% of net earnings on a conversion basis and represented 26% of sales. Free cash flow was $181 million. Same story, 149% of net earnings here for conversions. So it was quite a strong finish in the fourth quarter to what was a historic year for us. 
Next slide. Here if we look at the fourth quarter income statement, you'll see bookings were basically flat. There are couple of reasons for that. The fourth quarter last year, our orders were up 23% over the prior year, so it was an exceptionally unusual and difficult comp. And we had 3 things happen that we detailed. Last year, we had quite a substantial Mexican order for Neptune that tends to be a nonrecurring type of item when those happen. Some unique shipments in the camera arena around some specific CapEx that was going on in China. And then we had a Gaz de France project largely booked and that was completed in the fourth quarter of this year. So those were unusual headwinds that exceeded $30 million. 
The backlog is up though, as you can see, by 5.5%. So backlog was $828 million, which is an all-time record for our year-ending backlog number for us. Net sales were up 9%, 7% organic. Gross profit, as we covered, was up 20 bps. Operating income at $187 million was up 13% and operating margin was at above 25% here, up 80 bps in the quarter. 
You can see the tax rate was actually a little bit of a negative headwind for us in the quarter compared to last year. We had a particularly favorable tax rate in Q4 last year, 27.7% for us, and the fourth quarter this year was 29%. So that cost us $0.02 a share. Nonetheless, we still are in at $1.23 on DEPS.
Next slide. If you'll look at fourth quarter cash flow, it's, for us, kind of just a breathtaking accomplishment. $193 million of operating cash flow in the quarter, and that's up dramatically. Last year, our record year was $155 million. And if you'll look at fourth quarter 2009, it was $120 million. So we just continue to pileup the cash. And if you look at the variances, it's up 24%, as you can see on this slide, from the fourth quarter a year ago, and 61% from 2009. 
Next slide. Here we'll start to look at the full year enterprise results. Next slide. We again achieved a record result on an annual basis, as well as a quarter. On an annual basis it just, again, includes everything in the kitchen sink here: historic levels of orders, backlog sales, net earnings, EBITDA, operating and free cash flow. 
Sales for the year were up 17%. Organic growth for 2011 was 13%. Remember, when we established guidance at the beginning of the year, we thought organic growth might be 9% to 11%, so it came in substantially stronger than we had expected. Gross margin was up 80 bps to 54.2%, operating margin up 200 bps to 23.6%, which is really an incredible achievement for all of our 28 P&Ls around the world that are so terrifically focused on margin and cash and growth. 
Our EBITDA for the year was up $164 million to $802 million. By the way, we had a remeasurement gain in the second quarter, and we're excluding that from this $802 million number. Otherwise it would have been $809 million, but that's a nonrecurring item. The EBITDA margin expanded to 28.7% for the full year and operating cash flow for the full year was $602 million or 22% of revenue. Free cash flow at $561 million was 20% of sales. So another terrific year for the Roper family of businesses. 
Next slide. Here, if we look at the full year income statement, you'll see bookings were up 11% on the year. Net sales up 17%, organic 13%. Gross margin up 80 bps, operating margin up 200 bps, as we said. 
Tax rate on the year came in at 29.4, which was a 130 bps headwinds compared to the prior year. So that cost us $0.08 a share. Despite that, we've reported DEPS of $4.34. And the one thing we point out there, again, is that remeasurement gain is in the GAAP number at $4.34. 
Next slide. Here if we look at our EBITDA growth, you can see the trends and performance in terms of capturing our gross margins in the form of EBITDA for our investors. We had EBITDA of $802 million as we mentioned, which is up $300 million from 2 years ago. Our EBITDA margins 2 years ago were 24.5%. And  common questions to us always are, "How are you ever going to keep those margins? They've got to degrade. Nobody can have a margins like this. They're going to regress to some artificial mean that S&P 500 companies are stuck with." But that's not the case here. As you can see our margins went up from 24.5% to 26.7% last year, and just continued forward at 28.7% this year. That's a 420 basis point improvement in just 2 years in our EBITDA margins. 
Next slide. Our full year cash flow, again, tells the story of Roper's business model. $602 million in operating cash flow, representing 22% of revenue. Free cash flow, 20% of revenue. A terrific execution throughout the enterprise. Networking capital, still, in our definition of inventory receivables less payables and accruals is like 6% or less. So just spectacular performance from the field here. And you can see that trend up from $367 million of operating cash flow in '09 to $500 million to $602 million, and we're forecasting continued growth in 2012. 
Next slide. We have a really terrific balance sheet. We closed out the year in a very strong position. You can see cash was up $68 million to $338 million. Our undrawn revolver is totally undrawn at $750 million. Last year it was -- we had $520 million. And we get the benefit of trailing EBITDA coming up at $802 million. Last year it was $638 million. So we when you think about all those kind of investment-grade characteristics and multiply it times EBITDA and you look at the power that we have, we've got really a spectacular balance sheet. 
Gross debt to capitalization is 25.4%. And when you look at the net debt number, we have about $1,085,000,000 in gross debt. With the $338 million in cash, you'd have net debt of $747 million against $802 million of trailing EBITDA. So it goes without saying that 2012 is likely going to be a strongly above average acquisition year for Roper, and we're very excited about our prospects in that arena. 
Next slide. Here we'll get into the individual segments. All of them are just faithfully executing the business models so that they drive. And you can see there's just no softness anywhere inside the full year activity. RF Technology's sales were up 17%, operating profit up 35% and margins up 300 bps. Industrial Technology was up 21%, OP up 29% and margins up 150. And boy, when you're up 150 and you show [ph] 28.2% OP margin for industrial flow control businesses, I can't take my hat off enough to the quality of people we have and the niches we've chosen to serve. 
Medical & Scientific Imaging sales were up 11%, OP was up 14% and margins were up 50. And then Energy Systems & Controls was up 19%, with OP up 31% and margins up to 50. Overall, the team produced 13% organic growth. They feel quite good about going into 2012. And the broad-based margin expansion we enjoyed this year, we think will continue next year. 
Next slide. So here we'll look with the smallest segment as a function of the total up 21% is Medical & Scientific Imaging. They had an unusual fourth quarter, just mathematically we'll talk about. But really, the story is the Medical growth continues with an even better prospects at Northern Digital than we originally identified. We've got significant OEM business that we believe is coming online in 2012. 
We had organic sales decline in the fourth quarter, really, caused by 2 primary events. We had lower camera sales for a -- an original equipment manufacturing videoconferencing series of things that go on with 1 particular large client and they were in decline this past year, and the fourth quarter really brought that to a head. And then our Rugged Mobile computer shipments, which we rarely talk about because it's certainly not the key to our Medical or Scientific Imaging businesses. But they enjoyed unusual activity in the fourth quarter last year with their Rugged Mobile applications and the certain overnight shipping arrangements, and those are really waned this year in the fourth quarter. 
We had very strong margin performance in the fourth quarter against an all-time record last year in the fourth quarter. So we wound up with 25% OP in the fourth quarter. For the full year, you can see sales were up 11%, OP 14% and margin up 50. 
As we look to 2012, what we see in the segment is that Medical growth we expect to continue. We have several new product launches that are occuring, generally starting in Europe and then coming into North America. We expect those to provide a lift in the second half of the year. We'll get the benefit of some growth from the Northern Digital acquisition in the first part of the year, and then it will turn into organic growth in the second. But we expect a very strong first quarter from Northern Digital. 
We've got significant backlog in the Scientific Imaging arena that supports modest growth for the year. It certainly going to be, probably, the low point of 2012 organic growth for Roper. But that said, given fears around research funding, as we've gone through our planning reviews with people, people seem reasonably confident. And certainly the physical science aspect of this looks better than the molecular and biological aspect does. But on balance, it should be a net gain for us in 2012. And we are confident we're going to have margin expansion from growth in the other arenas. 
Next slide. If we look at the Energy Systems & Controls. Here you can see just virtually all the divisions here, with the exception of Zetec's nuclear steam gen activity, have had very strong growth across the segment. They all have record margin performance. We continue to get our diesel engine shut-off systems that we've talked about frequently, continue to grow at a very rapid pace. We don't see any pullback in that area. We have had record results, really, for Compressor Controls and -- primarily due to the continuing expansion of projects around the world. And you can see for the full year, our revenue was up 19%, OP up 31% and margin up 250. To have OP in the fourth quarter at 30.5% is really quite substantial performance. 
If you look at 2012, we don't really see any headwinds here. We would expect that this segment ought to grow the fastest of our 4 segments in 2012. It's got major drivers, none of which are waning in any way with the oil and gas markets remaining favorable. Compressor Controls has a backlog that assures its success for the year. And the bolt-on acquisitions, which we haven't talked a lot about because they're small, United Controls down earlier this year, gives us access to very substantial OEMs that we haven't been involved within the past. 
Trinity, is a software company in the U.K. that's just coming onboard now. It's a modest revenue but it gives us a lot of technology and can allow us to get Compressor Control even more and better than software activity. And then Hao Ying is a Chinese company. It's our first Chinese acquisition that we acquired for Dynisco. Dynisco is enjoying very nice growth. Probably everyone is aware of that tire manufacturing CapEx is doing well. And the things that Hao Ying can do for us in China are similar to what we do in the U.S. We have a lot of new products coming online and having our own in-house manufacturing capability and distribution channel reach directly in China for the rubber industry is quite useful for us. 
Next slide. Here, if we look at Industrial Technology, the fourth quarter was up 20% in sales, 25% in OP, margins at 29.2%. Let's not be confused, those are not gross margins of an industrial company, those are the operating margins of our flow control businesses. Fluid handling, very rapid growth from new customers expanding oil and gas markets here. Certainly, fracking is driving a significant portion of our growth. 
A very important indicator for us, our Material Test business that's headquartered in Denmark, along with the Dynisco business I just mentioned, were 2 of 3 indicators that late in 2008 about the downturn for '09 that people are going to experience. And they finished the fourth quarter at a very strong rate, up over 20%. Dynisco finished very strong as well. So we haven't seen any sign of any deterioration in forward activity. 
Neptune is continuing to grow in the U.S., despite the concerns that we and others would have had about the municipal market. And the fourth quarter was -- it was favorable for Neptune. And we delivered both growth and execution with these record margins. Full year, you can see sort of similar, 20% in the fourth quarter, 21% for the year, OP up 29% and margin up 150 basis points. 
For this coming year, we really don't see anything that's going to arrest the trend, the major drivers. We get a big benefit from the Toronto project at Neptune, which will roll out more rapidly in 2012 than it did in '11. We don't see any pullback in any of our flow control businesses. And then we have new products in Material Test that ought to allow that continue to grow. So we think it'll do nicely in the high end of any range we've established for organic growth. 
Then we look at the RF Technology business. And here in the fourth quarter, we had sales up 4%, OP up 12% and a significant margin improvement up 190 bps. The organic was flatter than -- it was far better than what it looked here because we had the completion of the France -- Gaz de France automatic meter reading project, which was completed. So from a revenue view point, it helped us all year but in the prior year it had been in the bookings. So that was a certain artificial headwind on a comparative basis. 
We had very strong toll tag shipments that offset somewhat less project work in tolling in the fourth quarter. But we continue to have growth in our Software-as-a-Service subscription and software maintenance businesses. We had, really, a terrific contribution throughout the year from our college campus software and integrated security solutions out of CBORD. They accounted for a significant portion of our growth in the full year. 
And importantly, you can see that full year sales growth for RF was up 17%, OP up 35% and margin up 300. And we're encouraged about margins in general in RF. So when we look to 2012, what we see is continued growth in the software and SaaS businesses that we have. We think toll project and maintenance growth will be stronger next year, while tag shipments will be lower. 
We have this headwind that we have to get through with the Gaz de France project that won't reoccur, although we'll have ongoing service with it. So that will be a drag into 2012. But the operating margin expansion that we expect to see by having the software businesses becoming a bigger portion of the segment, and the backlog that we have in this segment gives us confidence that we'll produce both more cash and operating profit in 2012 in RF. 
Next slide. Here, as we get into the 2012 guidance -- next slide. The full year guidance for us is $467 million to $487 million, and the assumptions around that is that organic growth would be up from a 5% at the low end of the range to 8% or more at the high end of the range. Last year, we said 7% to -- or 9% to 11%, I believe. This year, 5% to 8%, given all the uncertainty in the world, seems like a rational approach to this. 
We're assuming currency is the same as it was at January 31, 2012. The tax rate, we're assuming is going to be about 30%. Share count creeps up a little bit from 98.5 million diluted shares to 99.5 million. First quarter we'd see coming in between $1.01 and $1.05, and full year operating cash flow should exceed $650 million in 2012. I'm sure some people worry that we haven't commented much about Europe in here. It's not overly significant for us. We don't see much difficulty in Europe. Our businesses there are often exporters to emerging markets, so we remain pretty comfortable with what's happening in Europe. 
Next slide. If you'll look at the 2011 summary then, we had an all-time performance record for orders and sales, net earnings, cash flow and EBITDA. We had terrific margin leverage. And when we looked back on the year, one of the things that I didn't cover that's worth really talking about in the income statement is, if we look at the difference, we were up -- operating income reached $661 million, up from $514 million. So that's $147 million up in operating income, while sales were up by $411 million. So you take that $147 million OP and divide it by an incremental $411 million in net sales, you get operating profit leverage of 36%. So our leverage is still world-class, and we expect that to continue in 2012. 
Operating cash flow at $602 million speaks for itself, 20% free cash flow to sales. I don't think you can find people doing that. And our family of businesses and our end markets are continuing to look quite reasonable for 2012. So we expect to have another record year in 2012, and we certainly are off to a good start. So with that, John, I think we're open for questions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, Brian, can you talk about in your oil and gas-related businesses whether or not a reduction in gas rig counts? An increase in oil rig counts? Are you -- is that good for Roper, not good, or are you guys indifferent to that? A
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, Brian, can you talk about in your oil and gas-related businesses whether or not a reduction in gas rig counts? An increase in oil rig counts? Are you -- is that good for Roper, not good, or are you guys indifferent to that? And then I have one follow-up.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Matt, we're probably indifferent to that, although it's probably a little bit better for us on the oil side than on the gas side. I mean, we have products that are used in both of those applications. And as Roper Pump, in particular, they've continued to
componenttext: Matt, we're probably indifferent to that, although it's probably a little bit better for us on the oil side than on the gas side. I mean, we have products that are used in both of those applications. And as Roper Pump, in particular, they've continued to expand their new products, and in fact have worked with our Dynisco business on some polymer technology for one of their power sections, which allows that to be utilized in downhole oil applications, as well as what they had been doing previously for gas applications. So we're largely indifferent to that. And also, remember, an awful lot of this is about building the base and expanding into some channels that we hadn't been before. So it's not only the growth in the drilling activity overall, but also some good channel development that those guys have done.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then can you sort of walk through the same things, specifically, talking about Compressor Controls? More around kind of the application-specific things that are driving what Brian seemed to describe as a backlog that's -- gives you very good visibilit
componenttext: And then can you sort of walk through the same things, specifically, talking about Compressor Controls? More around kind of the application-specific things that are driving what Brian seemed to describe as a backlog that's -- gives you very good visibility through the year. Is this mostly -- is this more of -- are you seeing good replacement or retrofit activity, or is this new capacity? And I guess can you talk about the what you've been doing maybe on the power side of that business as well?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, generally, what happens with us is while we do OEM to certainly very well-known manufacturers, most of our business is aftermarket business. So we get a whole lot of several year out from new CapEx activity, where people want to see us deploy better
componenttext: Well, generally, what happens with us is while we do OEM to certainly very well-known manufacturers, most of our business is aftermarket business. So we get a whole lot of several year out from new CapEx activity, where people want to see us deploy better technology for their controls than perhaps they had in the original purchase. It's just a phenomenon that's not unusual. So people who are looking for productivity or more throughput or less consumption in the gas and the pipeline frequently are going to choose us. That business -- we've really become quite effective in distribution channels around the world and we're sort of growing in China as well. So we really have -- anybody who wants to have LNG operations that are as efficient as possible in getting the least consumption of gas inside their gas turbines is likely to look to us as a solution provider. That reputation just continues to build. So from an aftermarket perspective, the projects that we get a bid on -- I mean, it would be not the least bit unusual for us to have 6 months of backlog at Compressor Control and known service work that's going to fill things up. So in fact, we completely redesigned our Des Moines headquarters last year, created a much, much more engineering-oriented facility that gives people an opportunity to work in teams in a very different way. It's certainly among our most exciting businesses. We've got just world-class human resources in that business. We're at the early phases of our growth, frankly. And good heavens, if we got to exporting gas and LNG, it would be phenomenal what will happen to our business in that area.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to on Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.
componenttext: And next we'll go to on Mark Douglass with Longbow Research.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: When we talk about the Medical, obviously there's some weakness in the whole segment but you had some tough comps. But what degree is that attributable to some product introductions? And you mentioned you have some new products rolling out in the back hal
componenttext: When we talk about the Medical, obviously there's some weakness in the whole segment but you had some tough comps. But what degree is that attributable to some product introductions? And you mentioned you have some new products rolling out in the back half, so does that keep people on the sidelines a little bit? And what gives you a..

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. No, these are not substitution products at all. These are entirely new products. So we've had ongoing ramp-up on certain kinds of positioning devices for MRI technology. We've got new products in Verathon around GlideScope. We have this Hardscape prod
componenttext: No. No, these are not substitution products at all. These are entirely new products. So we've had ongoing ramp-up on certain kinds of positioning devices for MRI technology. We've got new products in Verathon around GlideScope. We have this Hardscape product that we've launched in Europe that we haven't brought into the U.S. at all yet. We have a product called the AortaScan that is a phenomenal product. All these things are just ramping up. In fact, we have a -- international sales meeting starting Sunday night with the Verathon people for 3 days to try to gear it up. And we've had similar situation last week with our CIVCO people around growth opportunities outside the U.S. So we're quite comfortable with that. And really any -- this organic stuff in Q4 was really not -- affected Medical much in any way. I mean Medical is still performing very well. We expect it will continue to do that. This is really much more about a business that we have stuck inside Scientific and Imaging, because it just doesn't fit anywhere. And that business had a really strong Q4 last year, which is quite unusual. And it had it's more normalized weak results in the fourth quarter of this year. So that's -- Rugged Mobile has, for a long time, been a -- not a typical Roper business in terms of performance. But we've got a lot of energy in that business and people are hopeful for a much brighter 2012.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then moving to industrial tech. I mean, it actually accelerated growth versus the third quarter on a year-over-year basis. I assume a lot of that is due in large part to the fluid handling and Material Test. And then looking at Material Test, ho
componenttext: Okay. And then moving to industrial tech. I mean, it actually accelerated growth versus the third quarter on a year-over-year basis. I assume a lot of that is due in large part to the fluid handling and Material Test. And then looking at Material Test, how much of that is automotive-driven, excuse the pun, and what do you see going into '12?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the derived demand for that business is really anyone who is utilizing or looking to understand their material content better. And so as one could imagine, that does include everyone who is making steel or aluminum or other types of really h
componenttext: Well, I mean, the derived demand for that business is really anyone who is utilizing or looking to understand their material content better. And so as one could imagine, that does include everyone who is making steel or aluminum or other types of really hard surface materials. And so there is, obviously, some impact from automotive production and for the supply chain, even though we don't really sell very much to any of the automotive companies or even the Tier 1 automotive suppliers directly. We have some sales there, but that's not the primary end market. But clearly, the fact that automotive production has come back into 2011, it is expected to grow again in 2012, I think, is adding some benefit for our Material Test business.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then is it safe to say that the non-Neptune businesses probably outperformed Neptune in the quarter?
componenttext: And then is it safe to say that the non-Neptune businesses probably outperformed Neptune in the quarter?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think that's fair. I don't think that's...
componenttext: No. I don't think that's fair. I don't think that's...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Or maybe year-to-year.
componenttext: Or maybe year-to-year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: On an annual basis, the answer is yes. For the quarter itself, I mean, Neptune continued to do very well. And remember we are ramping up with the Toronto project, which did give us some additional revenue in the fourth quarter, and that will continue into
componenttext: On an annual basis, the answer is yes. For the quarter itself, I mean, Neptune continued to do very well. And remember we are ramping up with the Toronto project, which did give us some additional revenue in the fourth quarter, and that will continue into 2012 and '13 and '14.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Deane Dray with Citi.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Deane Dray with Citi.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: For the orders this quarter, it's rare that we'd see a book to bill below 1. And Brian, as I recall, anytime this has happened, it really hasn't happened for like 10 quarters, you bring out these historical references about any time you're below 1. You ca
componenttext: For the orders this quarter, it's rare that we'd see a book to bill below 1. And Brian, as I recall, anytime this has happened, it really hasn't happened for like 10 quarters, you bring out these historical references about any time you're below 1. You can see -- you get some one-off comments, but then look at the trend that comes back. We didn't hear that this time. You gave a little bit of the comp issue. But just put this in perspective about the order activity, bid activity and some of the leading indicators because this is a little bit of an anomaly to see you below 1.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, not below 1, Deane. I think what we've said is from 0.97 to 1.03 is kind of a ban that we would have. And routinely, I don't know what percent it is -- a very high percentage time, we're between 0.97 and 1.03. But we had some unusual situations
componenttext: Yes. Well, not below 1, Deane. I think what we've said is from 0.97 to 1.03 is kind of a ban that we would have. And routinely, I don't know what percent it is -- a very high percentage time, we're between 0.97 and 1.03. But we had some unusual situations in Q4 last year. The large Mexico City project that we revealed to people in industrial in fourth quarter from an order perspective. And then, obviously, it wouldn't repeat in the fourth quarter this year. So that alone explains most of the book to bill in industrial. And then RF is a lumpy situation. Book to bill in RF was weak at like 0.9 or something like that. But we're not really worried about that. We have huge backlog in RF and the non-toll project activity is quite robust going into 2012, so it's not much of a factor. If we had a poor book to bill in the first quarter, then we'd be talking more about that. But we're -- we wouldn't have established organic guidance at 5%, 8% or more if we are really worried about book to bill. But it's a fair thing to point out, because normally we would expect it to not be worse than 0.97. This time it was 0.94 but there were this 3 unusual events with cameras and Rugged Mobile and Mexico that aren't really core to the overall nature of activity. So the rest of it was much more in our wheelhouse.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for my follow-up, we pay attention to how you craft the expectations regarding M&A and a strongly above average year, both in terms of firepower within the balance sheet. But take us through what you're seeing in the pipeline pricing and in part
componenttext: Okay. And for my follow-up, we pay attention to how you craft the expectations regarding M&A and a strongly above average year, both in terms of firepower within the balance sheet. But take us through what you're seeing in the pipeline pricing and in particular -- opportunities to add on Medical. There's big leverage to be able to drop in a new medical line into an existing sales force. And my question there is are you restricted at all as to what type of medical products, that you need to be complementary to some of your existing surgical products, or can you go into some newer areas on the Medical side?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we have kind of 3 different sales forces that are available to us. So at the low end, you have the overnight delivery people with consumables and telephony-driven responses with hospitals around the world. And that -- we're extremely confident in th
componenttext: Well, we have kind of 3 different sales forces that are available to us. So at the low end, you have the overnight delivery people with consumables and telephony-driven responses with hospitals around the world. And that -- we're extremely confident in that area with the right call centers, right SKU, sorting almost the mini-distributor function. Then we have the technical sell around radiation oncology, which is a unique specific trade calling on a very small niche in a hospital and has to really be joined at the hip with the major OEM manufacturers that are involved in that equipment. And then we have the third sales force, which is the Verathon sales force, which is a more generic. But they're selling products that are in the thousands of dollars, not the hundreds of thousand of dollars. Not really CapEx for the most part. Those people have very specific people they call on. It's organized into an acute care activity and a private practice activity. It's easy for them to add things in those 2 areas. Increasingly we're investing outside the U.S. in channel presence, and that's doing really well. So it is certainly possible that we can do bolt-on acquisitions and take advantage of our existing sales force in that area. But we look at a lot of things in Medical and I have to say a number of things we look at are in software and medical and we find those to be exceptionally exciting.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just in terms of expectations, how close do you think you are to making some announcements on the M&A side?
componenttext: And just in terms of expectations, how close do you think you are to making some announcements on the M&A side?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: You never know. You just -- you never know. I mean, we're sitting here with a lot of capacity, which is matched by a lot of patience. So our goal is to buy things at the right price at the right time and have the right people in place to monitor them. One
componenttext: You never know. You just -- you never know. I mean, we're sitting here with a lot of capacity, which is matched by a lot of patience. So our goal is to buy things at the right price at the right time and have the right people in place to monitor them. One of the things we did last year, which is very important strategically, is add 2 new very senior resources. We brought Neil Hunn in to focus on Medical activity. Neil is an M&A pro, former CFO of a publicly traded company running the revenue business in Medical. Just a world-class guy. But we want to marry him up with a world-class software guy. We brought Joe Bergera in, who's worked for Wolters Kluwer and Sage for his career. Joe's a domain expert around architecture, platforms and software and trying to get our software leaders more capable of doing more bolt-ons and activities. So we have dramatically enhanced our internal capability to assimilate both software and medical companies, which we really needed to do. I think the rest of us here in Sarasota, we were only interested in doing transactions that brought world-class management teams and didn't take too much more of our time. So now that we really beefed up our capability in this area, we have a lot more firepower intellectually than we did in the past. And then fortunately, that matches our balance sheet.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Alex Blanton with Clear Harbor Asset Management.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Alex Blanton with Clear Harbor Asset Management.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd like to just continue that last topic. You mentioned software as being an area of focus and on acquisitions. And historically, Roper has acquired companies that were often converting from old analog technology to new digital technology, and that invol
componenttext: I'd like to just continue that last topic. You mentioned software as being an area of focus and on acquisitions. And historically, Roper has acquired companies that were often converting from old analog technology to new digital technology, and that involve a lot of new software-driven equipment. So that the software, really, was an integral part of the equipment business that you were in. And that's started with the CCC, which by the way, I was happy to hear that you think you're still in the early phases of growth with CCC given that you acquired it almost 20 years ago. In September of 1992, it was $17 million in sales. So at this point, after 20 years, it's pretty impressive to be in the early phases of growth. But it's software-driven mainly, very -- equipment's only a small part of it. So going forward, are you really going to go into standalone software, or are you just going to continue to acquire equipment businesses that have a high component of software? Could you clarify that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, no. We'll do both. If there was sort of one core in Roper that unifies the enterprise, it would be algorithms. Every one of our businesses almost is dependent on some kind of algorithmic technology and feedback mechanism for people, for data. And so
componenttext: Well, no. We'll do both. If there was sort of one core in Roper that unifies the enterprise, it would be algorithms. Every one of our businesses almost is dependent on some kind of algorithmic technology and feedback mechanism for people, for data. And so that's almost always a core of something. But our recent acquisitions, many of them have been pure software plays, certainly iTrade and CBORD and Horizon. Back in '04, Freight Matching, which was a core portion of what we wanted to acquire when we did the TransCore transaction, and it's now split off as a separate company. We acquired another company called Getloaded, pure software. They have a link up in Canada of pure software. Certainly, a lot of acquisitions that were moving through the pipeline now are software-driven things. I think every once in a while, we'll look at an equipment business. But for the most part, the software businesses or the digitization of analog businesses, as you pointed out, are more attractive in terms of shareholder return on a cash-on-cash basis.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. But...
componenttext: Absolutely. But...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: They're [ph] just spectacular the last several years.
componenttext: They're [ph] just spectacular the last several years.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: But still you're -- these are software for Roper equipment not software for somebody else's equipment.
componenttext: But still you're -- these are software for Roper equipment not software for somebody else's equipment.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. That is true. We're not Exilica [ph] or Rockwell Automation or something. No. We're not doing software for other people's products. When we're saying software, we're doing software for other people to manage that cash in their channel. So if you look
componenttext: No. That is true. We're not Exilica [ph] or Rockwell Automation or something. No. We're not doing software for other people's products. When we're saying software, we're doing software for other people to manage that cash in their channel. So if you look at what CBORD does, it's software that's managing campus activity and monetizing activity and showing people what the flow looks like. When you're looking at Horizon, it's pure software, no products, providing cash register support mechanisms and telling people about the supply chain. When you look at Freight Matching, it's pure software subscription model where thousands and thousands of people are looking every minute about available freight movement. When you look at iTrade, you're looking at people sorting through supply chains so that vendors can sell to supermarkets. So we like networks as such and we continue to look at software companies that provide niche networks to people.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is this. EPS last year for the year as a whole was up 29.9%, and that was well above your average rate. And of course, you also had some headwinds like higher tax rate and so on. But guidance for this year is only 9.9%, less than 10%
componenttext: Okay. Second question is this. EPS last year for the year as a whole was up 29.9%, and that was well above your average rate. And of course, you also had some headwinds like higher tax rate and so on. But guidance for this year is only 9.9%, less than 10% above 2011. Actually, that's -- it's a little bit higher than the consensus, which was looking for a 9.5% increase. So it's not a big surprise. But one of the reasons could be that you didn't make very many big acquisitions last year, so you have to depend more on your organic growth this year. But also, are there any big headwinds that you're -- could you just go over the things that made last year above average and might be responsible for making this year below average in terms of EPS growth? Because, I think, investors are kind of looking for a continuation of the long-term trend, which is about 20%.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the long-term trend, it certainly includes acquisitions. Our guidance [indiscernible] that simple. SO if you're looking at...
componenttext: Yes. Well, the long-term trend, it certainly includes acquisitions. Our guidance [indiscernible] that simple. SO if you're looking at...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: But you didn't make very many...
componenttext: But you didn't make very many...

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. So you don't have them rolling in so much into 2012. The last 3 years, we've done about $1 billion, $1.25 billion in acquisitions and we generated cash of about $1.4 billion. So we've reinvested our cash at about 75% clip into acquisitions. And the
componenttext: Right. So you don't have them rolling in so much into 2012. The last 3 years, we've done about $1 billion, $1.25 billion in acquisitions and we generated cash of about $1.4 billion. So we've reinvested our cash at about 75% clip into acquisitions. And the next 3 years, good heavens, we're giving a one year guidance at $650 million, so it's obviously -- we'd expect well over $2 billion in cash in the next 3 years so that you can -- it's easy to see how that will carry [ph]. When that does, you'll get a lot more revenue, so the overall revenue will be going up. So in any one year, you can't look at a step change, you have to look at it -- what it is over time. We don't see any disruption in any long-term trends around Roper. We're just going to continue to have compound growth that's favorable. It just doesn't look like organic growth on an acquisition until a year later.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. What was some of the things, though, that last year might have, in addition to not having acquisitions to roll in this year, but might have made last year a tough comparison with this year?
componenttext: Right. What was some of the things, though, that last year might have, in addition to not having acquisitions to roll in this year, but might have made last year a tough comparison with this year?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, you had record performance last year. You're looking at lousy GDP around the world. You're looking at people who are terrified about a whole variety of end markets. Our organic growth in the fourth quarter, I think, is best-in-class. Our projection
componenttext: Well, you had record performance last year. You're looking at lousy GDP around the world. You're looking at people who are terrified about a whole variety of end markets. Our organic growth in the fourth quarter, I think, is best-in-class. Our projection around organic growth for 2012 -- I haven't seen anybody projecting 8% or more. So if we were simply at the high end of our organic growth and we capture the kind of leverage we expect to capture, we have more like 13% diluted earnings per share year-over-year variance, Alex. And that's without acquisitions. I don't think we're going through the year without acquisitions. So if you said, "Can you get several points out of earnings related to acquisitions," the answer is yes. So yes, I don't think it's -- to go back over all those things that were favorable, we kind of -- we're doing that in the slides. If you look at our statements going into '12, we aren't really describing any deterioration. All you're doing is having a slower rate of organic growth based on anabysmal global GDP forecast and fears people have in Europe. So we're hoping not to participate in those negatives.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you average the 2 years, it's right in line with your historic.
componenttext: Yes. If you average the 2 years, it's right in line with your historic.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Wondering if -- will you might be able to just help us with some color on where your organic expectations for the segments are, relative to the 5% to 8% for the year. It kind of sounded from your comments like, perhaps Energy and Industrial may be above t
componenttext: Wondering if -- will you might be able to just help us with some color on where your organic expectations for the segments are, relative to the 5% to 8% for the year. It kind of sounded from your comments like, perhaps Energy and Industrial may be above the high end of the range or at the high end of the range, and maybe RF and Medical at or below the low end of the range. But maybe you can put a finer point on that color.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we're still expecting double-digit growth out of Energy and Industrial in terms of organic growth in 2012, and then the bottom end of the range on Medical and Imaging. And only modest growth out of RF because of the tolling activity, which is a bi
componenttext: I think we're still expecting double-digit growth out of Energy and Industrial in terms of organic growth in 2012, and then the bottom end of the range on Medical and Imaging. And only modest growth out of RF because of the tolling activity, which is a big piece of that with other stuff growing. We've got a few things that affect us there in RF because we have that headwind around the Gaz de France project. So you take out $30 million or whatever it is out of that, it's a big chunk that you have to beat up. And so we actually, if you were adjusting for that, we'd have growth even there. And it's our first guess out of the box, right, at 5% to 8%. So clearly, the Industrial and Energy segment will drive, but particularly Energy is going to drive outperformance in 2012.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Brian, maybe how are you thinking about the first quarter or cadence through the year? Do you start stronger and end up a little slower towards the end of the range, or do you think it's even through the year, or how do you feel about that?
componenttext: Okay. And Brian, maybe how are you thinking about the first quarter or cadence through the year? Do you start stronger and end up a little slower towards the end of the range, or do you think it's even through the year, or how do you feel about that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't know, Terry, it's hard to say. I mean, we're expecting kind of maybe 6% to 8% organic growth inside our guidance for the quarter with $1.01 and $1.05 with really strong leverage. Whether it could be better than that, it's hard to say. I think we w
componenttext: I don't know, Terry, it's hard to say. I mean, we're expecting kind of maybe 6% to 8% organic growth inside our guidance for the quarter with $1.01 and $1.05 with really strong leverage. Whether it could be better than that, it's hard to say. I think we were impressed as we went through our year-end reviews with people that -- if you didn't have all the headline news and you didn't have the political environment and the conversations that are going on, our people would probably be forecasting better results, because they are seeing really excellent results. They're not seeing a big fall off in anything. But it tends to make everybody conservative.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I know there's a lot of noise as you mentioned in the 4Q orders. But I'm just wondering if you were to try to strip out the noise, can you give us a sense of how the order trends were through the quarter? In other words, did you end up stro
componenttext: Okay. And then I know there's a lot of noise as you mentioned in the 4Q orders. But I'm just wondering if you were to try to strip out the noise, can you give us a sense of how the order trends were through the quarter? In other words, did you end up stronger than you started or was it the strong start and a weak finish?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think -- I wouldn't say month-to-month that it was a big difference. I think the thing that we would have liked to have seen a little more year-end buying than we got in the fourth quarter. That's just residual MRO activity, people have money
componenttext: No. I don't think -- I wouldn't say month-to-month that it was a big difference. I think the thing that we would have liked to have seen a little more year-end buying than we got in the fourth quarter. That's just residual MRO activity, people have money left in their budgets, and particularly in Energy. It's not an all unusual for us to get disproportionate mid-Q4 orders for instruments, because it's just some people can do when they don't want to lose their budgets. I think their activity throughout the year was so strong that they didn't have that leftover money, and so we didn't see that dynamic that we frequently see. But I don't think it has anything to do with Q1 demand or 2012 demand. So I think it's just that it was so strong all year long that people didn't wait to buy things.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, one more on Medical. Brian, I guess I'm just trying to discern, is there any element of the revenue miss in the quarter. At least I perceived it missed your expectations a bit and you could calibrate that. That was just related
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, one more on Medical. Brian, I guess I'm just trying to discern, is there any element of the revenue miss in the quarter. At least I perceived it missed your expectations a bit and you could calibrate that. That was just related to timing. In other words, it slipped by a couple of weeks or something like that, and that's part of what gives you the confidence on the Q1, despite the little bit softer order trends into year end.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, in the segment, in Medical and Imaging, we have our very high-end Optics and Imaging business that had a record year. That didn't shift everything in Q4 that we would like to have seen for a variety reasons that I think we expected to have a banner
componenttext: Well, in the segment, in Medical and Imaging, we have our very high-end Optics and Imaging business that had a record year. That didn't shift everything in Q4 that we would like to have seen for a variety reasons that I think we expected to have a banner 2012. But it was more the unusual comp situation where we had, basically, laboratory camera technology that was going in to Asia that was a one-off thing that could not be repeated. And then just, frankly, without mentioning the company, the videoconferencing business for that enterprise went down dramatically, and they've talked about it in their on own company. And it pulled down us, which makes for an easy comp for 2012 for us, frankly.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: As far as some of the other units you were asking about there, Chris. Neptune continued to do extremely well during the year, and they'll give continued benefit out of Toronto, but even excluding Toronto, they were up kind of in the mid-single digits in 2
componenttext: As far as some of the other units you were asking about there, Chris. Neptune continued to do extremely well during the year, and they'll give continued benefit out of Toronto, but even excluding Toronto, they were up kind of in the mid-single digits in 2011 in the U.S, which I don't think most people looking at the municipal market would've expected something like that. So I think Neptune did a very nice job there. And then of course with the high degree of recurring revenue that comes out of our TransCore total entropic business, that is a business that will naturally kind of be in the mid-single digits, also. And that's kind of what it did in 2011. And then the variation that we see in that business is largely due to the timing of tag shipments based upon when customers are going to replenish their inventory. They've done a very nice job outside the U.S., our total entropic business has, with the expansion of electronic tolling opportunities in Puerto Rico, and continuing with the largest tolling project in the world in Dubai. So we have a nice global footprint there and a large installed base that gives us a lot of visibility and good recurring revenue.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my question was a little more forward-looking than the answer, but I appreciate the great color. Would we -- is that kind of the trend you expect to continue? And then it sounds like Neptune probably just continues to execute on market share dom
componenttext: Okay. And my question was a little more forward-looking than the answer, but I appreciate the great color. Would we -- is that kind of the trend you expect to continue? And then it sounds like Neptune probably just continues to execute on market share domestically?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's right. And also, of course, Toronto ramps up in 2012. But as far as the toll and traffic business, I mean, as Brian said, to the extent that we're at 5% to 8% for the enterprise, we'd expect that to be at the lower side, but with good
componenttext: Yes. I think that's right. And also, of course, Toronto ramps up in 2012. But as far as the toll and traffic business, I mean, as Brian said, to the extent that we're at 5% to 8% for the enterprise, we'd expect that to be at the lower side, but with good margin performance.

componenttext: Absolutely. I think that we have one large turnkey operation that's going more slowly than we'd like, more customer driven. But we're certainly looking forward to an even better 2012 in iTrade than we had in 2011.
