headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and thank you, all, for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our first quarter 2012. Here with me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and thank you, all, for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our first quarter 2012. Here with me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
If you turn to Slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of all that information.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 3, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. After his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Today, we'll kind of go through the first quarter enterprise financial results, and then we'll get into the specific segment detail on the outlook for each of the 4 segments for the second quarter and balance of the year. We'll update you on
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Today, we'll kind of go through the first quarter enterprise financial results, and then we'll get into the specific segment detail on the outlook for each of the 4 segments for the second quarter and balance of the year. We'll update you on our established guidance for the second quarter and our full year guidance and then take your questions. So next slide, please.
The first quarter here was another spectacular quarter. We achieved all-time records for revenue, orders, net earnings, EBITDA, operating and free cash flow in the quarter. Total sales were up 10% and, importantly, organic revenue was up 8%. Our book-to-bill ratio was above 1 at a strong 1.03. Gross margin reached 55%, which is really quite remarkable. And our operating margin leverage was spectacular and the quarter operating margins were up 200 basis points to 24%, and our incremental operating margins were 43% in the first quarter. We closed out the quarter with $205 million in EBITDA and an EBITDA margin of 28.9%. The diluted earnings per share were up 20% to $1.09. More importantly, the free cash flow was up 69% to $131 million in the quarter. It is an all-time record first quarter for us and a great start for 2012.
Next slide. Our first quarter income statement, you can see here at the revenue was up 10%, 8% organic and book-to-bill at 1.03. Gross profit up another 70 basis points to 55%. Operating margins up -- operating income was up 20%. Tax rate was a little bit higher than the first quarter of a year ago, 40 basis points higher, which cost us $0.01. Still net earnings were up 22%, and you can see the slide at 1.09.
Next slide. We had terrific EBITDA growth in the quarter. And if you just continue to look at our trend, you can see on this chart our trailing 12-month EBITDA now is $830 million, up from $685 million last year on a trailing 12-month basis and $519 million on a trailing basis at the end of Q1 2010. So we've added 60% to our EBITDA in just the last 2 years. And our EBITDA margins on a trailing basis are up 400 basis points from 25% in 2010 to 29% in 2012. People from time to time investors ask when are you going to have that deterioration in margin, our plan would be never. We were just going to continue to move up that line because of the culture and focus we have here.
Next slide. Q1 cash flow, you can see another blowout kind of a quarter here. Our cash conversion was very strong. We had $141 million in operating cash flow, which was $0.20 of every dollar of revenue. The conversion on that 131% of net earnings. We invested about $10 million in capital in the quarter, which was 1.4% of revenue right within our kind of 1.2% to 1.6% of revenue plans. So free cash flow was $131 million, 18% of revenue, and the conversion 121, a remarkable performance against last year's first quarter where we had $78 million of free cash flow last year in the first quarter and $131 million this year in the quarter.
Next slide. Our asset velocity continues to improve. I know people keep saying it can't be done, it won't get better, but it does get better. If you look at the same period, inventories now down to 7.5%. Receivables actually dropped down to 14.5%, payables and accruals 14.9%. So our inventory plus receivables less payables and accruals lows closed out at 7.1%. And if you look at the trend in 2009, it was 9.6%, finally breaking below 10%, and people would ask us if you could get any better and the answer is, oh, yes, you can get better. 250 basis points improvement over that 3-year period closing out at 7.1%, very exceptional performance.
Next slide. Balance sheet is pretty strong here. Cash, if we look at a year-ago, we had $261 million of cash, and we closed out this quarter with $452 million of cash. We had drawn a little bit against our revolver, which has $750 million in capacity this time a year ago. Now our undrawn revolver is just that we don't have any drawn against it, so it take that cash and the undrawn revolver and you get a little over $1.2 billion. 
Our trailing 12 months EBITDA is now up to $830 million, quite a substantial increase over the trailing EBITDA at this point in 2011. So it of course has a very dramatic positive effect on all of our credit status. Our gross debt is less than it was a year ago, and our shareholder equity has increased by $450 million in the year from $2,882,000,000 to $3,332,000,000 which then brings down the gross debt to cap number from 30% to 24.4% and gives us a gross debt to EBITDA line at 1.3. You can kind of do the math on the net debt to EBITDA line, and you'll come up with quite a remarkable number. 
Segment details here in the next slide. Really all of the segments had extraordinary performance. They all had double-digit growth in operating profit. Next slide, we'll start with the RF segment. Revenue was up 2% but operating profit was up 12%. Operating margin was 24.6% for our RF of 220 basis points. And they finished the quarter with a gross margin of 52%. They had very strong leverage in higher-margin areas obviously when revenues up to and OP up 12%. We certainly had a headwind on that revenue line because the gas to fronts project which was in 2011 was substantial in Q1 and quite substantial in Q2 was completed last year. So we don't have anything other than administrative revenue associated with that now, which makes tough comps for RF a little bit difficult first couple of quarters of this year. We continue to have expansion in both the security and cashless payment systems that we have for higher education that drove substantial growth in the software platform. And then our SaaS-based solution networks have added subscribers both in our freight systems area and our food service areas and our European expansion continued. Our total entropic traffic service business was led by electronic tolling conversion we're doing in Puerto Rico that adds to our growth and offsets the sort of weakness in other areas around transportation. 
For the rest of 2012, we have fighting as particularly Q2 the Gaz de France project, which is completed. That takes some revenue away, makes for difficult comp. Our toll project activity in the last year second quarter was a record and the last 3 years and quite disproportionate to the rest of the year. So that's a difficult comp. That said, we'll still perform better because of the strength of the rest of the businesses in the RF segment. We expect to have continued growth in software and the SaaS network businesses, particularly in the campus area and the growth of subscribers in our network.
Next slide. Industrial Technology, here, you can see revenue was up double digits at 15%, operating profit was up 25% and our OP margins really are spectacular at 29.5% OP. Compared at the most people's gross margins, that's really quite a remarkable achievement, 29.5% OP, up 230 basis points. Our gross margins in the segment were 51%. 
In the quarter, fluid handling was very strong once again as we continue to gain share in the oil and gas industry with the shale activity that's going on. We have a variety of new products there going into agricultural applications around irrigation, and those are doing very well, and then we've had some pumping activity we do in the transport industrial, which was quite strong in the quarter as well. 
The Toronto water meter project is kind of moving ahead as planned, which gave us some growth in the first quarter. And then the U.S. municipal market in Q1 was relatively strong for Neptune. We have a significant increase in our material analysis equipment and consumables business in Denmark, as industrial production around the world continues to expand that business, continues to have double-digit growth. And the margins in the quarter, as I said, really, were remarkable. It's an all-time record OP margin for us, which is coming from capturing a leverage off of the growth. For the remainder of the year in 2012, with segment backlog is quite strong, and that supports continued growth even if orders were to moderate. And the industrial and shale and markets remain quite favorable to us. And these outstanding margins that we captured in the first quarter, we believe that the things we've done to get better margins are sustainable and will continue throughout 2012 at these higher levels.
Next slide. In the Medical & Scientific Imaging segment, here, you've got revenue growth again double-digit at 12%, OP growth at 24%, operating margin up 250 basis points to 26.6%. We were benefited by having Northern Digital in the first quarter, which delivered exactly what we expected out of them on the revenue side and even better margins. We've had a very, very strong first quarter with it and and the electron microscopy arena, these end markets are pretty good, and we've recently introduced some products there in the last 15 months, which are continuing to grow and add to enhance strength. Our medical expansion internationally continued in the quarter, gave us some growth as well. And then this margin performance that we've gotten from the operating leverage here in Medical really was terrific, and it offset what otherwise would've been a tough first quarter because North American research funding has been quite soft in the Life Science area around our photonics camera businesses was weak. 
For the second quarter, we'll have some continued weakness around those North American research markets. We don't see that ticking up, but it may get better than it was in the first quarter. We expect to continue to grow the Medical business. We are experiencing an increase in consumables as we think organic share in the end markets are favorable in each of the product categories that we participate. 
Northern Digital in the second half of the year will become organic for us, and that will help organic growth profile and the backlog, which is quite heavy we'd like to see that shipments improve in Q2 but they certainly are going to improve strongly in the second half of the year gives us confidence for the full year as a whole.
Next slide. Gross margins I guess I can say were a modest 65% in Medical and Imaging in the quarter. 
Next slide, Energy Systems & Controls, same old story isn't it. Revenue up 15%, operating profit up 23%, OP margins 24%. Energy systems Q1 OP margins are usually the worst of the year, but these are pretty good at 24% but will improve. In the first quarter, our Compressor Controls business continued to grow nicely with projects in both LNG and upstream activities. The oil and gas markets continue to be very favorable to us, and our diesel engine safety shutoff systems in the valves that we provide both oil and gas in marine. Very good instrument sales for the petrochem refining markets and we acquired a small but important company called Cambridge Viscosity, which gives us online Internet capacity around measuring data. I asked John to talk a little bit about the small acquisition.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. We just recently completed the Cambridge acquisition just within the last month of the quarter so they've been contributing awful lot. You can see it on a cash flow statement kind of the range that we paid there. But what this really provides is vis
componenttext: Sure. We just recently completed the Cambridge acquisition just within the last month of the quarter so they've been contributing awful lot. You can see it on a cash flow statement kind of the range that we paid there. But what this really provides is viscosity measurement for fluids, both in the oil area but also in the petrochemical. So it adds additional technology to our existing set a businesses there. And so Cambridge will be able to kind of come into an existing sales channel but also provides additional online work. So outside of the laboratory, into the process. So it's a nice fit both for us as well as for Cambridge and additional technology and they'll be able to benefit from our expanded reach and we'll be able to benefit from their technology. So I think it's a nice acquisition for us, will start to contribute in the second quarter and beyond.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. We're going to have for the rest of the year double-digit growth, we believe. In energy we've got the record backlog at the moment, we have continuing strength in incoming orders and we've got favorable industrial and markets for our one
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. We're going to have for the rest of the year double-digit growth, we believe. In energy we've got the record backlog at the moment, we have continuing strength in incoming orders and we've got favorable industrial and markets for our one business that kind of fits to the industrial area, Dynisco Business, and we expect that that should continue to be okay throughout the year. We've got great operating leverage in the remainder of the year and the execution and focus of everybody in this business is quite strong.
Next slide. This will be our introduction into our 2012 guidance. I'll talk a little bit about the quarter and then the full year and of course we've raised our guidance. 
Next slide. For the full year, we've raised the guidance to $4.75, which is an $0.08 increase on the bottom end and to $4.91, which is an increase on the high-end as well. And in the second quarter, we'll have some headwinds and a little bit of confusing data. Last year, we reported, as you can see on the slide, $1.03, excluding a $0.05 remeasurement gain for foreign currency that we had, and absolutely we treaded that throughout the year on a GAAP basis though and some reporting services, you'll see $1.0, which includes the $0.05 remeasurement gain. But our baseline is $1.0. And the second quarter last year was extraordinary compared to the rest of the year as it was about $1.03 in the second quarter in 2010 was $0.74. So our guidance for the second quarter of this year is $1.11 to $1.15. At the midpoint of that, still a double-digit growth over last year. We do have some comparative headwinds around the gas to fronts contract, which was large last year, that we have this North American research softness and we have some toll shipment timing things that occurred last year. It was the best quarter for the TransCore business in the 3 years in the second quarter last year on a full year basis of course the modest growth trend, and that we expect will continue this year but we won't have to outsize the second quarter. That said, we still look for quite strong results in the second quarter and much stronger results for the second half and the full year. We've raised our operating cash flow projection. We had said it could be $650 million, we're now saving it ought to be between that and $675 million for the full year.
Next slide. So if we recap here before we go to Q&A, the first quarter produced all-time records for revenue, orders, net earnings, EBITDA, operating and free cash flow, spectacular gross margin at 55%. Very strong cash conversion around the operating cash flow and the free cash flow with free cash flow being up 69%. Book-to-bill strongly above 1 at 1.03. Terrific operating leverage, which just speaks to the quality of our different operating teams around the world, and we've raised the guidance as we go into the balance of the year. Certainly, expect to have record performance for 2012 as a whole. And I think with that, John, we can open it up to questions  .

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jay, we're ready for the Q&A session.
componenttext: Jay, we're ready for the Q&A session.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Deane Dray, Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Deane Dray, Citi Investment Research.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: On the comments on shale activity, so we've seen a big ramp-up in all the frac-ing opportunities and you've participated both in the industrial side and the palms and on the Compressor Controllers. But you're saying some investment move away from that giv
componenttext: On the comments on shale activity, so we've seen a big ramp-up in all the frac-ing opportunities and you've participated both in the industrial side and the palms and on the Compressor Controllers. But you're saying some investment move away from that given low nat gas prices. Is that embedded in your guidance? And maybe can you just kind of give us some realtime color as to what you're seeing in that segment?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Of course in our realtime color we're not really on the leading edge of the exploration activity. We're more along in how they go about on the production side once they've ramped up there. So realtime information I think you may be able to get bette
componenttext: Sure. Of course in our realtime color we're not really on the leading edge of the exploration activity. We're more along in how they go about on the production side once they've ramped up there. So realtime information I think you may be able to get better color on that from someone else. Now our activity there is both on the natural gas side as well as on the oil side. So what we have been seeing at least over the last quarter or so is some of those rigs start to move and really ramp up more on the oil side and less on the gas side as you're talking about. And so -- and we still see very solid activity of course as we have more pumps that are deployed, we'll see more aftermarket revenue associated with that as well. And then the LNG and the other investments in order to make sure that the transport and processing of the gas, particularly, and as well as on the oil side but mostly on the gas side, those investments are continuing, and those are in our backlog in one of our businesses in particular. So embedded in our expectation for the rest of the year, I wouldn't say is a ramp-up of activity, it's kind of the steady-state of what we're seeing today. And that's our expectation based upon the backlog and the cold activity out of our businesses.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then a follow-up question over in the RF side. The expense speculation that TransCore's #1 U.S. competitor could be for sale. And there are a number of interesting markets and customer relationships and so forth. Is there -- would you be boxed
componenttext: Great. And then a follow-up question over in the RF side. The expense speculation that TransCore's #1 U.S. competitor could be for sale. And there are a number of interesting markets and customer relationships and so forth. Is there -- would you be boxed out from any trust reason to be able to if that asset were available or convert other side might yet be competitively at a disadvantage if it fell into a stronger competitor?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Are you suggesting that there are weak competitor? It would be safe to say that there are 2 large players in the space that around hardware applications, 1 of those is the European company, the others are ourselves. There are a number of players in back o
componenttext: Are you suggesting that there are weak competitor? It would be safe to say that there are 2 large players in the space that around hardware applications, 1 of those is the European company, the others are ourselves. There are a number of players in back office administrative space in the company you're talking about, which is publicly traded company, has a very, very modest position in back office activity as part of that. So we wouldn't view that as being anticompetitive in any way.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: But I'm not quite sure I understood the answer. Is that -- would there be a reason that it would be make sense to be paired with TransCore?
componenttext: But I'm not quite sure I understood the answer. Is that -- would there be a reason that it would be make sense to be paired with TransCore?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: As the strongest player in the toll and traffic world, I think it's always a beneficial thing for someone to want to join with TransCore. But yet our future, we feel very comfortable with the set of technologies and services that we are providing to that
componenttext: As the strongest player in the toll and traffic world, I think it's always a beneficial thing for someone to want to join with TransCore. But yet our future, we feel very comfortable with the set of technologies and services that we are providing to that marketplace. We are active with our position. But if something else happens there, then we'll happen to see and we'll see what that's looks like.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

componenttext: Brian, you're talking about industrial tech and the very strong margin improvement there. Can you flesh that out what drove the margins and then can you even take it to 30 exiting 2012?

componenttext: That will be a great goal. When we think about weak Q1, we really only think about the energy systems business, I wouldn't think normally about industrial necessarily being weak. There is sometimes based on weather that Neptune that might be very good because you got winter and so forth, but that wasn't the case of this year. But I don't --  seasonal Q4 for them is difficult just because of the timing of the year it is. I think as long as we get revenue growth, we're going to continue to have favorable leverage. Its as simple as that, and we expect to have continued revenue growth. So we would expect to maintain or enhance our leverage.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

componenttext: Okay. But it was enough really strong mix component in this quarter that. . .

componenttext: No. There wasn't any unusual activity. I will say I mean both certainly the pump businesses as they grow throw off a lot of cash and very favorable incremental returns, so that's something that has grown a lot more in the last year or 2 than historically it's grown. So that supports better results in the quarter.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Helpful. And then can you break down your second half versus 1/2 expectations and maybe what you're thinking organic growth consolidated for 2012 at least a bounded range?
componenttext: Okay. Helpful. And then can you break down your second half versus 1/2 expectations and maybe what you're thinking organic growth consolidated for 2012 at least a bounded range?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me take a swag at that. Second half organic growth should be better in our view. We got -- we've had a really -- our guidance at the beginning of the year was 528 and we had in the first quarter. We would expect less than that in the second quarter, a
componenttext: Let me take a swag at that. Second half organic growth should be better in our view. We got -- we've had a really -- our guidance at the beginning of the year was 528 and we had in the first quarter. We would expect less than that in the second quarter, and that or more in the third and fourth quarter. So we'd still stay generally with this kind of update, we're seeing organic growth for the full year and at the low-end of that range in Q2 at the high-end of that range in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I will move to a question from Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: And I will move to a question from Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. Brian, do you think about kind of the strength in the secular growth that has materialized in your energy and pump-related businesses, they may haven't been a huge source of M&A, although you did a deal kind of in that space th
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Brian, do you think about kind of the strength in the secular growth that has materialized in your energy and pump-related businesses, they may haven't been a huge source of M&A, although you did a deal kind of in that space this quarter. But has your view about the long-term attractiveness of these businesses changed for the better, might you be more active there over time?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't rule it out, Jeff, but the reality is as when we look at most of the businesses in that space or trading at relatively high valuations versus their intrinsic long-term value, and they have a lot of assets. We're still pretty wedded in the conce
componenttext: I wouldn't rule it out, Jeff, but the reality is as when we look at most of the businesses in that space or trading at relatively high valuations versus their intrinsic long-term value, and they have a lot of assets. We're still pretty wedded in the concept of being asset light. So I think we would prefer to buy intellectual property that we can deploy a into those businesses using their existing assets. I think to find something that we could buy -- we have looked at a couple of things, but in terms of how we think they should be valued on a cash flow basis, I think some people are overpaying for the flow control assets at the moment. And as you know, we rarely would -- I don't believe ever overpay for anything.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And maybe on that the buyer not overpay, seems you keep the still M&A activity at a relatively low level, what's going on out there in terms of valuations and pipeline and attractiveness of assets?
componenttext: And maybe on that the buyer not overpay, seems you keep the still M&A activity at a relatively low level, what's going on out there in terms of valuations and pipeline and attractiveness of assets?

componenttext: I think there's so much going on that it's a classic case of you don't want to do something that's good when the best thing is around the corner. So and a good better best situation with the strength of our balance sheet, we have we're looking for the best thing. I think we have a couple of best things identified, we're doing a lot of work and we are very excited about what will happen over the next months.

componenttext: Should roll out something meaningful in 2012, it sounds like?

componenttext: I wouldn't rule it out.

componenttext: Very sophisticated sensor technology we have to buy and it oftentimes only produce periodically. The orders have been pretty good, and they do have some occasional bottlenecks and. And they're forecasting kind of treading water in Q2, which suggests that if the beta or if they swam. So I think they understand our view of that. And that's kind of where that is. We don't see anything but upside in Gatan for the full year but they had a really remarkable first quarter. And so they've been pace themselves and all I think kind of gear up here again for Q2, and maybe they're being a little conservative for those of you who are at Pleasanton here listening.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to find out what the assumptions are behind your guidance. You've raised your guidance. I'm not sure I heard the exact reason for that. But what are you assuming about the economy, about Europe, about Asia and whatnot in the guidance. Because my th
componenttext: I want to find out what the assumptions are behind your guidance. You've raised your guidance. I'm not sure I heard the exact reason for that. But what are you assuming about the economy, about Europe, about Asia and whatnot in the guidance. Because my thinking is if you're doing this well in a weak recovery, what are you going to do when the recovery accelerates?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: We'll do better.
componenttext: We'll do better.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: But what if it happens -- what's behind your guidance right now are you assuming continued weakness in the economy?
componenttext: But what if it happens -- what's behind your guidance right now are you assuming continued weakness in the economy?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Certainly what we would see, we've had strength everywhere except for Europe and Europe was positive but it was only up a couple of percent versus everything else being up double-digit, Canada and Asia being up over 20%. So we do just see some areas that
componenttext: Certainly what we would see, we've had strength everywhere except for Europe and Europe was positive but it was only up a couple of percent versus everything else being up double-digit, Canada and Asia being up over 20%. So we do just see some areas that are going to be weak. There's North American research funding scenario puts a real break on our photonics businesses in a negative way. So that kind of pares back revenue some from what we'd like to have. On the other hand, margins in this business are not as high and their cash generation capability is little less good. So they don't hurt us overall. And for the year, we expect to do sort of okay. We're going with the 30% tax rate for the year as a whole. I think if we wind up with 8% organic growth on the year, I think that will -- if it's not best in class, I'd be surprised. So we think that's pretty good. Now if things picked up and became better, then obviously as the year went on, we'd look at higher numbers.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you got a conservative forecast here. Do not looking for much of that improvement in the economy.
componenttext: Okay. So you got a conservative forecast here. Do not looking for much of that improvement in the economy.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would say about that is remember we are a collection of many different niche markets and that things that maybe a little bit weaker that you may be referring to around the housing or something like that, we don't really have any exposure
componenttext: The only thing I would say about that is remember we are a collection of many different niche markets and that things that maybe a little bit weaker that you may be referring to around the housing or something like that, we don't really have any exposure to speak of to new construction activity or automobile production or some of those areas that are more broadly aligned with the more cyclical aspects of GDP. So as we look at our individual niche markets, we see a number of them that I wouldn't characterize as weak today and that we expect them to continue to perform well.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

componenttext: A couple of questions on the Medical and Life Sciences area. Brian, can you talk about where you're at with some of the new products? Are other new product pipelines and we'd Rivera conical couple of the other divisions, I think that you'd talked about in the last quarters or last quarter or 2 having some pretty meaningful launches slated for this year?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we do -- in Verathon, we have a product called Hardscape, which is an important product for us, and it's launched in Europe, it's not launched in the U.S. We still are going through regulatory issues with that to get it launched. I think whenever it
componenttext: Well, we do -- in Verathon, we have a product called Hardscape, which is an important product for us, and it's launched in Europe, it's not launched in the U.S. We still are going through regulatory issues with that to get it launched. I think whenever it launches, it should be a very good product. We don't have it in much of our guidance for the balance of this year, it's more likely to be something that could help in 2013 from the U.S. perspective. But sales have started in Europe. And in fact, our clear of Verathon is on a plane as we speak right now going over to have some meetings over there with people on the subject. So I think that's pretty good. We have some and MEDTEC products there launching in the second half and some things that they've been working on better we kind of know were going to be beneficial in the second half of the year. And then Northern Digital, we're doing several things in Northern Digital to broaden their range of activity, which we expect to pay dividends in the second half.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, you mentioned in terms of the headwinds you are encountering in the second quarter, the Gaz de France, the total shipments being may be unusually high last year. Are you able to ballpark or quantify if you will the whole revenue t
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, you mentioned in terms of the headwinds you are encountering in the second quarter, the Gaz de France, the total shipments being may be unusually high last year. Are you able to ballpark or quantify if you will the whole revenue that you guys are kind of comping against? Is that a $5 million headwind $50 million headwind? Can you frame that up a little bit for us?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd say a little north of $10 million.
componenttext: I'd say a little north of $10 million.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then are you able to quantify as well in imaging what the impact is with regards to the downward pressure in NIH and other public funding sources? Or maybe how much of your business there do you feel is driven by public funding?
componenttext: And then are you able to quantify as well in imaging what the impact is with regards to the downward pressure in NIH and other public funding sources? Or maybe how much of your business there do you feel is driven by public funding?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just kind of clarify in terms of that. When we said, I'd say a little over $10 million for just the towing and gas truck, which both happen to be in the RF segment. It could be a little higher than that on a comparable basis. But the Imaging is a differen
componenttext: Just kind of clarify in terms of that. When we said, I'd say a little over $10 million for just the towing and gas truck, which both happen to be in the RF segment. It could be a little higher than that on a comparable basis. But the Imaging is a different thing and of course under different segment. The problem with Imaging is that Gatan will probably outperform enough to make up for the camera softness. But the camera softness from the funding, both in Japan in the U.S., probably a double-digit negative on their baseline. So that's likely be a drag in each of the second and third quarters, and that would be in the mid-millions.

I'm just wondering if we can think about continuing to see double-digit growth for '13, '14 given what you're saying on the shale gas infrastructure buildout, but also the other LNG piece.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely we will expect double-digit growth. No question about that. I mean we've built a great organization over there. We put as much talent in there as any place in the company, and it's got a very much broader leadership team and capability team. We
componenttext: Absolutely we will expect double-digit growth. No question about that. I mean we've built a great organization over there. We put as much talent in there as any place in the company, and it's got a very much broader leadership team and capability team. We have terrific people throughout their organization, and we made some acquisitions there we acquired Trinity, we acquired United Controls in addition to the investments and the structure we put in. I mean they are absolutely going to do double-digit growth. And we completely refurbished the headquarters operation at Des Moines, which for those people never been there, it's unbelievable it really does look like a technology business now and double-digit growth will be easy for them to obtain.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

componenttext: John, tell us what's in this book there, but does it get big enough and is that growth rate big enough to really give you some confidence that energy systems in total can be double-digit '13 and beyond?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: '13 and beyond, I mean I wouldn't say that we have a view on '13 and beyond yet, most of our commentaries is really about '12. And it's backlog and the growth that we have seen out of energy. And so far in this region has clearly been above the average fo
componenttext: '13 and beyond, I mean I wouldn't say that we have a view on '13 and beyond yet, most of our commentaries is really about '12. And it's backlog and the growth that we have seen out of energy. And so far in this region has clearly been above the average for the segment in total. I mean Brian talked a little bit about the fact that we're up 22% -- in a 20% north in Asia and as well as in Canada, but also in the rest of world category, which includes Australia as well as a few others, that's also a north of 20% for us. And we've seen that at least for Energy Systems & Controls north of 20%. And that's largely driven by the investments that are happening, and I would still off at a relatively small base sort of want to overplay this but it does add to our backlog and add to the LNG position that we have where I think that we are largely seeing that the best control systems provider for any type of LNG plant anywhere around the world. So the fact that they're making strong investments there, the site as well as in others, is going to continue to benefit us, we think.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012

componenttext: Okay and then maybe just a little bit more color on the slower growth in Europe, I think you said up a couple of percent, trying to recall you're kind of profile there. I guess I thought you were overly Europe relative to company average in energy and medical, so I might take the comments on funding to mean that medical was a drag and maybe even negative in Europe one would assume energy still running strong there. But if you just profile Europe exposures for us more broadly and just identify which businesses are really driving that slowdown?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: We actually grew in Europe, we just didn't grow at the same rate as other places. So it's not a matter of not growing, it's just in Europe we grew at 2% and in the quarter every other geography was double-digit growth. So we had 10% growth in the U.S., an
componenttext: We actually grew in Europe, we just didn't grow at the same rate as other places. So it's not a matter of not growing, it's just in Europe we grew at 2% and in the quarter every other geography was double-digit growth. So we had 10% growth in the U.S., and 22% Canada and Asia, 13% and the rest of world and just above 2. so I mean the growth remains fine and Europe represents less than 20% of Roper. So it's in the sort of 15%, 18% category, so it's not a major drag. And energy was up double digits, but medical was very close to that, it was just it was really the change in Europe was purely from the gastropods contract that we had that was unique and was just something that occurred and it was down a sharply, if you hadn't had that adjustment, you would've had close to double-digit growth everywhere. So that was it took some points off of our growth profile.

So thinking about the longer-term comps and what you can do from here, I'm wondering if you look at new products, OEM and channel expansion, work that you do, are those opportunities that remain fundamentally part of the long-term outlook for industrial tech and energy systems to continue to kind of re-create your organic growth profile there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our industrial business is really a non-OEM for the most part.  Our industrial business is our product solutions for direct customers. In the energy arena, we do some OEM activity. But even there, it's not super high but they are engine shutoff valves for
componenttext: Our industrial business is really a non-OEM for the most part.  Our industrial business is our product solutions for direct customers. In the energy arena, we do some OEM activity. But even there, it's not super high but they are engine shutoff valves for instance somebody can argue that's an OEM product going into most everybody's diesel engine. Fortunately we don't look at it that way, we look at this as a solution that customer really requires and engine manufacturer has to buy.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I do think, Chris, that you're right. We definitely benefited from the investments that we have made and continue to make in new product development and channel development for those. I mean you've seen that out of our fluid handling businesses, with
componenttext: And I do think, Chris, that you're right. We definitely benefited from the investments that we have made and continue to make in new product development and channel development for those. I mean you've seen that out of our fluid handling businesses, with expansion of channel activity, particularly in wastewater and agriculture areas, rental market expansion, new product applications and oil and gas for our fluid handling as well as in our energy systems businesses. And we continue to focus on those areas where customers are really going to benefit from the technology that we can provide and the application knowledge that we haven and I don't see that as being something that our businesses will continue to reinvent themselves but I will think as reinventing, it's just a question of expanding their solution set and becoming even more important to the customers to really able to be successful. That's what they've done this year, and I expect them to do that next year just as they've done over the previous decades.

componenttext: Okay. Understood. Are you comfortable that the municipal market is in fact starting to recover? headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't know. We read some comments from others and we wonder. I mean I think that the weather had a healthy one for people. We certainly don't see a robust municipal market for anybody, and we don't see speedy decisions occurring in municipal markets. We
componenttext: I don't know. We read some comments from others and we wonder. I mean I think that the weather had a healthy one for people. We certainly don't see a robust municipal market for anybody, and we don't see speedy decisions occurring in municipal markets. We have a huge installed base so that continues unabated, but there's no question if municipal houses were in a little better shape or you had any new residential construction will have a growth spurt.
