headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Roper Industries Second Quarter 2012 Financial Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead,
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Roper Industries Second Quarter 2012 Financial Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to John Humphrey, Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller and Jason Conley
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller and Jason Conley, Head of Planning and Investor Relations for us.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We have prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
If you could please turn to Slide 2. We begin with our updated Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 3, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everybody. Today, we'll go through the enterprise financial results for the quarter, talk a little bit about specific segment detail and the outlook for each of the segments, give you an overview of the Sunquest acquisition and then es
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everybody. Today, we'll go through the enterprise financial results for the quarter, talk a little bit about specific segment detail and the outlook for each of the segments, give you an overview of the Sunquest acquisition and then establish our third quarter and full year guidance and take your questions. I think we had indicated in our first quarter call that we expected going into the second quarter would be our most difficult challenge for the year. We had really an outstanding quarter compared to what we expected, because we had quite a few headwinds this quarter. Certainly, had the uncertain economy we're able to blow through that. We had very difficult comps going into Q2 because of the Gaz de France revenue last year and outsized performance and shipments last year in our 10 technology business that we knew wouldn't be repeated. And then, of course, we had currency, which became a bigger surprise than we expected, it cost us about $0.01 a share versus our guidance and about $0.02 a share versus the prior year. 
That said, let's look at what we did in Q2.
Next slide. We had record results in the second quarter, pretty well across-the-board, highest level of orders in our history, highest level of sales in our history in the second quarter. This backlog that we entered the second quarter with record net earnings and record EBITDA performance for the quarter. Our orders were up 8%, and revenue was up 4% despite those headwinds and the effect of currency. Our book-to-bill ratio was actually quite high at 1.05. Our gross margins reached 54.9% in the quarter, and our operating margin was really quite spectacular, it came up 130 basis points to 24.7%. If you look at the incremental OP and the incremental sales, our operating leverage in the quarter was 59% and there's no smoke and mirrors in that, it's just 59%. Our EBITDA was up 214 -- was $214 million and our EBITDA margin reached 29.5%. Operating cash flow in the quarter was $119 million, slightly lower than we would expect in the second quarter but we had a higher cash tax rate, and that won't happen again in the rest of the year. Our first half operating cash flow was $261 million and will project what we believe will be for the full year later this morning.
Our diluted earnings per share were $1.15 versus $1.03 last year. That $1.15 would've been $0.01 higher if based on our guidance if it weren't for the currency scenario. And the $1.03 is the number that we used with the remeasurement gained last year, you might remember it was about $0.05 a share so GAAP it would have been $1.08 but was really adjusted at $1.03. Net earnings were up 13%. We're very happy with the performance, because we had about $30 million headwind between our Scientific camera business and Gaz de France and some European activity coming into the quarter and we were able to really blow through that. Very solid revenue throughout the world with the exception of Europe,, which was down about 18%. Record performance really in an uncertain economic environment.
Next slide. In the Q2 income statement, you'll see orders were $763 million, up 7% organically. Revenue, book-to-bill came in at 1.05. Gross profit was up 100 basis points to 54.9% from 53.9 a year ago. And our operating income was an amazing 24.7%, up 130 basis points from a year ago. Our interest expense about flat. Tax rate was consistent with the guidance we established for the quarter, came in at 29.6%. And net earnings were $115million versus $102 million last year, up 13%.
Next slide. If you look at our EBITDA performance, our trailing 12 months EBITDA has now reached $845 million. It's up from last year. Trailing number this time of $739 million and 2 years ago $540 million. So EBITDA is up 57% over the last 2 years. And our EBITDA margins continue to soar, we were 25.2% in 2010 and 29.3% on the trailing 12 months calculation now and of course, this quarter at 29.5%.
Next. If we look here at the cash flow performance, you'll see Q2 cash flow at $119 million of operating cash flow and $109 million of free cash flow. Very good performance again but working capital. Our inventory actually improved by 30 bps from 7.5% to 7.2% of revenue. And our accounts receivable improved by 50 bps from 15.6% to 15.1%. And when you adjust that for payables and accruals, we were still below 7%. 
In the first half cash flow, it normally our first half cash flow is about 40% of the full year. This year, it will second half of the year is stronger because of the acquisition of Sunquest and how cash accretive it really is. So you can see that our full year operating cash flow, we've now raised our guidance to be about $700 million for the full year. That will put our operating cash flow at a very high percentage of revenue. It could reach 23% of revenue, in fact. It's really driven by expanded margins. It's driven by the Sunquest acquisition that we expect to close in the last 4 months of the year and some cash tax benefits that we are acquiring in the Sunquest transaction. It does exclude the deal cost and refinancing charges associated with the new credit facility we put in place effective this past Friday.
And you can see here that free cash or operating cash goes up to $700 million, our estimate this year up from $602 million last year and $500 million a year before. So that would be a 40% increase in cash flow over the last 2 years.
Next slide. On Friday, we closed the new credit facility, a $1.5 billion revolver. So if you look at our normal credit stats here, a year ago on 6/30/11, you can see that we had $196 million in cash and $595 million in an undrawn revolver, which gave us acquisition powder investment powder of about $791 million. When we closed out the quarter on June 30, our cash had increased to $519 million in our undrawn revolver was at its capacity at $750 million, giving us $1.269 billion. As of Friday, with the new $1.5 billion revolver and a cash from the end of the quarter, we now have capacity in excess of $2 billion. Our gross debt on the other hand is only  $1.69 billion. Our gross debt to capitalization is at 23.8, but if you look at the net debt-to-EBITDA, you'll see it's actually cut in half from a year ago, it was 1.4. And at the end of the quarter, it was 0.7. Even with the financing of the Sunquest acquisition at $1.4 billion, we'll have ample capacity to pursue other opportunities in the near-term and the pipeline remains very, very exciting.
If we look the next slide here, the Sunquest details -- the segment details, we'll start with the RF Technology slide. Next. So on RF Technology, really, very, very outstanding orders in the quarter. They were up 18%. So those orders and the execution really in the telegraph business kind of got us up to the high-end of our range despite the European pressures and helped us deliver. You can see the OP margin was amazing at 27%, up 290 basis points. And if you want to look at leverage, revenue was down 2% and operating profit was up 10%. So what would speak strongly to the execution that's occurring in those businesses. The softer businesses continue to help us on the margin expansion as they grow. We've got a very significant win again in Houston. We are going to upgrade the entire Lane Hardware in the Houston area with our united toll systems technology, which is really an advancement over what was in place in the past. We think that contract ought to produce about $65 million in revenue between maintenance and the change out. 
Our CBORD cash flow system business continue to grow, it had a record quarter in the second quarter for any time. And that involved both university and good management wins in both higher education and healthcare. And we had of course it's difficult headwind for our Technolog business, Gaz dez France, which had that sort of onetime large install last year, and that held us back by about $500 million in the quarter.
In the second half, we will have a continued difficult comp with the Gaz dez France, because it went throughout the year last year. But our increased toll project and maintenance activity that will be led by this Texas wins will easily offset any challenges we have and the rest of those types of activities in the segment. And then the software business, was had Software-as-a-Service activity is continuing to increase and both iTrade and Freight Matching continue to roll along with the sort of nominal organic growth but outstanding cash growth.
Next slide. If we look at the Industrial Technology segment, gee it's again spectacular performance. Revenue was up 11%. The operating profit margins reached 30.4%. That's an all-time record for the segment. The highest previous we ever had was at 29.2% in the fourth quarter last year. This 30.4% to just add some perspective around how amazing it is, the S&P 500 industrials gross margins had it grew by 30.8%. Roper's operating profit for industrial is 30.4%. So we've got an all-time record here in OP margin. Again, leverage off the growth, terrific execution everywhere. Fluid handling continues to grow in both agriculture, food and the shale activity. Our General Industrial markets have performed well. We're not seeing any early indicators of any softness in any of those businesses. The material test business, which is primarily European business, actually had a record second quarter, very strong North America and Asia sales offset any weakness that we had in Europe. And then Neptune business continued to grow, driven by the Toronto project and some higher shipments in the U.S. In the second half of the year, we would expect that the shale activity growth would moderate, not stall, but certainly moderate with gas activity on shale being down but the oil activity on shale being up. To the industrial end markets, again, no signs of any falloff. The outstanding margins we expected continue throughout the second half of the year. And just personal note to our people and investor, we just couldn't be more proud of these teams as we watch them execute in a very tough market.
Next slide. If we look at our Energy Systems & Controls business, here, you can see revenue was up 6%, OP up 7%. Margin at 26% was up 200 basis points from the first quarter margin and energy. Organic growth in the quarter was 5%. Compressor Controls continues to do very well on LNG projects and the field service activity that we do drove double-digit growth for them. The bolt-on acquisitions that we did in the last year, very small United Controls Trinity and Cambridge, all have noncash amortization charges in them. They're actually putting a little bit of a drag on the OP margins even though at 26% it's hard to see a drag, but they actually would've been about 120 basis points higher in OP without all that amortization drag and the on those 3 businesses. That said, they're performing well. They're all on plan from an integration viewpoint. They will add to growth in the second half of the year. 
Our European markets weakened. In fact, in energy, they were down about 18%, but our U.S. was up by about 18%. So the U.S. business being larger, that was a benefit. And the Rest of the World was quite strong in the Middle East and Asia, Australia. Brazil not quite as strong. Cost actions are underway for the second half on a very selective basis where people are executing some contingency plans in those things that relate to any softness that they see. We think Europe continue to be soft but we'll have continued growth in both North America and Middle East and Asia to offset that. But the exception of our petrochem business, which is down about 20%, and that's a worldwide shortfall, we're not seeing any strength anywhere in that business. Very solid backlog though. Compressor controls gives us confidence that growth in the second half. And then we would expect a normal, very strong Q4 seasonal activity in energy would be repeated this year.
Next slide. So here we look at Medical & Scientific Imaging. This is one of those things where looks like nothing happened, but there is great variability throughout the different businesses here. And while revenue was flat and operating margin was up 20 bps, what really was going on is Europe and the North American academic research funding softness impacted our camera portion of the Photonics businesses. Cameras are not a big part of Roper, but they do come in around $125 million to $140 million with the total revenue, and they were down as much as 20% in some cases. And we don't see any real turnaround as it relates to these research markets for the camera technology business. And while they perform relative well, they certainly are drag on short-term growth. 
Our medical businesses continue to grow organically. The channel expansion that we've been able to provide them in Asia is offsetting any weakness that they have in Europe. And the Northern Digital business performed very well, expanding its offerings to OEM customers. And also we were able to do a bolt-on acquisition in the quarter called Ascension Technology Corporation, which is in the state of Vermont. And Ascension does 3D tracking for minimally invasive surgery, which you probably all know is a rapidly growing aspect in surgical applications. We paid about $18 million for Ascension. We expect it ought to deliver 3 plus million dollars in EBITDA over the next 12 months. In the second half, we expect to have continued weakness in this academic research area, which will affect our Photonics businesses. Fortunately, the medical expansion is going to continue. Markets remain pretty favorable. Ascension will give us a live bit of for Digital. The Japan business has a substantial backlog, which we expect to be able to do ship during the second half of the year, which will add to our growth. And then we have this transformational Sunquest acquisition, which will add substantial amount of revenue and EBITDA to our medical platform. We would expect it to add somewhere in the neighborhood of $75 million of revenue in last 4 months of the year. It's going to add well over 35% to the Medical and Scientific segment for the next year in revenue. It's going to add quite a substantial amount to Roper's overall revenue base for 2013.
Next slide. So as we look at the Sunquest acquisition, I'll talk a bit about the transaction, and John will talk a little more in-depth about this specific business. 
Next slide. So if we look at the Sunquest acquisition, you can see that it meets all of our acquisition criteria. It's really an amazing fit where we're able to take our software platforms inside RF and the medical platforms inside Medical & Scientific Imaging and hook them up in a very creative way with the Sunquest business, which is truly a software business but it's also a Medical business. If you look at our criteria, we talk about all the time asset like low CapEx. Absolutely it's almost no CapEx, and that exceptionally light asset business. 
Focusing on the market structures and driving forces at work, we've done probably more marketplace diligence on this business, because we've  actually looked at it in 2010 and have maintained in the business forever and really felt that based on the work that we have done and the things that we thought they could and should be looking at and then seeing how they've done, our diligence revealed a lot of strategic competitive advantages that Sunquest enjoys. And they have a lot of whitespace opportunities for growth that are beyond our core traditional business. They've done a great job in transforming their business. It was acquired by in 2007 and certainly was a high-margin business. But, could be better. And to the Sunquest leadership teams efforts, they've done an incredible job in making that a transformational business that we are acquiring now compared to what it was in 2007.
The incentives is always a link to the commitments that the leadership teams made and those are in place. It has the technology advantages that are clear and easily measured against competition, and it has very deep application expertise. It really is a niche business and the lab market. Management continuity is always valued and every on that team has the groups that in place. The communication for the Sunquest employees is taking place this morning in Tucson. We've asked them as always to preserve what's made by very good company and core values that stimulate progress. In this area the progress is going to come in the form of even more investment and the sales and marketing arena and some faster execution in the development area. This is a business that when we talk about growing, once you buy, Mike, this business has higher margins than we do. It has twice the EBITDA margins that Roper enjoys. And when you look at those kind of margins and you recognize the incredible strength of the company, it has 2/3 of its revenue comes on a recurring basis. 98% of its customers sign up annually for the software programs that it has. It has negative working capital and very low CapEx. And we expect in 2013 it will generate $140 million or more EBITDA for us. Fourth quarter run rate, which we just completed their fiscal company May 31 and just had their audit and signed are prior to our  closing actually supports our expectations for '13 -- 2013 nicely. It's really a business, when John talkies about it, you want to think about what do they do and where are they located and why do they win because it is a phenomenal management team and outstanding group of employees that have really done things in this space that no one can really replicate.
So with that, we'll turn to the next slide and John Humphrey.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Brian. So just talk a little bit more about kind of what Sunquest is and what it's able to provide for its customers. Further, the global market leader for providing the underlying software information solution for laboratories and hospitals
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Brian. So just talk a little bit more about kind of what Sunquest is and what it's able to provide for its customers. Further, the global market leader for providing the underlying software information solution for laboratories and hospitals and large academic medical centers, with a headquarter in Tucson, Arizona, locations both in the U.K. and the development center in Bangalore. They have a global footprint that allows them to serve that customer base. With their customer base are those folks who for whom the effectiveness and efficiency of the lab is of critical importance. The lab ends up with in many cases hundreds of thousands of tests being done each month to support the diagnostic decisions that are made on the hospital. And they rely upon the Sunquest information and the quality and safety associated with that to help drive those decisions. The comprehensive solutions is about improving the productivity with workflow automation tools. You see on the right-hand side both the Sunquest laboratories 7.0 and the cool cat solution, both of those are about workflow automation to make sure that the right test is done on the right patient at the right time, leading to the right diagnosis. So those things also reach beyond just the lab and also go out to the collection manager, one of the modules that Sunquest has. So that nurse has a point of collection tool that integrates back with the lab so you have full connectivity between both of those parts of the hospital.
The very large customer base, very high retention rates, over 98% retention each year, continue to utilize and depend upon the software set of solutions. And is really supported by a 30-year history. These are very long-term relationships, relationships that are supported by the decade of application expertise Sunquest has developed about what the hospital lab needs and their unique set of needs that Sunquest is going to be able to meet. And as Brian talked about, it's a proven team, it's a great culture, everything that we varied diligence process continues to support the fact that their culture of excellence and execution is really phenomenal. And I think they're going to be a great addition to the team. And I thin the company is very well-positioned to capture the growth opportunities that they've identified over the coming years.
So with that, I'll turn it back to Brian to talk a little bit about guidance and the summary for the quarter.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So after we get that guidance, we move to the guidance slide. We've raised our full year guidance to $4.84 to $5. That reflects about a $0.04 reduction due to currency. We had started out at $4.75 to $4.91, you might remember $0.04 comes off the bot
componenttext:
Okay. So after we get that guidance, we move to the guidance slide. We've raised our full year guidance to $4.84 to $5. That reflects about a $0.04 reduction due to currency. We had started out at $4.75 to $4.91, you might remember $0.04 comes off the bottom your 4 71 and $0.05 off the top for 4.86 running back $0.12 and $0.14 on GAAP accretion for Sunquest, excluding any deal cost. And then in addition, of course, we've got other things that we are absorbing and other things that are good. So $4.84 to $5 on full year guidance. The quarter comes in at $1.19 to $1.25 in the third quarter. Most importantly, we now expect our full year operating cash flow to be approximately $700 million. 
And just a couple of footnotes, you'll notice their the acquisition of Sunquest we expect to close at the end of August. We will have the HSR filing and since there's no competitive issues, it should move along quickly. We have some deferred revenue that's unusual. Sunquest some other businesses when you acquire them, there's some GAAP issues around that. And so we'll have to kind of reveal that to you each quarter as we report out. And this does exclude whatever cost we will have that will be registered in the third quarter. That will be related to the acquisition and removal of the remaining amortization and the old revolver.
Next slide. So looking at the summary of the second quarter, we go back to the top point being that it's again an all-time record for the second quarter in our history, highest level of orders, revenue, backlog, net earnings and EBITDA. Organic quarter growth at 7% was really a pleasant benefit for the quarter. The operating margins at 24.70, EBITDA at 29 5 and gross margins at 54 9 really terrific. Leverage is kind of breathtaking at 59%. We used to talk about 30% to 35% leverage, and the target leverage is going to be about 40% for a long time.
Doing a new revolver a big help, $1.5 billion. The old revolver was put in place in July of 2008 and would have had to be replaced in July of 2013. So this removes any refinancing risk around that for next year. It gives us twice as much capacity to write checks against as we had previously. And $1.5 billion is pretty sizable revolver for Roper. That was completed last Friday, a timely completion, we might add, relative to the deal closing on Saturday. Sunquest, just an exceptional financial profile. Higher gross margins than we have at twice the EBITDA margins. Terrific fit. You couldn't find a business that sort of marry what we're doing in software and what we're doing in medical that would benefit both so much Sunquest. It's got great development people. Our software people spent last week in Bangalore, visiting and talking with people. We've done tremendous diligence around their robustness of the software platforms in place for Sunquest and how they can be used. All of these then creates an opportunity for us to be positioned again in 2012 for an all-time record year. $700 million in operating cash flow. And perhaps most importantly, the transformation process that we're doing here continues as we get more and more technology. If you think about where we are, and how we continue this, we have more technology content, we have higher margins, higher cash returns, more recurring revenue and just a much different company than what you would look at in 2002. And the next 5 years, we added Neptune and TransCore. And then if you look at 2007 and you look at the forward 5 years here 2012, you CBORD and Horizon and iTrade and Technolog. And now Sunquest. So technology content gets better margins get better cash return gets better and the available forward acquisition powder for growth will be better than it ever has been in the past. And with that, I think we're ready for questions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Matt Summerville, KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Matt Summerville, KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to clarify something, Brian, on Sunquest. That 12 to 14, is that a GAAP number that will have under GAAP rules the deferred revenue adjustments? I just want to make sure I have that right.
componenttext: I just wanted to clarify something, Brian, on Sunquest. That 12 to 14, is that a GAAP number that will have under GAAP rules the deferred revenue adjustments? I just want to make sure I have that right.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: That is -- Matt, this is John. That is a non-GAAP number. So it has as you are probably aware, like an awful lot of software companies, Sunquest has deferred revenue for the annual maintenance, they get paid in advance for that. And the accounting rules u
componenttext: That is -- Matt, this is John. That is a non-GAAP number. So it has as you are probably aware, like an awful lot of software companies, Sunquest has deferred revenue for the annual maintenance, they get paid in advance for that. And the accounting rules upon acquisition will require us to take a write-down of that, so to basically move that deferred revenue to a fair value. And then over the next 12 months, as those renewals happen, that deferred revenue will get back up. So the $0.12 to $0.14 is a non-GAAP number. And as we're able to estimate exactly what that deferred revenue fair value adjustment is, then we'll be able to provide have for you. We'll be able to do that until after we close the business. But we'll be providing that insight each quarter to be able to reconcile between the GAAP numbers and then the non-GAAP numbers that we think provides better visibility to understanding the operations of the company.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think really, Doug, the quarter from organic -- we would have given ourselves a shot at having 7% organic orders in the quarter. That was a pleasant surprise. But got really strong activity that we knew would eventually come in the year in the quarter.
componenttext: I think really, Doug, the quarter from organic -- we would have given ourselves a shot at having 7% organic orders in the quarter. That was a pleasant surprise. But got really strong activity that we knew would eventually come in the year in the quarter. So that helped. I think we entered the quarter with more concern and turned out to be justified. So those like any early indicators of things that would make us nervous that would be in energy or industrial, we really haven't seen that. There's just a little bit of activity, mostly in petrochem and oil and gas that we're going to modest internal retrenchment on. But on balance, it's pretty good. We never really talk about a quarter in which we're in. But I would say things remain pretty decent. We're going to expect organic growth actually kind of picked up in the second quarter, and we would expect it to continue to be mid-single digits, really, for the rest of the year. So it's really kind of better than we expect because there's more European headwinds than we would have originally forecast.

componenttext: It was down 18% for us in total. About half of that is just due to currency though. So maybe 8% or 9% on an organic basis. Something to remember on that, Matt, is that does include the headwinds Gaz de France. So that's got $5 million. Even when you take that out, we saw a decline in Europe that was definitely mid-single-digit.

componenttext: Well, I think we don't want to tip off other people to things that we think are available to us. But it would be safe to say that we think that they can continue to grow share at the expense of other people. We think people have been paying a lot of attention to electronic health records and companies that are in the EHR space. Here again, we do about a niche, which is think is unrelated in that activity. And this niche has done an opportunity very hard return for people investing it is in the hospital space and then the clinics space and then private care space. If you basically lab work is critical to every aspects of people diagnosing folks, and that happens at a variety d of different places. We think we have the preeminent technology to do that and we think we can make people more productive and more efficient and what they do when they do it. It has been hard, I think on the last couple of years to get the intention of hospitals that have had these mandates to do a variety of thing around health records. Now we get the chance to make an investment i n things like this business that will give them a natural return. So we think it's got pretty exciting growth. And these guys, they've brought in a new sales executive, a woman that we have great confidence in that we think is going to drive better focus on organic growth. It's been a very high cash contributor. And it's same old situation, private equity has done in this case a really amazing job than it has been what they acquired in 2007, but it can grow more. And it does have opportunities for share gains and expansion around the world. This business, it doesn't do much in certain portions of the world, and we do a lot in other portions of the world than they do. It's also got an incredible development team in Bangalore, and that's very, very bullish for us.

componenttext: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing what lesson you learned from iTrade and how that plays into both the negotiation for Sunquest but also integration, managing a software company and so forth?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: We have a big advantage today versus when we first acquired iTrade in that we have recently hired a chief architect for our technology businesses. He's working in our software arena. We also have a software executive, full-time, that's looking over our ve
componenttext: We have a big advantage today versus when we first acquired iTrade in that we have recently hired a chief architect for our technology businesses. He's working in our software arena. We also have a software executive, full-time, that's looking over our very softer companies. And we have a medical executive, which looking at the medical scenario. So between the 2 new executives, 1 that's a domain expert in medical, 1 that's a domain expert in software and the architectural person, the quality of diligence that we are able to do on our own was a dramatic improvement. We had a much deeper understanding about source code and the ways in which development programs need to be done and measured. And we've got a deeper understanding about cost structures around development activity, and all those things are good. I think we've also come to recognize that a slightly lower organic growth rates in the software businesses really are the problem, because the recurring revenue that they have inside them and the quality of the cash that they generate, I mean, to look at a company I think most people would look at us and say that this is best-of-breed. EBITDA margins and yet here we are acquiring one that has twice the margins that we enjoy. So they are fundamentally different and our Executive leadership capability around them isn't better than ever.

componenttext: Just to clarify on the deferred revenues. You said that it refers to the maintenance side. Is that 2 years? That's pretty typical that you see in 2 years of maintenance and any of the licensing fees included in that deferred revenues or just maintenance?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the short answer is nothing on the license fees. And the maintenance contracts and the deferred revenue are 2 slightly different things. So the maintenance agreements range anywhere from 1 year, 3 year 5 year, some even 7-year agreements, because, of c
componenttext: So the short answer is nothing on the license fees. And the maintenance contracts and the deferred revenue are 2 slightly different things. So the maintenance agreements range anywhere from 1 year, 3 year 5 year, some even 7-year agreements, because, of course, the customer would like to make sure that they have kind of the long-term commitment with Sunquest or Sunquest might like having a long-term contract. So but they don't pay for all 7 years or all 5 years upfront. So it's a 1-year payment, and that's what goes into the deferred revenue. So we would expect to see that deferred revenue build back up after the fair value adjustment after 12 months to be back to normal steady state.

So the lead time for getting agencies to understand, see and test and kick tires around that is by the long. headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't really know, Jeff. It's possible. I would sure wouldn't rule against it. I know what we're willing to do. to we never know what people are willing to do. So there's usually a bit bid/ask spread all the time when we are doing work. This transaction
componenttext: I don't really know, Jeff. It's possible. I would sure wouldn't rule against it. I know what we're willing to do. to we never know what people are willing to do. So there's usually a bit bid/ask spread all the time when we are doing work. This transactional of Sunquest demonstrates kind of how we act. So we started talking to these people in 2010. And I'll tell you, sometimes it will get people ideas or whatever. We wonder about what they're going to do, I think these people have done just a spectacular job of taking advantage of some momentum that we thought would be available to them. And they've done that. So we have some transactions that are similar to those that we've been talking to people off and on about for several years. I think that depending on who owns the asset and what people thing is going to happen between now and the end of the year around the tax structure, going into next year, you have higher levels of seller activity if they believe nothing is going to change and they don't have a capital gains that they are worried about, they may hold on. If on the other hand, they are candidate think that getting a higher percentage of something is better than a lower percentage of something else, we may close the valuation gap, I don't know. So I think it's possible that we would do another transaction, probably not quite as large as $1.4 billion, however.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

componenttext: That brings up another topic. What are you thinking about on the divestiture side, you are not naming names, of course, but clearly, the portfolio is changing, there's maybe some pieces of it that is not as core as they used to be. It's an interesting juncture right. I mean your returns are so high anything diluted but at the time when you got maybe such accretive acquisition activity going on, perhaps there's an opportunity to mold the portfolio a little bit differently. Are you thinking that way at all? Is there any prospect for something leaving the portfolio the next 6, 12 months?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, our core businesses deliver a tremendous amount of cash. They've gotten dramatically better. Their cash returns are more than 50% better than they were like 5 years ago. They give us tremendous EPS performance, because they don't have the non-GAAP o
componenttext: Well, our core businesses deliver a tremendous amount of cash. They've gotten dramatically better. Their cash returns are more than 50% better than they were like 5 years ago. They give us tremendous EPS performance, because they don't have the non-GAAP or amortization charges that lay against them. There is certainly an increasing inflection point where you look at this and say what about this situation. We're in a marvelous place where since we maintain the autonomy of each one of these businesses, we can always decouple business and not have any problem doing that. It's not like some other strategic that's got everything so embedded that one factory is making 5 items and one information system can't go with the business. So all our businesses are total isolated and independent and anyone could be spun off to another party. I think people largely have some ideas about which things might become available. It's kind of like the trade deadline, right, for Tuesday. So who's willing to pay what, but we're not an active seller, but we have some assets that are probably more valuable to others than they are to us.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

componenttext: Well, I mean seems the EBITDA excludes the affect of amortization, I don't think that really impacts that. So on the EPS side, it definitely does include debt, of course, always with doesn't include the impact of the deferred revenue fair value accounting treatment.

componenttext: First, I wanted to ask you about Industrial Technology business and the pump business, specifically. Another company recently recorded a substantial decline in orders, it's Gardner Denver, in the petroleum in the industrial pump business. In that particular business of theirs, orders were down 36% in the quarter. And then another division, they had a pressure pumping order decline of 17%. And you haven't seen anything like that according to what you said. Do you compete with them? Or are you taking market share? Or just what is going on here, because the 2 results are dramatically different?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the markets were focused on totally different for the most part with Gardner Denver. I mean we do have dewatering pumps makes, and those have certainly been used in the shale activity. Those have had strong growth. That growth is moderating,
componenttext: Yes, I think the markets were focused on totally different for the most part with Gardner Denver. I mean we do have dewatering pumps makes, and those have certainly been used in the shale activity. Those have had strong growth. That growth is moderating, but it's not totally negative at all. That's pretty small part of the overall enterprise, and our Roper Pump business continues to grow quite substantially. So, I think, gosh, I'm not really at all close to Gardner Denver, but I think they're building a lot of stuff that maybe is going into rental and platforms and that stuff. We have some rental business with Cornell, but it's not the core component of what we do. So we are still making pumps for waste water activity, agricultural irrigation and those kind of things.

componenttext: Sure, Alex, and you're correct, it's not the same one. The business for the Harris County is the one that we talked about. And so it doesn't have the same immediate booking that the more definite execution for the Harris County does. So we expect the Texas contract, the  contract to add maybe $30 million over the next 3 years, but at a timing that may be a little bit lumpy as they decide on when to update and when to upgrade their specific lanes.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Jason Conle
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Jason Conley, Head of Finance and Investor Relations for us.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We've prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
If you turn to Slide 2. We begin with our updated Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 3, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. And after his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everybody. Today, we'll go through the enterprise financial results for the quarter, talk a little bit about specific segment detail and the outlook for each of the segments, give you an overview of the Sunquest acquisition and then es
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everybody. Today, we'll go through the enterprise financial results for the quarter, talk a little bit about specific segment detail and the outlook for each of the segments, give you an overview of the Sunquest acquisition and then establish our third quarter and full year guidance and take your questions. 
I think we had indicated in our first quarter call that we expected going into the second quarter would be our most difficult challenge for the year. We had really an outstanding quarter compared to what we expected because we had quite a few headwinds this quarter. Certainly, we had the uncertain economy and we're able to blow through that. 
We had very difficult comps going into Q2 because of the Gaz de France revenue last year and the outsized performance and toll tag shipments last year in our Gatan technology business that we knew wouldn't be repeated. And then of course, we had currency, which became a bigger surprise than we expected. It costs us about $0.01 a share versus our guidance and about $0.02 a share versus the prior year. That said, let's look at what we did in Q2.
Next slide. We had record results in the second quarter, pretty well across-the-board, highest level of orders in our history, highest level of sales in our history in the second quarter, biggest backlog that we've entered the second quarter with record net earnings and record EBITDA performance for the quarter. 
Our orders were up 8%, and revenue was up 4%, despite those headwinds and the effect of currency. Our book-to-bill ratio was actually quite high at 1.05. Our gross margins reached 54.9% in the quarter, and our operating margin was really quite spectacular. It came up 130 basis points to 24.7%. 
If you look at the incremental OP and the incremental sales, our operating leverage in the quarter was 59%, and there are no smoke and mirrors in that. It's just 59%. Our EBITDA was up 214 -- or sorry, was $214 million, and our EBITDA margin reached 29.5%. 
Operating cash flow in the quarter was $119 million, slightly lower than we would expect in the second quarter, but we had a higher cash tax rate, and that won't happen again in the rest of the year. Our first half operating cash flow was $261 million and will project what we believe will be for the full year later this morning.
Our diluted earnings per share were $1.15 versus $1.03 last year. That $1.15 would've been $0.01 higher if -- based on our guidance, if it weren't for the currency scenario. And the $1.03 is the number that we used with the remeasurement gained last year. You might remember, it was about $0.05 a share. So on GAAP, it would have been $1.08 but was really adjusted at $1.03. 
Net earnings were up 13%. We're very happy with the performance, because we had about $30 million headwind between our scientific camera business and Gaz de France and some European activity coming into the quarter, and we were able to really blow through that. Very solid revenue throughout the world with the exception of Europe, which was down about 18%, record performance, really, in an uncertain economic environment.
Next slide. In the Q2 income statement, you'll see orders were $763 million, up 7% organically. Revenue book-to-bill came in at 1.05. Gross profit was up 100 basis points to 54.9% from 53.9 a year ago, and our operating income was an amazing 24.7%, up 130 basis points for a year ago. Our interest expense is about flat. Tax rate was consistent with the guidance we established for the quarter, came in at 29.6%, and net earnings were $115million versus $102 million last year, up 13%.
Next slide. If we look at our EBITDA performance, our trailing 12 months EBITDA has now reached $845 million. It's up from last year's trailing number this time of $739 million and 2 years ago, $540 million. So EBITDA is up 57% over the last 2 years, and our EBITDA margins continue to soar. We were 25.2% in 2010 and 29.3% on the trailing 12 months calculation now, and of course, this quarter at 29.5%.
Next. If we look here at the cash flow performance, you'll see Q2 cash flow at $119 million of operating cash flow and $109 million of free cash flow. Very good performance again to working capital. Our inventory actually improved by 30 bps from 7.5% to 7.2% of revenue, and our accounts receivable improved by 50 bps from 15.6% to 15.1%. And when you adjust that for payables and accruals, we were still below 7%. 
In the first half cash flow, it normally, our first half cash flow, is about 40% of the full year. This year, it'll -- the second half will be even a little stronger because of the acquisition of Sunquest and how cash accretive it really is. So you can see that our full year operating cash flow, we've now raised our guidance to be about $700 million for the full year. That'll put our operating cash flow at a -- at very high percentage of revenue. It could reach 23% of revenue, in fact. 
It's really driven by expanded margins. It's driven by the Sunquest acquisition that we expect to close in the last 4 months of the year and some cash tax benefits that we're acquiring in the Sunquest transaction. It does exclude the deal cost and refinancing charges associated with the new credit facility we put in place effective this past Friday.
And you can see here that free cash flow or operating cash flow goes up to $700 million. Our estimate this year up from $602 million last year and $500 million a year before. So that would be a 40% increase in cash flow over the last 2 years.
Next slide. On Friday, we closed the new credit facility, a $1.5 billion revolver. So if you look at our normal credit stats here, a year ago on 6/30/11, you can see that we had $196 million in cash and $595 million in an undrawn revolver, which gave us acquisition powder investment powder of about $791 million. When we closed out the quarter at June 30, our cash had increased to $519 million, and our undrawn revolver was at its capacity of $750 million, giving us $1.269 billion. As of Friday, with the new $1.5 billion revolver and the cash from the end of the quarter, we now have capacity in excess of $2 billion. 
Our gross debt, on the other hand, is only $1.069 billion. Our gross debt to capitalization is at 23.8%, but if you look at the net debt to EBITDA, you'll see it's actually been cutting in half from a year ago. It was 1.4. And at the end of the quarter, it was 0.7. Even with the financing of the Sunquest acquisition at $1.4 billion, we will have ample capacity to pursue other opportunities in the near term, and the pipeline remains very, very exciting.
If we look next slide here at the Sunquest details -- or sorry, the segment details, we'll start with the RF Technology slide. Next. 
So on RF Technology, really, a very, very outstanding orders in the quarter. They were up 18%. So those orders and the execution, really, in the toll and traffic business kind of got us up to the high end of our range, despite the European pressures, and helped us deliver. 
You can see the OP margin was amazing at 27%, up 290 basis points. And if you want to look at leverage, revenue was down 2% and operating profit was up 10%. So that would speak strongly to the execution that's occurring in those businesses. 
The software businesses continue to help us on the margin expansion as they grow. We've got a very significant win again in Houston. We're going to upgrade the entire lane hardware in the Houston area with our United Toll Systems technology, which is really an advancement over what was in place in the past. We think that contract ought to produce about $65 million in revenue between maintenance and the change-out. 
Our CBORD cashless system business continue to grow. It had a record quarter in the second quarter for it, for anytime, and that involve both university and food management wins in both higher education and healthcare. 
And we had -- of course, it's difficult headwind for our Technolog business, Gaz de France, which had that sort of onetime large install last year, and that held us back by about $5 million in the quarter. In the second half, we'll have the continued difficult comp with the Gaz de France, because it went throughout the year last year. But our increased toll project and maintenance activity that will be led by this -- these Texas wins will easily offset any challenges we have and the rest of those types of activities in the segment. 
And in the software businesses and the Software-as-a-Service activity, it's continuing to increase. And both iTrade and Freight Matching continue to roll along with the sort of nominal organic growth but outstanding cash growth.
Next slide. If we look at the Industrial Technology segment, gee, it's just, again, spectacular performance. Revenue was up 11%. The operating profit margins reached 30.4%. That's an all-time record for the segment. The highest previous we ever had was at 29.2% in the fourth quarter last year. 
This 30.4%, to just add some perspective around how amazing it is, the S&P 500 Industrials gross margins, as a group, were 30.8%. Roper's operating profit for Industrial is 30.4%. So we've got an all-time record here in OP margin, again, leveraged off the growth, terrific execution everywhere. 
Fluid handling continues to grow in both agriculture, food and the shale activity. Our general industrial markets have performed well. We're not seeing any early indicators of any softness in any of those businesses. 
The Material Test business, which is primarily a European business, actually had a record second quarter, very strong North America and Asia sales offset any weakness that we had in Europe. And the Neptune business continued to grow, driven by the Toronto project and some higher shipments in the U.S. 
In the second half of the year, we would expect that the shale activity growth would moderate, not stall, but certainly moderate, with gas activity on shale being down but the oil activity on shale being up. The industrial end markets, again, no signs of any falloff. The outstanding margins we expected continue throughout the second half of the year. And just a personal note to all our people and investor, we just couldn't be more proud of these teams as we watch them execute in a very tough market.
Next slide. If we look at our Energy Systems & Controls business, here, you can see revenue was up 6%; OP, up 7%. Margin at 26% was up 200 basis points from the first quarter margin in Energy. Organic growth in the quarter was 5%. Compressor Controls continues to do very well on LNG projects, and the field service activity that we do drove double-digit growth for them. 
The bolt-on acquisitions that we did in the last were very small, United Controls Group, Trinity and Cambridge, all have noncash amortization charges in them. They're actually putting a little bit of a drag on the OP margins, even though at 26%, it's hard to see a drag. But they actually would have been about 120 basis points higher in OP without all that amortization drag and integration on those 3 businesses. That said, they're performing well. They're all on plan from an integration viewpoint. They will add to growth in the second half of the year. 
Our European markets weakened. In fact, in Energy, they were down about 18%, but our U.S. was up by about 18%. So the U.S. business being larger, that was a benefit. And the rest of the world was quite strong in the Middle East and Asia, Australia. Brazil not quite as strong. 
Targeted cost actions are underway for the second half on a very selective basis, where people are executing some contingency plans in those things that relate to any softness that they see. We think Europe continue to be soft, but we'll have continued growth in both North America and Middle East and Asia to offset that. 
With the exception of our petrochem business, which is down about 20%, and that's a worldwide shortfall, we're not seeing any strength anywhere in that business. Very solid backlog, though, at Compressor Controls. It gives us confidence about growth in the second half. And then we would expect the normal, very strong Q4 seasonal activity in Energy would be repeated this year.
Next slide. So here we look at Medical & Scientific Imaging. This is one of those things where looks like nothing happened, but there is great variability throughout the different businesses here. And while revenue was flat and operating margin was up 20 bps, what really was going on is the Europe and the North American academic research funding softness impacted our camera portion of the photonics businesses. 
Cameras are not a big part of Roper, but they do come in around $125 million to $140 million with their total revenue. And they were down as much as 20% in some cases. And we don't see any real turnaround as it relates to these research markets for the camera technology businesses. And while they perform relative well, they certainly are drag on short-term growth. 
Our Medical businesses continue to grow organically. The channel expansion we've been able to provide them in Asia is offsetting any weakness that they have in Europe. And the Northern Digital business performed very well, expanding its offerings to OEM customers. And also, we were able to do a bolt-on acquisition in the quarter called Ascension Technology Corp., which is in the state of Vermont. And Ascension does 3D tracking for minimally invasive surgery, which you probably all know is a rapidly growing aspect in surgical applications. We paid about $18 million for Ascension. We expect it ought to deliver $3-plus million in EBITDA over the next 12 months. 
In the second half, we expect to have continued weakness in this academic research area, which will affect our photonics businesses. Fortunately, the Medical expansion is going to continue. Markets remain pretty favorable. Ascension will give us a little bit of a growth spurt for Northern Digital. 
The Gatan business have a substantial backlog, which we expect to be able to ship during the second half of the year, which will add to our growth. And then we have this transformational Sunquest acquisition, which will add substantial amount of revenue and EBITDA to our Medical platform. We would expect it ought to add somewhere in the neighborhood of $75 million of revenue in last 4 months of the year. It's going to add well over 35% to the Medical & Scientific segment for the next year in revenue. It's going to add quite a substantial amount to Roper's overall revenue base for 2013.
Next slide. So as we look at the Sunquest acquisition, I'll talk a bit about the transaction, and John will talk a little more in-depth about this specific business. 
Next slide. So if we look at the Sunquest acquisition, you can see that it meets all of our acquisition criteria. It's really an amazing fit, where we're able to take our software platforms inside RF and the medical platforms inside Medical & Scientific Imaging and hook them up in a very creative way with the Sunquest business, which is truly a software business but it's also a medical business. 
And if you look at our criteria, we talk about it all the time. Asset light, like low CapEx, absolutely. It's almost no CapEx, and exceptionally light-asset business. 
Focusing on the market structures and driving forces at work, we've done probably more marketplace diligence on this business. Because we actually looked at it in 2010 and have maintained  interest in the business forever and really felt that based on the work that we had done and the things that we thought they could and should be looking at and then seeing how they've done, our diligence revealed a lot of strategic competitive advantages that Sunquest enjoys, and they have a lot of whitespace opportunities for growth that are beyond our core traditional business. 
They've done a great job in transforming their business. It was acquired by Vista in 2007 and certainly was a high-margin business, but it could be better. And to the Sunquest leadership teams' efforts, they've done an incredible job in making that a transformational business that we're acquiring now compared to what it was in 2007.
The incentives is always linked to the commitments that the leadership teams made and those are in place. It has technology advantages that are clear and easily measured against competition, and it has very deep application expertise. It really is a niche business in the lab market. 
Management continuity is always as valued, and everybody on that team has agreed to stay in place. The communication for the Sunquest employees is taking place this morning in Tucson. We've asked them, as always, to preserve what's made them a very good company in core values that stimulate progress. In this area, the progress is going to come in the form of even more investment in the sales and marketing arena and some faster execution in the development area. 
This is a business that when we talk about growing, once you buy -- mind you, this business has higher margins than we do. It has twice the EBITDA margins that Roper enjoys. And when you look at those kind of margins and you recognize the incredible strength of the company, it has 2/3 of its revenue comes on a recurring basis. 98% of its customers sign up annually for the software programs that it has. 
It has negative working capital and very low CapEx. And we expect, in 2013, that it'll generate $140 million or more EBITDA for us. And the fourth quarter run rate, which they just completed their fiscal company May 31 and just had their audit and signed up prior to our closing, actually supports our expectations for '13 -- 2013 nicely. 
It's really a business, when John talks about it, you want to kind of think about, well, what do they do and where are they located and why do they win, because it is a phenomenal management team and outstanding group of employees that have really done things in this space that no one can really replicate.
So with that, we'll turn to the next slide and John Humphrey.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Brian. So just talk a little bit more about kind of what Sunquest is and what it is able to provide for its customers. They are the global market leader for providing the underlying software information solution for laboratories and hospital
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Brian. So just talk a little bit more about kind of what Sunquest is and what it is able to provide for its customers. They are the global market leader for providing the underlying software information solution for laboratories and hospitals and large academic medical centers with a headquarter in Tucson, Arizona, locations both in the U.K. and a development center in Bangalore. They have a global footprint that allows them to serve that customer base. 
Who are their customer base? So those folks who -- for whom the effectiveness and efficiency of the lab is of critical importance. The lab ends up with, in many cases, hundreds of thousands of tests being done each month to support the diagnostic decisions that are made on the hospital, and they rely upon the Sunquest information and the quality and safety associated with that to help drive those decisions. 
Their comprehensive solutions is about improving the productivity with workflow automation tools. You see on the right-hand side both the Sunquest Laboratory 7.0 and the CoPath solution. Both of those are about workflow automation to make sure that the right test is done on the right patient at the right time, leading to the right diagnosis. So those things also reach beyond just the lab and also go out to the collection manager, which is one of the modules that Sunquest has. So that nurse has a point of collection tool that integrates back with the lab so you have full connectivity between both of those parts of the hospital.
The very large customer base, very high retention rates, over 98% retention each year, continue to utilize and depend upon their software set of solutions. And it's really supported by a 30-year history, and these are very long-term relationships. Relationships that are supported by the decades of application expertise that Sunquest has developed about what the hospital lab needs and their unique set of needs that Sunquest is going to be able to meet. 
And as Brian talked about, it's a proven team. It's a great culture. Everything that we learned through the diligence process continues to support the fact that their culture of excellence and execution is really phenomenal, and I think they're going to be a great addition to the team. And I think the company is very well positioned to capture the growth opportunities that they've identified over the coming years.
So with that, I'll turn it back to Brian to talk a little bit about guidance and the summary for the quarter.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So after we get the title sheet on guidance, we move to the guidance slide. We've raised our full year guidance to $4.84 to $5. That reflects about a $0.04 reduction due to currency. We had started out at $4.75 to $4.91. You might remember that $0.0
componenttext:
Okay. So after we get the title sheet on guidance, we move to the guidance slide. We've raised our full year guidance to $4.84 to $5. That reflects about a $0.04 reduction due to currency. We had started out at $4.75 to $4.91. You might remember that $0.04 comes off the bottom of your $4.71 and $0.05 off the top here, $4.86, and we're adding back $0.12 and $0.14 on a GAAP accretion for Sunquest, excluding any of the deal cost. And then in addition, of course, we've got other things that we're absorbing and other things that are good. So $4.84 to $5 on full year guidance. The quarter comes in at $1.19 to $1.25 in the third quarter. Most importantly, really, is that we now expect our full year operating cash flow to be approximately $700 million. 
And just a couple of footnotes. You'll notice there the acquisition of Sunquest we expect to close at the end of August. We'll have the HSR filing. And since there is no competitive issues, it should move along quickly. 
We have some deferred revenue that's unusual in Sunquest and some of our some other businesses. When you acquire them, there are some GAAP issues around that. And so we'll have to -- we'll kind of reveal that to you each quarter as we report out. And this does exclude whatever cost we will have that will be registered in the third quarter that will be related to the acquisition and removal of the remaining amortization in the old revolver.
Next slide. So looking at the summary of the second quarter, we go back to the top point, being that it's, again, an all-time record for any second quarter in our history, highest level of orders, revenue, backlog, net earnings and EBITDA. Organic quarter growth at 7% was really a pleasant benefit for the quarter. The operating margin's at 24.7%, the EBITDA at 29.5% and gross margins at 54.9%, really terrific. Leverage is kind of breathtaking at 59%. We used to talk about 30% to 35% leverage, and it's hard to see how our leverage isn't going to be above 40% for a long time.
Doing a new revolver, a big help, $1.5 billion. The old revolver was put in place on July of 2008 and would have had to be replaced in July of 2013. So this removes any refinancing risk around that for next year. It gives us twice as much capacity to write checks against, as we had previously, and $1.5 billion is pretty sizable revolver for Roper. That was completed last Friday, a timely completion, we might add, relative to the deal closing on Saturday. 
Sunquest, a -- just an exceptional financial profile, higher gross margins than we have at twice the EBITDA margins, a terrific fit. You couldn't find a business that sort of marry what we're doing in software and what we're doing in Medical that would benefit both so much as Sunquest. It's got great development people. Our software people spent last week in Bangalore, visiting and talking with people. We've done tremendous diligence around the robustness of the software platforms in place for Sunquest and how they can be used. 
All of these then creates an opportunity for us to be positioned again in 2012 for an all-time record year, $700 million in operating cash flow. And perhaps, most importantly, the transformation process that we're doing here continues as we get more and more technology. If you think about where we are, and how we continue this, we have more technology content. We have higher margins, higher cash returns, more recurring revenue and just a much different company than what you would've looked at in 2002. And then in the next 5 years, we added Neptune and TransCore. And then if you look at 2007 and you look at the forward 5 years here to 2012, you've picked up CBORD and Horizon and iTrade and Technolog and, now, Sunquest. So the technology content gets better, margins get better, cash return gets better and the available forward acquisition powder for growth will be better than it ever has been in the past. 
And with that, I think we're ready for questions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Matt Summerville, KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to clarify something, Brian, on Sunquest. That $0.12 to $0.14, is that a GAAP number that will have, under GAAP rules, the deferred revenue adjustments? I just want to make sure I have that right.
componenttext: I just wanted to clarify something, Brian, on Sunquest. That $0.12 to $0.14, is that a GAAP number that will have, under GAAP rules, the deferred revenue adjustments? I just want to make sure I have that right.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: That is -- Matt, this is John. That's a non-GAAP number. So as you're probably aware, like an awful lot of software companies, Sunquest has deferred revenue for the annual maintenance. They get paid in advance for that. And the accounting rules upon acqui
componenttext: That is -- Matt, this is John. That's a non-GAAP number. So as you're probably aware, like an awful lot of software companies, Sunquest has deferred revenue for the annual maintenance. They get paid in advance for that. And the accounting rules upon acquisition will require us to take a write-down of that, so to basically move that deferred revenue to a fair value. And then over the next 12 months, as those renewals happen, that deferred revenue will get build back up. So the $0.12 to $0.14 is a non-GAAP number. And as we're able to estimate exactly what that deferred revenue fair value adjustment is, then we'll be able to provide that for you. We won't be able to do that until after we close the business. But we'll be providing that insight each quarter to be able to reconcile between the GAAP numbers and then the non-GAAP numbers that we think provides better visibility in understanding the operations of the company.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

componenttext: The greatness, though, is the cash is the cash.

componenttext: Absolutely. Brian, could you maybe spend a minute talking about, just more broadly for Roper, as you moved through Q2, how would you characterize the overall demand environment for your businesses? And then how are orders so far in July from what you've seen?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, really, the quarter from an organic -- we wouldn't have given ourselves much of a shot at having 7% organic orders in the quarter. That was a pleasant surprise. But we got really strong pull activity that we knew would eventually come in here. I
componenttext: I think, really, the quarter from an organic -- we wouldn't have given ourselves much of a shot at having 7% organic orders in the quarter. That was a pleasant surprise. But we got really strong pull activity that we knew would eventually come in here. I wouldn't necessarily say in the quarter, so that helped. I think we entered the quarter with more concern and turned out to be justified. So those any like early indicators of things that would make us nervous that would be in Energy or Industrial, we really haven't seen that. There's just a little bit of activity, mostly in petrochem and oil and gas, that we're going to do some very modest internal retrenchment on. But on balance, it's pretty good. We never really talk about a quarter in which we're in, but I would say things remain pretty decent. We're going to expect -- organic growth actually kind of picked up in the second quarter, and we would expect it to continue to be mid-single digits, really, for the rest of the year. So it's really kind of better than we expect, because there's more European headwinds than we would have originally forecast.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: How much was your European business down in the quarter?
componenttext: How much was your European business down in the quarter?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: It was down 18% for us in total. About half of that is just due to currency though. So that'd be 8% or 9% on an organic basis. Something to remember on that, Matt, is that does include the headwinds associated with the Gaz de France. So that's kind of $5
componenttext: It was down 18% for us in total. About half of that is just due to currency though. So that'd be 8% or 9% on an organic basis. Something to remember on that, Matt, is that does include the headwinds associated with the Gaz de France. So that's kind of $5 million. But even once you take that out, we saw a decline in Europe that was definitely mid-single digits.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: So on Sunquest, Brian, you talked about that there's a lot of whitespace. Can you talk about what that would look like? I mean, is it market share shift? Is it just -- it's under-penetrated as far as the clinics and hospitals, or is it geographies?
componenttext: So on Sunquest, Brian, you talked about that there's a lot of whitespace. Can you talk about what that would look like? I mean, is it market share shift? Is it just -- it's under-penetrated as far as the clinics and hospitals, or is it geographies?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- we don't want to tip off other people to things that we think are available to us, but it would be safe to say that we think that they can continue to grow share at the expense of other people. We think people have been paying a lot of at
componenttext: Well, I think -- we don't want to tip off other people to things that we think are available to us, but it would be safe to say that we think that they can continue to grow share at the expense of other people. We think people have been paying a lot of attention to Electronic Health Records and companies that are in the EHR space. Here, again, we've picked out a niche that we think is unrelated to that activity, and this niche has got an opportunity, very high return, for people investing in this, in the hospital space and in the clinic space and in private care space. Basically, lab work is critical to every aspects of people diagnosing folks, and it happens in a variety of different places. We think we have the preeminent technology to do that, and we think we can make people more productive and more efficient than what they do when they do it. It has been hard, I think, the last couple of years to get the attention of hospitals that have had these mandates to do a variety of thing around health records. Now they get a chance to make an investment in things like this business, so it'll give them an actual return. So we think it's got pretty exciting growth. And these guys, they've -- they have brought in a new sales executive, a woman who we have great confidence in, that we think is going to drive better focus on organic growth. It's been a very high cash contributor, and it's the same old situation. Private equity has done, in this case, a really amazing job with this business versus what they acquired in '07, but it can grow more. And it has -- it does have opportunities for share gain and expansion around the world. I mean, this business it doesn't do much in certain portions of the world, and we do a lot in other portions of the world than they do. It's also got an incredible development team in Bangalore, and that is very, very bullish for us.

componenttext: I think it ought to -- it'll grow its cash and EBITDA double digits. Revenue in their current year -- forward revenue is probably going to go up by 10%. We would think, over time, that it grows revenue. Remember, it's got this massive recurring business, right. So in fact,  new business won't look like a high number. So if you got a couple hundred million of constant business, it could grow its net new business by 20% and it wouldn't look like a big number on the core business, right. So it's not like looking at a cyclical company that's up and down and looking at various trends. This is just as -- it starts with its Q4 and then each quarter gets better all the time.
