headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing what the lessons you learned from iTrade and how that played into both the negotiation for Sunquest but also integration, managing a software company and so forth.
componenttext: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing what the lessons you learned from iTrade and how that played into both the negotiation for Sunquest but also integration, managing a software company and so forth.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: We have a big advantage today versus when we first acquired iTrade, in that we have recently hired a chief architect for our technology businesses who's working in our software arena. We also have a software executive full time that's looking over our var
componenttext: We have a big advantage today versus when we first acquired iTrade, in that we have recently hired a chief architect for our technology businesses who's working in our software arena. We also have a software executive full time that's looking over our various software companies, and we have a medical executive, which we didn't have before, looking over the Medical scenario. So between the 2 new executives and one that's a domain expert in Medical, one that's a domain expert in software and the architectural person, the quality of our diligence that we're able to do on our own was a dramatic improvement. We have a much deeper understanding about source code and the ways in which development programs need to be done and measured, and we've got a deeper understanding about cost structures around development activity. And all those things are good. I think we also come to recognize that a slightly lower organic growth rates in the software businesses really are the problem because of the recurring revenue that they have inside them and the quality of the cash that they generate. I mean, to look at a company, I think most people would look at us and say this is best-of-breed EBITDA margins, and yet, here, we're acquiring one that has twice the margins that we enjoy. So they are fundamentally different, and our executive leadership capability around them is better than ever.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify on the deferred revenues. You said that it refers to the maintenance side of it. Is that 2 years? It's pretty typical that you see in 2 years of maintenance fees. And are any of the licensing fees included in that deferred revenues, or
componenttext: And just to clarify on the deferred revenues. You said that it refers to the maintenance side of it. Is that 2 years? It's pretty typical that you see in 2 years of maintenance fees. And are any of the licensing fees included in that deferred revenues, or is it just maintenance?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the short answer is, nothing on the license fees, and the maintenance contracts and the deferred revenue are 2 slightly different things. So the maintenance agreements range anywhere from 1-year, 3-year, 5-years, some of it or even 7-year agreements, b
componenttext: So the short answer is, nothing on the license fees, and the maintenance contracts and the deferred revenue are 2 slightly different things. So the maintenance agreements range anywhere from 1-year, 3-year, 5-years, some of it or even 7-year agreements, because, of course, the customer would like to make sure that they have kind of the long-term commitment with Sunquest or Sunquest might have in the long-term contracts. So -- but they don't pay for all 7 years or all 5 years upfront. So it's a 1 year of payment, and that's what goes into the deferred revenue. So we would expect to see that deferred revenue build back up after the fair value adjustment, after 12 months to be back to the normal-steady state.

componenttext: Well, you'll have to define new era. So if -- it's the lumpy areas alive and well for those activities. There are a lot of initiatives. I think the longer we go with people learning more and more about our United Toll Systems technology, the more and more and more people recognize it is dramatically superior to what other people have done for a long period of time, including ourselves. So the lead time for getting agencies to understand and see and test and kick tires around that is kind of long. But in terms of long-term growth vehicle, nobody has got a better mouse trap than us, and I don't think anybody is going to get one. So we like the long-term nature of the business, and we certainly like the second quarter. And we think the rest of the year will be fine.

componenttext: And just to put a little more color around that, Chris, for instance, the win in Harris County is not a conversion from a non-toll to a tolled lane or a new road that's being constructed. componenttext: It's very sustainable. So we know exactly where it came from in every one of the businesses, and certainly, we have tightened up our execution in the TransCore toll business and have better margins as a result of that activity, which is a shout out to a terrific work that's been done, really, by George McGraw in our Amtech business and some work that's been done in our ITS business. That said, software tends to grow at a faster clip than our friends do in the rest of the product measure of RF. And as it grows, it carries with it extraordinary margins compared to the product businesses.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't really know. Jeff. It's possible. I sure wouldn't rule against it. I know what we're willing to do. You never know what other people are willing to do. So -- and there's usually a bid-ask spread all the time when we're doing work. This transaction
componenttext: I don't really know. Jeff. It's possible. I sure wouldn't rule against it. I know what we're willing to do. You never know what other people are willing to do. So -- and there's usually a bid-ask spread all the time when we're doing work. This transaction with Sunquest demonstrates kind of how we act, right. So I mean, we started talking to these people in 2010, and we – I'll tell you, sometimes we'll give people ideas or whatever. We wonder about they are going to do. I think these people have done just a spectacular job of taking advantage of some momentum that we thought could be available to them, and they've done that. So we have some transactions that are similar to this. So we have to talk to people off and on about -- for several years. I think that depending on who owns the asset and what people think is going to happen between now and the end of the year around the tax structures, going into next year, you have higher levels of seller activity. If they believe nothing is going to change and they don't have capital gains that they're worried about, they may hold on. If, on the other hand, they think that getting a high percentage of something is better than a lower percentage of something else, we may close the valuation gap. I don't know. So, I think it's possible that we would do another transaction, probably not quite as large as $1.4 billion, however.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would bet not. But that brings up another topic. What are you thinking about on the divestiture side? Not naming names, of course, but clearly, the portfolio is changing. There's maybe some pieces of it that are not as core as they used to be. It's an i
componenttext: I would bet not. But that brings up another topic. What are you thinking about on the divestiture side? Not naming names, of course, but clearly, the portfolio is changing. There's maybe some pieces of it that are not as core as they used to be. It's an interesting juncture, right. I mean, your returns are so high. Anything you divest is dilutive. But at a time when you've got maybe such accretive acquisition activity going on, perhaps there's an opportunity to move the portfolio a little bit differently. Are you thinking that way at all? Is there any prospect for something leaving the portfolio in the next 6, 12 months?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, our core business is delivering a tremendous amount of cash. They've gotten dramatically better. Their cash returns are more than 50% better than they were like 5 years ago. They give us tremendous EPS performance, because they don’t have the non-
componenttext: Well, our core business is delivering a tremendous amount of cash. They've gotten dramatically better. Their cash returns are more than 50% better than they were like 5 years ago. They give us tremendous EPS performance, because they don’t have the non-GAAP of -- or amortization charges that lay against them. There is certainly an increasing inflection point where you look at this and say, "What about this situation?" We're in a marvelous place, where since we maintain the autonomy at each one of these businesses, we can always decouple a business and not have any problem doing that. It's not like some other strategic that's got everything so embedded that one factory is making 5 items and one information system can't go with the business. So all our businesses are total isolated and independent, and anyone could be spun-off to another party. I think people largely have some ideas about which things might become available, kind of like the trade deadline, right, for Tuesday, so depends who's willing to pay what. But we're not an active seller, but we have some assets that are probably more valuable to others than they are to us.

componenttext: Well, I mean, since the EBITDA excludes the effective amortization, I don't think that really impacts that. Having said that, the accretion number for the back half of this year, the $0.12 to $0.14 that we expect, that does include the new amortization that we are estimating that we will absorb and then start to record post acquisition. So on the EPS side, it definitely does include that, of course, always with a caveat that does not include the impact of the deferred revenue fair value accounting treatment.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to ask you about Industrial Technology business and the Pump business, specifically. Another company recently recorded a substantial decline in orders is Gardner Denver, in the petroleum and industrial pump business. In that particular bus
componenttext: First, I wanted to ask you about Industrial Technology business and the Pump business, specifically. Another company recently recorded a substantial decline in orders is Gardner Denver, in the petroleum and industrial pump business. In that particular business of theirs, orders were down 36% in the quarter. And in another division, they had a pressure pumping order decline of 17%. And you haven't seen anything like that, according to what you said. Do you compete with them, or are you taking market share? Or just what is going on here? Because the 2 results are dramatically different?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the markets we're focused on are totally different for the most part than Gardner Denver. I mean, they're -- we do have dewatering pumps that Cornell makes, and those have certainly been used in the shale activity. Those have had strong growt
componenttext: Yes. I think the markets we're focused on are totally different for the most part than Gardner Denver. I mean, they're -- we do have dewatering pumps that Cornell makes, and those have certainly been used in the shale activity. Those have had strong growth. That growth is moderating, but it's not totally negative at all. That's a pretty small part of the overall enterprise. And our Roper Pump business continues to grow quite substantially. So I think -- gosh, I'm just not really at all close to Gardner Denver, but I think they're building a lot of stuff that maybe is going into rental and platforms and that stuff. We have some rental business with Cornell, but it's not the core component of what we do. So we're still making pumps for waste water activity, agricultural irrigation and those kind of things.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And second question is on the orders for RF Technology. TransCore, on July 19, said they were awarded the Texas Department of Transportation statewide toll system integration and maintenance contract, replacing one of your competitors and you get to
componenttext: Okay. And second question is on the orders for RF Technology. TransCore, on July 19, said they were awarded the Texas Department of Transportation statewide toll system integration and maintenance contract, replacing one of your competitors and you get to replace all of their systems, plus add your own to new systems that come on board. So you didn't mentioned this, I don't believe. There seems to be a different project than the one you talked about in RF Technology. Could you talk about this new TransCore business that was announced July 19?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alex. And you're correct, it's not the same one. The HCTRA business for the Harris County is the one that we talked about. What you're referring to is the TxDOT, which operates a different set of toll lanes across the state of Texas. And you're righ
componenttext: Sure, Alex. And you're correct, it's not the same one. The HCTRA business for the Harris County is the one that we talked about. What you're referring to is the TxDOT, which operates a different set of toll lanes across the state of Texas. And you're right, we'll be providing them with software and maintenance activity. More of a -- it's an indefinite quantity, indefinite timing, so it's an IDIQ type of contract. And so it doesn't have the same immediate booking that the more definite executions for the Harris County does. So we expect the Texas contract to –- sorry the TxDOT contract to add maybe $30 million over the next 3 years. But as a timing, that maybe a little bit lumpy as they decide on when to update and when to upgrade the -- their specific lanes.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Jason Conle
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you all for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our second quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Jason Conley, Head of Finance and Investor Relations for us.
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We've prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com.
If you turn to Slide 2. We begin with our updated Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements, which are subject to the risks and uncertainties as described on this page and as further detailed in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information.
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 3, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. And after his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, everybody. Today, we'll go through the enterprise financial results for the quarter, talk a little bit about specific segment detail and the outlook for each of the segments, give you an overview of the Sunquest acquisition and then es
componenttext:
Well, good morning, everybody. Today, we'll go through the enterprise financial results for the quarter, talk a little bit about specific segment detail and the outlook for each of the segments, give you an overview of the Sunquest acquisition and then establish our third quarter and full year guidance and take your questions. 
I think we had indicated in our first quarter call that we expected going into the second quarter would be our most difficult challenge for the year. We had really an outstanding quarter compared to what we expected because we had quite a few headwinds this quarter. Certainly, we had the uncertain economy and were able to blow through that. 
We had very difficult comps going into Q2 because of the Gaz de France revenue last year and outsized performance and toll tag shipments last year in our Gatan technology business that we knew wouldn't be repeated. And then of course, we had currency, which became a bigger surprise than we expected. It cost us about $0.01 a share versus our guidance and about $0.02 a share versus the prior year. That said, let's look at what we did in Q2.
Next slide. We had record results in the second quarter, pretty well across-the-board, highest level of orders in our history, highest level of sales in our history in the second quarter, biggest backlog that we've entered the second quarter with, record net earnings and record EBITDA performance for the quarter. 
Our orders were up 8%, and revenue was up 4%, despite those headwinds and the effect of currency. Our book-to-bill ratio was actually quite high at 1.05. Our gross margins reached 54.9% in the quarter, and our operating margin was really quite spectacular. It came up 130 basis points to 24.7%. 
If you look at the incremental OP and the incremental sales, our operating leverage in the quarter was 59%, and there are no smoke and mirrors in that. It's just 59%. Our EBITDA was up 214 -- or sorry, was $214 million, and our EBITDA margin reached 29.5%. 
Operating cash flow in the quarter was $119 million, slightly lower than we would expect in the second quarter, but we had a higher cash tax rate, and that won't happen again in the rest of the year. Our first half operating cash flow was $261 million, and we’ll project what we believe it will be for the full year later this morning.
Our diluted earnings per share were $1.15 versus $1.03 last year. That $1.15 would've been $0.01 higher if -- based on our guidance, if it weren't for the currency scenario. And the $1.03 is the number that we used with the remeasurement gain last year. You might remember, it was about $0.05 a share. So on GAAP, it would have been $1.08, but it was really adjusted at $1.03. 
Net earnings were up 13%. We're very happy with the performance because we had about $30 million headwind between our scientific camera business and Gaz de France and some European activity coming into the quarter, and we were able to really blow through that. Very solid revenue throughout the world with the exception of Europe, which was down about 18%. Record performance, really, in an uncertain economic environment.
Next slide. In the Q2 income statement, you'll see orders were $763 million, up 7% organically. Revenue book-to-bill came in at 1.05. Gross profit was up 100 basis points to 54.9% from 53.9% a year ago, and our operating income was an amazing 24.7%, up 130 basis points for a year ago. Our interest expense is about flat. Tax rate was consistent with the guidance we established for the quarter, came in at 29.6%, and net earnings were $115 million versus $102 million last year, up 13%.
Next slide. If we look at our EBITDA performance, our trailing 12 months EBITDA has now reached $845 million. It's up from last year's trailing number at this time of $739 million and, 2 years ago, $540 million. So EBITDA is up 57% over the last 2 years, and our EBITDA margins continue to soar. We were 25.2% in 2010 and 29.3% on the trailing 12 months calculation now, and of course, this quarter at 29.5%.
Next. If we look here at the cash flow performance, you'll see Q2 cash flow at $119 million of operating cash flow and $109 million of free cash flow. Very good performance again in working capital. Our inventory actually improved by 30 bps from 7.5% to 7.2% of revenue, and our accounts receivable improved by 50 bps from 15.6% to 15.1%. And when you adjust that for payables and accruals, we were still below 7%. 
In the first half cash flow, normally, our first half cash flow, is about 40% of the full year. This year, it'll -- the second half will be even a little stronger because of the acquisition of Sunquest and how cash accretive it really is. So you can see that our full year operating cash flow, we've now raised our guidance to be about $700 million for the full year. That'll put our operating cash flow at a very high percentage of revenue. It could reach 23% of revenue, in fact. 
It's really driven by expanded margins. It's driven by the Sunquest acquisition that we expect to close in the last 4 months of the year and some cash tax benefits that we're acquiring in the Sunquest transaction. It does exclude the deal cost and refinancing charges associated with the new credit facility we put in place effective this past Friday.
And you can see here that free cash -- or operating cash flow goes up to $700 million, our estimate this year up from $602 million last year and $500 million the year before. So that would be a 40% increase in cash flow over the last 2 years.
Next slide. On Friday, we closed a new credit facility, a $1.5 billion revolver. So if you look at our normal credit stats here, a year ago on 6/30/11, you can see that we had $196 million in cash and $595 million in an undrawn revolver, which gave us acquisition powder, investment powder of about $791 million. When we closed out the quarter on June 30, our cash had increased to $519 million, and our undrawn revolver was at its capacity at $750 million, giving us $1.269 billion. As of Friday, with the new $1.5 billion revolver and the cash from the end of the quarter, we now have capacity in excess of $2 billion. 
Our gross debt, on the other hand, is only $1.069 billion. Our gross debt to capitalization is at 23.8%, but if you look at the net debt to EBITDA, you'll see it's actually been cut in half from a year ago. It was 1.4. And at the end of the quarter, it was 0.7. Even with the financing of the Sunquest acquisition at $1.4 billion, we will have ample capacity to pursue other opportunities in the near term, and the pipeline remains very, very exciting.
If we look next slide here at the Sunquest details -- or sorry, the segment details, we'll start with the RF Technology slide. Next. 
So on RF Technology, really, very, very outstanding orders in the quarter. They were up 18%. So those orders and the execution, really, in the toll and traffic business kind of got us up to the high end of our range, despite the European pressures, and helped us deliver. 
You can see the OP margin was amazing at 27%, up 290 basis points. And if you want to look at leverage, revenue was down 2%, and operating profit was up 10%. So that would speak strongly to the execution that's occurring in those businesses. 
The software businesses continue to help us on the margin expansion as they grow. We got a very significant win again in Houston. We're going to upgrade the entire lane hardware in the Houston area with our United Toll Systems technology, which is really an advancement over what was in place in the past. We think that contract ought to produce about $65 million in revenue between maintenance and the change-out. 
Our CBORD cashless system business continued to grow. It had a record quarter in the second quarter for it, for anytime, and that involved both university and food management wins in both higher education and healthcare. 
And we had, of course, this difficult headwind for our Technolog business, Gaz de France, which had that sort of onetime large install last year, and that held us back by about $5 million in the quarter. In the second half, we'll have the continued difficult comp with the Gaz de France because it went throughout the year last year. But our increased toll project and maintenance activity that will be led by this -- these Texas wins will easily offset any challenges we have and the rest of those types of activities in the segment. 
And then software businesses and the Software-as-a-Service activity is continuing to increase. And both iTrade and Freight Matching continue to roll along with the sort of nominal organic growth but outstanding cash growth.
Next slide. If we look at the Industrial Technology segment, gee, it's just, again, spectacular performance. Revenue was up 11%. The operating profit margins reached 30.4%. That's an all-time record for the segment. The highest previous we ever had was at 29.2% in the fourth quarter last year. 
This 30.4%, to just add some perspective around how amazing it is, the S&P 500 Industrials gross margins, as a group, were 30.8%. Roper's operating profit for Industrial is 30.4%. So we've got an all-time record here in OP margin, again, leveraged off the growth, terrific execution everywhere. 
Fluid handling continues to grow in both agriculture, food and the shale activity. Our general industrial markets have performed well. We're not seeing any early indicators of any softness in any of those businesses. 
The Material Test business, which is primarily a European business, actually had a record second quarter. Very strong North America and Asia sales offset any weakness that we had in Europe. And the Neptune business continued to grow, driven by the Toronto project and some higher shipments in the U.S. 
In the second half of the year, we would expect that the shale activity growth would moderate, not stall, but certainly moderate, with the gas activity on shale being down but the oil activity on shale being up. The industrial end markets, again, no signs of any falloff. The outstanding margins we expect to continue throughout the second half of the year. And just a personal note to all our people in Industrial, we just couldn't be more proud of these teams as we watch them execute in a very tough market.
Next slide. If we look at our Energy Systems & Controls business, here, you can see revenue was up 6%; OP, up 7%. Margin at 26% was up 200 basis points from the first quarter margin in Energy. Organic growth in the quarter was 5%. Compressor Controls continues to do very well on LNG projects, and the field service activity that we do drove double-digit growth for them. 
The bolt-on acquisitions that we did in the last year were very small, United Controls Group, Trinity and Cambridge, all have noncash amortization charges in them. They're actually putting a little bit of a drag on the OP margins, even though at 26%, it's hard to see a drag. But they actually would have been about 120 basis points higher in OP without all that amortization drag and integration on those 3 businesses. That said, they're performing well. They're all on plan from an integration viewpoint. They will add to growth in the second half of the year. 
Our European markets weakened. In fact, in Energy, they were down about 18%, but our U.S. was up by about 18%. So the U.S. business being larger, that was a benefit. And the rest of the world was quite strong in the Middle East and Asia, Australia. Brazil not quite as strong. 
Targeted cost actions are underway for the second half on a very selected basis, where people are executing some contingency plans in those things that relate to any softness that they see. We think Europe continued to be soft, but we'll have continued growth in both North America and Middle East and Asia to offset that. 
With the exception of our petrochem business, which is down about 20%, and that's a worldwide shortfall, we're not seeing any strength anywhere in that business. Very solid backlog, though, at Compressor Controls. It gives us confidence about growth in the second half. And then we would expect the normal, very strong Q4 seasonal activity in Energy would be repeated this year.
Next slide. So here we’ll look at Medical & Scientific Imaging. This is one of those things where it looks like nothing happened, but there is great variability throughout the different businesses here. And while revenue was flat and operating margin was up 20 bps, what really was going on is that Europe and the North American academic research funding softness impacted our camera portion of the photonics businesses. 
Cameras are not a big part of Roper, but they do come in around $125 million to $140 million worth of total revenue. And they were down as much as 20% in some cases. And we don't see any real turnaround as it relates to these research markets for the camera technology businesses. And while they perform relative well, they certainly are a drag on short-term growth. 
Our Medical businesses continue to grow organically. The channel expansion that we've been able to provide them in Asia is offsetting any weakness that they have in Europe. And the Northern Digital business performed very well, expanding its offerings to OEM customers. And also, we were able to do a bolt-on acquisition in the quarter called Ascension Technology Corp., which is in the state of Vermont. And Ascension does 3D tracking for minimally invasive surgery, which you probably all know is a rapidly growing aspect in surgical applications. We paid about $18 million for Ascension. We expect it ought to deliver $3-plus million in EBITDA over the next 12 months. 
In the second half, we expect to have continued weakness in this academic research area, which will affect our photonics businesses. Fortunately, the Medical expansion is going to continue. Markets remain pretty favorable. Ascension will give us a little bit of a growth spurt for Northern Digital. 
The Gatan business has a substantial backlog, which we expect to be able to ship during the second half of the year, which will add to our growth. And then we have this transformational Sunquest acquisition, which will add substantial amount of revenue and EBITDA to our Medical platform. We would expect it ought to add somewhere in the neighborhood of $75 million of revenue in last 4 months of the year. It's going to add well over 35% to the Medical & Scientific segment for the next year in revenue. It's going to add quite a substantial amount to Roper's overall revenue base for 2013.
Next slide. So as we look at the Sunquest acquisition, I'll talk a bit about the transaction, and John will talk a little more in-depth about the specific business. 
Next slide. So if we look at the Sunquest acquisition, you can see that it meets all of our acquisition criteria. It's really an amazing fit, where we're able to take our software platforms inside RF and the medical platforms inside Medical & Scientific Imaging and hook them up in a very creative way with the Sunquest business, which is truly a software business but it's also a medical business. 
And if you look at our criteria, we talk about all the time, asset light, low CapEx, absolutely. It's almost no CapEx and exceptionally light-asset business. 
Focusing on the market structures and driving forces at work, we've done probably more marketplace diligence on this business. Because we actually looked at it in 2010 and have maintained an interest in the business forever and really felt that based on the work that we had done and the things that we thought they could and should be looking at and then seeing how they've done, our diligence revealed a lot of strategic competitive advantages that Sunquest enjoys, and they have a lot of whitespace opportunities for growth that are beyond their core traditional business. 
They've done a great job in transforming their business. It was acquired by Vista in 2007 and certainly was a high-margin business, but it could be better. And to the Sunquest leadership teams’ efforts, they've done an incredible job in making that a transformational business that we're acquiring now compared to what it was in 2007.
The incentives, as always, are linked to the commitments that the leadership teams made, and those are in place. It has technology advantages that are clear and easily measured against competition, and it has very deep application expertise. It really is a niche business in the lab market. 
Management continuity, as always, is valued, and everybody on that team has agreed to stay in place. The communication for the Sunquest employees is taking place this morning in Tucson. We've asked them, as always, to preserve what's made them a very good company in core values that stimulate progress. In this area, the progress is going to come in the form of even more investment in the sales and marketing arena and some faster execution in the development area. 
This is a business that when we talk about growing what you buy -- my goodness, this business has higher margins than we do. It has twice the EBITDA margins that Roper enjoys. And when you look at those kind of margins and you recognize the incredible strength of the company, it has -- 2/3 of its revenue comes on a recurring basis. 98% of its customers sign up annually for the software programs that it has. 
It has negative working capital and very low CapEx. And we expect, in 2013, that it'll generate $140 million or more EBITDA for us. The fourth quarter run rate, which they just completed their fiscal company May 31 and just had their audit and signed up prior to our closing, actually supports our expectations for '13 -- 2013 nicely. 
It's really a business, when John talks about it, you want to kind of think about, well, what do they do and where are they located and why do they win, because it is a phenomenal management team and outstanding group of employees that have really done things in this space that no one can really replicate.
So with that, we'll turn to the next slide and John Humphrey.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Brian. So just talking a little bit more about kind of what Sunquest is and what it is able to provide for its customers. They are the global market leader for providing the underlying software and information solution for laboratories and h
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Brian. So just talking a little bit more about kind of what Sunquest is and what it is able to provide for its customers. They are the global market leader for providing the underlying software and information solution for laboratories and hospitals and large academic medical centers with a headquarter in Tucson, Arizona, locations both in the U.K. and a development center in Bangalore. They have a global footprint that allows them to serve that customer base. 
Really, their customer base are those folks who -- for whom the effectiveness and efficiency of the lab is of critical importance. The lab ends up with, in many cases, hundreds of thousands of tests being done each month to support the diagnostic decisions that are made in a hospital, and they rely upon the Sunquest information and the quality and safety associated with that to help drive those decisions. 
Their comprehensive solutions is about improving the productivity with workflow automation tools. You see on the right-hand side both the Sunquest Laboratory 7.0 and the CoPath solution. Both of those are about workflow automation to make sure that the right test is done on the right patient at the right time, leading to the right diagnosis. So those things also reach beyond just the lab and also go out to the collection manager, which is one of the modules that Sunquest has. So that nurse has a point of collection tool that integrates back with the lab so you have full connectivity between both of those parts of the hospital.
The very large customer base, very high retention rates, over 98% retention each year, continue to utilize and depend upon the software set of solutions. And it's really supported by a 30-year history, and these are very long-term relationships. Relationships that are supported by the decades of application expertise that Sunquest has developed about what the hospital lab needs and their unique set of needs that Sunquest is going to be able to meet. 
And as Brian talked about, it's a proven team. It's a great culture. Everything that we learned during the diligence process continues to support the fact that their culture of excellence and of execution is really phenomenal, and I think they're going to be a great addition to the team. And I think the company is very well positioned to capture the growth opportunities that they've identified over the coming years.
So with that, I'll turn it back to Brian to talk a little bit about guidance and the summary for the quarter.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So after we get the title sheet on guidance, we move to the guidance slide. We've raised our full year guidance to $4.84 to $5. That reflects about a $0.04 reduction due to currency. We had started out at $4.75 to $4.91. You might remember, if $0.04
componenttext:
Okay. So after we get the title sheet on guidance, we move to the guidance slide. We've raised our full year guidance to $4.84 to $5. That reflects about a $0.04 reduction due to currency. We had started out at $4.75 to $4.91. You might remember, if $0.04 comes off the bottom, you’re at $4.71, and $0.05 off the top, you’re at $4.86, and we're adding back $0.12 and $0.14 on a GAAP accretion for Sunquest, excluding any of the deal cost. And then in addition, of course, we've got other things that we're absorbing and other things that are good. So $4.84 to $5 on full year guidance. The quarter comes in at $1.19 to $1.25 in the third quarter. Most importantly, really, is that we now expect our full year operating cash flow to be approximately $700 million. 
And just a couple of footnotes. You'll notice there the acquisition of Sunquest we expect to close at the end of August. We'll have the HSR filing. And since there is no competitive issues, it should move along quickly. 
We have some deferred revenue that's unusual in Sunquest. Similar to some other businesses, when you acquire them, there are some GAAP issues around that. And so we'll have to -- we'll kind of reveal that to you each quarter as we report out. And this does exclude whatever cost we will have that will be registered in the third quarter. That will be related to the acquisition and removal of the remaining amortization in the old revolver.
Next slide. So looking at the summary of the second quarter, we go back to the top point being that it's, again, an all-time record for any second quarter in our history, highest level of orders, revenue, backlog, net earnings and EBITDA. Organic quarter growth at 7% was really a pleasant benefit for the quarter. The operating margin's at 24.7%, the EBITDA at 29.5% and gross margin’s at 54.9%, really terrific. Leverage is kind of breathtaking at 59%. We used to talk about 30% to 35% leverage, and it's hard to see how our leverage isn't going to be above 40% for a long time.
Doing a new revolver, a big help, $1.5 billion. The old revolver was put in place on July of 2008 and would have had to be replaced in July of 2013. So this removes any refinancing risk around that for next year. It gives us twice as much capacity to write checks against as we had previously, and $1.5 billion is a pretty sizable revolver for Roper. That was completed last Friday, a timely completion, we might add, relative to the deal closing on Saturday. 
Sunquest, a -- just an exceptional financial profile, higher gross margins than we have at twice the EBITDA margins, a terrific fit. You couldn't find a business that sort of married what we're doing in software and what we're doing in Medical that would benefit both so much as Sunquest. It's got great development people. Our software people spent last week in Bangalore, visiting and talking with people. We've done tremendous diligence around the robustness of the software platforms in place for Sunquest and how they can be used. 
All of this then creates an opportunity for us to be positioned again in 2012 for an all-time record year, $700 million in operating cash flow. And perhaps, most importantly, the transformation process that we're doing here continues as we get more and more technology. If you think about where we are and how we’ve continued this, we have more technology content. We have higher margins, higher cash returns, more recurring revenue and just a much different company than what you would've looked at in 2002. And then in the next 5 years, we added Neptune and TransCore. And then if you look at 2007 and you look at the forward 5 years here to 2012, you've picked up CBORD and Horizon and iTrade and Technolog and, now, Sunquest. So the technology content gets better, margins get better, cash return gets better and the available forward acquisition powder for growth will be better than it ever has been in the past. 
And with that, I think we're ready for questions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

componenttext: I just wanted to clarify something, Brian, on Sunquest. That $0.12 to $0.14, is that a GAAP number that will have, under GAAP rules, the deferred revenue adjustments? I just want to make sure I have that right.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: That is -- Matt, this is John. That's a non-GAAP number. So as you're probably aware, like an awful lot of software companies, Sunquest has deferred revenue for the annual maintenance. They get paid in advance for that. And the accounting rules upon acqui
componenttext: That is -- Matt, this is John. That's a non-GAAP number. So as you're probably aware, like an awful lot of software companies, Sunquest has deferred revenue for the annual maintenance. They get paid in advance for that. And the accounting rules upon acquisition will require us to take a write-down of that, so to basically move that deferred revenue to fair value. And then over the next 12 months, as those renewals happen, that deferred revenue will get built back up. So the $0.12 to $0.14 is a non-GAAP number. And as we're able to estimate exactly what that deferred revenue fair value adjustment is, then we'll be able to provide that for you. We won't be able to do that until after we close the business. But we'll be providing that insight each quarter so you’re able to reconcile between the GAAP numbers and then the non-GAAP numbers that we think provide better visibility in understanding the operations of the company.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, really, the quarter from an organic -- we wouldn't have given ourselves much of a shot at having 7% organic orders in the quarter. That was a pleasant surprise. But we got really strong pull activity that we knew would eventually come in the year
componenttext: I think, really, the quarter from an organic -- we wouldn't have given ourselves much of a shot at having 7% organic orders in the quarter. That was a pleasant surprise. But we got really strong pull activity that we knew would eventually come in the year, wouldn’t have necessarily seen it in the quarter, so that helped. I think we entered the quarter with more concern than turned out to be justified. So those any like early indicators of things that would make us nervous that would be in Energy or Industrial, we really haven't seen that. There's just a little bit of activity, mostly in petrochem and oil and gas, that we're going to do some very modest internal retrenchment on. But on balance, it's pretty good. We never really talk about a quarter in which we're in, but I would say things remain pretty decent. We're going to expect -- organic growth actually kind of picked up in the second quarter, and we would expect it to continue to be mid-single digits, really, for the rest of the year. So it's really kind of better than we expect because there's more European headwinds than we would have originally forecast.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: How much was your European business down in the quarter?
componenttext: How much was your European business down in the quarter?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: It was down 18% for us in total. About half of that is just due to currency though. So maybe 8% or 9% on an organic basis. Something to remember on that, Matt, is that does include the headwinds associated with the Gaz de France. So that's kind of $5 mill
componenttext: It was down 18% for us in total. About half of that is just due to currency though. So maybe 8% or 9% on an organic basis. Something to remember on that, Matt, is that does include the headwinds associated with the Gaz de France. So that's kind of $5 million. But even once you take that out, we saw a decline in Europe that was definitely mid-single digits.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012

componenttext: So on Sunquest, Brian, you talked about that there's a lot of whitespace. Can you talk about what that would look like? I mean, is it market share shift? Is it just -- it's just under-penetrated as far as the clinics and hospitals? Or is it geographies?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- we don't want to tip off other people to things that we think are available to us, but it would be safe to say that we think that they can continue to grow share at the expense of other people. We think people have been paying a lot of at
componenttext: Well, I think -- we don't want to tip off other people to things that we think are available to us, but it would be safe to say that we think that they can continue to grow share at the expense of other people. We think people have been paying a lot of attention to Electronic Health Records and companies that are in the EHR space. Here, again, we've picked out a niche that we think is unrelated to that activity, and this niche has got an opportunity, very high return, for people investing in this, in the hospital space and in the clinic space and in private care space. Basically, lab work is critical to every aspect of people diagnosing folks, and it happens in a variety of different places. We think we have the preeminent technology to do that, and we think we can make people more productive and more efficient in what they do when they do it. It has been hard, I think, the last couple of years to get the attention of hospitals that have had these mandates to do a variety of thing around health records. Now they get a chance to make an investment in things like this business, so it'll give them an actual return. So we think it's got pretty exciting growth. And these guys, they've brought in a new sales executive, a woman who we have great confidence in, that we think is going to drive better focus on organic growth. It's been a very high cash contributor, and it's the same old situation. Private equity has done, in this case, a really amazing job with this business versus what they acquired in '07, but it can grow more. And it has -- it does have opportunities for share gain and expansion around the world. I mean, this business, it doesn't do much in certain portions of the world, and we do a lot in other portions of the world than they do. It's also got an incredible development team in Bangalore, and that is very, very bullish for us.

componenttext: I think it ought to -- it'll grow its cash and EBITDA double digits. Revenue -- in this current year, forward revenue is probably going to go up by 10%. We would think, over time, that it grows revenue -- remember, it's got this massive recurring business, right? So its net new business won't look like a high number. So if you’ve got a couple hundred million of constant business, it could grow its net new business by 20%, and it wouldn't look like a big number on the core business, right? So it's not like looking at a cyclical company that's up and down and looking at various trends. This is just as -- it starts with its Q4 and then each quarter gets better all the time.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing what the lessons you learned from iTrade and how that played into both the negotiation for Sunquest but also integration, managing a software company and so forth.
componenttext: Brian, I'd be interested in hearing what the lessons you learned from iTrade and how that played into both the negotiation for Sunquest but also integration, managing a software company and so forth.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: We have a big advantage today versus when we first acquired iTrade, in that we have recently hired a chief architect for our technology businesses who's working in our software arena. We also have a software executive full time that's looking over our var
componenttext: We have a big advantage today versus when we first acquired iTrade, in that we have recently hired a chief architect for our technology businesses who's working in our software arena. We also have a software executive full time that's looking over our various software companies, and we have a medical executive, which we didn't have before, looking over the Medical scenario. So between the 2 new executives and one that's a domain expert in Medical, one that's a domain expert in software and the architectural person, the quality of our diligence that we're able to do on our own was a dramatic improvement. We have a much deeper understanding about source code and the ways in which development programs need to be done and measured, and we've got a deeper understanding about cost structures around development activity. And all those things are good. I think we also come to recognize that slightly lower organic growth rates in the software businesses really aren’t a problem because of the recurring revenue that they have inside them and the quality of the cash that they generate. I mean, to look at a company -- I think most people would look at us and say this is best-of-breed EBITDA margins, and yet, here, we're acquiring one that has twice the margins that we enjoy. So they are fundamentally different, and our executive leadership capability around them is better than ever.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify on the deferred revenues. You said that it refers to the maintenance side of it. Is that 2 years? It's pretty typical that you see in 2 years of maintenance fees. And are any of the licensing fees included in that deferred revenues, or
componenttext: And just to clarify on the deferred revenues. You said that it refers to the maintenance side of it. Is that 2 years? It's pretty typical that you see in 2 years of maintenance fees. And are any of the licensing fees included in that deferred revenues, or is it just maintenance?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the short answer is, nothing on the license fees, and the maintenance contracts and the deferred revenue are 2 slightly different things. So the maintenance agreements range anywhere from 1-year, 3-year, 5-years, some of them even 7-year agreements, be
componenttext: So the short answer is, nothing on the license fees, and the maintenance contracts and the deferred revenue are 2 slightly different things. So the maintenance agreements range anywhere from 1-year, 3-year, 5-years, some of them even 7-year agreements, because, of course, the customer would like to make sure that they have kind of the long-term commitment with Sunquest, and Sunquest likes having the long-term contracts. So -- but they don't pay for all 7 years or all 5 years upfront. So it's a 1-year payment, and that's what goes into the deferred revenue. So we would expect to see that deferred revenue build back up after the fair value adjustment, after 12 months to be back to normal-steady state.

componenttext: Well, you'll have to define new era. So it’s -- the lumpy area is alive and well for those activities. There are a lot of initiatives. There are a number of things that'll come out for bid. I think the longer we go with people learning more and more about our United Toll Systems technology, the more and more and more people recognize that it is dramatically superior to what other people have done for a long period of time, including ourselves. So the lead time for getting agencies to understand and see and test and kick tires around that is kind of long. But in terms of long-term growth vehicle, nobody has got a better mouse trap than us, and I don't think anybody is going to get one. So we like the long-term nature of the business, and we certainly like the second quarter. And we think the rest of the year will be fine.

componenttext: And just to put a little more color around that, Chris, for instance, the win in Harris County is not a conversion from a non-tolled to a tolled lane or a new road that's being constructed. So it's really just building out our maintenance and support capabilities with the team that we have rather than net new, if you will.

componenttext: Brian, could you just speak for 1 minute or 2 about the RF segment EBIT significant jump in the quarter on a growth rate that was slightly negative? Is that -- first of all, is that mix? Or secondly, is that -- and maybe, also, is that sustainable at that level as we move forward?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's very sustainable. One of the things, Richard, you might know, if you want to get in trouble at Roper, you come in from operations and you say, "Well, we had a mix variance." Okay, so we know exactly where it came from in every one of the busi
componenttext: I think it's very sustainable. One of the things, Richard, you might know, if you want to get in trouble at Roper, you come in from operations and you say, "Well, we had a mix variance." Okay, so we know exactly where it came from in every one of the businesses, and certainly, we have tightened up our execution in the TransCore toll business and have better margins as a result of that activity, which is a shout-out to a terrific work that's been done, really, by George McGraw in our Amtech business and some work that's been done in our ITS business. That said, software tends to grow at a faster clip than our friends do in the rest of the product measure of RF. And as it grows, it carries with it extraordinary margins compared to the product businesses.

componenttext: No, I don't believe so. So I mean, clearly, ITS has improved their operating performance and their margins, but we haven't changed the underlying economics of the fact that maintenance of toll and road services doesn't carry the same type of margin profile as our software businesses or as hardware for toll applications. So as we continue to do more on the toll lane maintenance and service side, we will have a -- I won't say mix, because Brian will kick me, but we will have a variance associated with the relative growth rate to those businesses.

componenttext: Well, we just don’t take out [ph] any SG&A to drive revenue growth. And so when you're largely selling direct and you got the best technologies of anybody and you've got solid gross margins, you get the leverage on incremental revenue. So we got some incremental revenue, we get the leverage.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't really know, Jeff. It's possible. I sure wouldn't rule against it. I know what we're willing to do. You never know what other people are willing to do. So -- and there's usually a bid-ask spread all the time when we're doing work. This transaction
componenttext: I don't really know, Jeff. It's possible. I sure wouldn't rule against it. I know what we're willing to do. You never know what other people are willing to do. So -- and there's usually a bid-ask spread all the time when we're doing work. This transaction with Sunquest demonstrates kind of how we act, right. So I mean, we started talking to these people in 2010, and we – I'll tell you, sometimes we'll give people ideas or whatever. We wonder about they’re going to do. I think these people have done just a spectacular job of taking advantage of some momentum that we thought could be available to them, and they've done that. So we have some transactions that are similar to this that we have been talking to people off and on about for several years. I think that depending on who owns the asset and what people think is going to happen between now and the end of the year around the tax structures, going into next year, you have higher levels of seller activity. If they believe nothing is going to change and they don't have capital gains that they're worried about, they may hold on. If, on the other hand, they think that getting a high percentage of something is better than a lower percentage of something else, we may close the valuation gap. I don't know. So, I think it's possible that we would do another transaction, probably not quite as large as $1.4 billion, however.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would bet not. But that brings up another topic. What are you thinking about on the divestiture side? Not naming names, of course, but clearly, the portfolio is changing. There's maybe some pieces of it that are not as core as they used to be. It's an i
componenttext: I would bet not. But that brings up another topic. What are you thinking about on the divestiture side? Not naming names, of course, but clearly, the portfolio is changing. There's maybe some pieces of it that are not as core as they used to be. It's an interesting juncture, right. I mean, your returns are so high, anything you divest is dilutive. But at a time when you've got maybe such accretive acquisition activity going on, perhaps there's an opportunity to mold the portfolio a little bit differently. Are you thinking that way at all? Is there any prospect for something leaving the portfolio in the next 6, 12 months?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, our core business is delivering a tremendous amount of cash. They've gotten dramatically better. Their cash returns are more than 50% better than they were like 5 years ago. They give us tremendous EPS performance because they don’t have the non-G
componenttext: Well, our core business is delivering a tremendous amount of cash. They've gotten dramatically better. Their cash returns are more than 50% better than they were like 5 years ago. They give us tremendous EPS performance because they don’t have the non-GAAP -- or amortization charges that lay against them. There is certainly an increasing inflection point where you look at this and say, "What about this situation?" We're in a marvelous place, where since we’ve maintained the autonomy at each one of these businesses, we can always decouple the business and not have any problem doing that. It's not like some other strategic that's got everything so embedded that one factory is making 5 items and one information system can't go with the business. So all our businesses are totally isolated and independent, and anyone could be spun-off to another party. I think people largely have some ideas about which things might become available. It’s kind of like the trade deadline, right, for Tuesday, so it depends who's willing to pay what. But we're not an active seller, but we have some assets that are probably more valuable to others than they are to us.

componenttext: Well, I mean, since the EBITDA excludes the effective amortization, I don't think it really impacts that. So on the EPS side, it definitely does include that, of course, always with the caveat it does not include the impact of the deferred revenue fair value accounting treatment.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to ask you about the Industrial Technology business and the Pump business, specifically. Another company recently recorded a substantial decline in orders is Gardner Denver, in the petroleum and industrial pump business. In that particular
componenttext: First, I wanted to ask you about the Industrial Technology business and the Pump business, specifically. Another company recently recorded a substantial decline in orders is Gardner Denver, in the petroleum and industrial pump business. In that particular business of theirs, orders were down 36% in the quarter. And in another division, they had a pressure pumping order decline of 17%. And you haven't seen anything like that, according to what you said. Do you compete with them? Or are you taking market share? Or just what is going on here? Because the 2 results are dramatically different.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the markets we're focused on are totally different for the most part than Gardner Denver. I mean, they're -- we do have dewatering pumps that Cornell makes, and those have certainly been used in the shale activity. Those have had strong growt
componenttext: Yes. I think the markets we're focused on are totally different for the most part than Gardner Denver. I mean, they're -- we do have dewatering pumps that Cornell makes, and those have certainly been used in the shale activity. Those have had strong growth. That growth is moderating, but it's not totally negative at all. That's a pretty small part of the overall enterprise. And our Roper Pump business continues to grow quite substantially. So I think -- gosh, I'm just not really at all close to Gardner Denver, but I think they're building a lot of stuff that maybe is going into rental and platforms and that stuff. We have some rental business with Cornell, but it's not the core component of what we do. So we're still making pumps for waste water activity, agricultural irrigation and those kind of things.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And second question is on the orders for RF Technology. TransCore, on July 19, said they were awarded the Texas Department of Transportation statewide toll system integration and maintenance contract, replacing one of your competitors, and you get t
componenttext: Okay. And second question is on the orders for RF Technology. TransCore, on July 19, said they were awarded the Texas Department of Transportation statewide toll system integration and maintenance contract, replacing one of your competitors, and you get to replace all of their systems, plus add your own to new systems that come on board. So you didn't mentioned this, I don't believe. It seems to be a different project than the one you talked about in RF Technology. Could you talk about this new TransCore business that was announced July 19?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alex. And you're correct. It's not the same one. The HCTRA business for the Harris County is the one that we talked about. What you're referring to is the TxDOT, which operates a different set of toll lanes across the state of Texas. And you're righ
componenttext: Sure, Alex. And you're correct. It's not the same one. The HCTRA business for the Harris County is the one that we talked about. What you're referring to is the TxDOT, which operates a different set of toll lanes across the state of Texas. And you're right. We'll be providing them with software and maintenance activity. More of a -- it's an indefinite quantity, indefinite timing, so it's an IDIQ type of contract. And so it doesn't have the same immediate booking that the more definite executions for the Harris County does. So we expect the Texas contract to –- sorry the TxDOT contract to add, oh, maybe $30 million over the next 3 years but at a timing that may be a little bit lumpy as they decide on when to update and when to upgrade the -- their specific lanes.
