headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions, I guess, maybe a little bit of follow up on that last one. But both the -- what we think of it as maybe the shorter-terms businesses, the industrial tech and the energy systems business, just in general, had -- the book-to-bill in the qu
componenttext: Just 2 questions, I guess, maybe a little bit of follow up on that last one. But both the -- what we think of it as maybe the shorter-terms businesses, the industrial tech and the energy systems business, just in general, had -- the book-to-bill in the quarter for both of those business was below one and certainly, below a seasonal pickup, seasonal expectation. And is that -- is the way you're thinking about that, that the damage was done kind of maybe in the month of August. And again, shorter-terms businesses, but we saw a recovery in September?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's -- I mean, that's generally the case, Rick, but also, as we look at the book-to-bill ratio inside the company, the major drivers are really are project-driven businesses, not the things that we're more booked and turned inside of a sho
componenttext: Yes, I think that's -- I mean, that's generally the case, Rick, but also, as we look at the book-to-bill ratio inside the company, the major drivers are really are project-driven businesses, not the things that we're more booked and turned inside of a shorter window. And as you know, we always keep a close eye on some of our, as we think of them, our leading indicator businesses, our Strewers [ph] Material Tests business, our Janisco [ph] business, serving a number of process industries, as well as a couple of the other sensor and businesses and energy. And those continue to perform well. Their book-to-bill ratio was solid in the quarter. And other than -- August was tough, but September was better for them. So I think that, that commentary that Brian was talking about is largely around the book and ship businesses than we have the project timing things that will overlay against that.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one follow -- my follow-up. There was some -- I think, Brian, you had mentioned that there was some project activity the RF Tech, the segment that was pushed from maybe the second half of this year into the first half of next year. Is
componenttext: Okay. And then just one follow -- my follow-up. There was some -- I think, Brian, you had mentioned that there was some project activity the RF Tech, the segment that was pushed from maybe the second half of this year into the first half of next year. Is it -- where did that fall? Is that the Tolling business, or where is that? .

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Toll stuff in Texas. We had a very large contract that we want in the second quarter, and we expect that we would have been doing some delivery by now. And there are some things going on with the holding authority that they're moving things around, and th
componenttext: Toll stuff in Texas. We had a very large contract that we want in the second quarter, and we expect that we would have been doing some delivery by now. And there are some things going on with the holding authority that they're moving things around, and they're not ready to deliver yet. So that's getting pushed out to probably first quarter of next year, tiny chance we might get a little bit of that here in the fourth quarter. But we're assuming it's more of a 2013. That actually did benefit to us, because it helps like any falloff that might occur in 2013 in some of these other areas.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: This is just -- when we were preparing our guidance for the third quarter, we were thinking we'd get $5 million to $10 million out of this particular project. And we didn't get anything that we -- that's why we're not at all worried about our book-to-bill, 9.96 [ph].

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Heard the comments on tolling being a little stronger next year, but just trying to think about how to frame up the segment in RF, longer-term. It looks like maybe the traffic and tolling side is kind of a flatline business. You get some growth out of the
componenttext: Heard the comments on tolling being a little stronger next year, but just trying to think about how to frame up the segment in RF, longer-term. It looks like maybe the traffic and tolling side is kind of a flatline business. You get some growth out of the software side, so it kind of low growth longer-term, but a margin melt up on mix shift. Is that  -- anything wrong with that thinking?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: If that's what happens, then you're right with respect to the margin benefit. I'm not at all going where you are as far as toll and traffic being a flat business. They have a lot of opportunities in front of them. They have the number of solutions that th
componenttext: If that's what happens, then you're right with respect to the margin benefit. I'm not at all going where you are as far as toll and traffic being a flat business. They have a lot of opportunities in front of them. They have the number of solutions that they continue to deploy. People around the world are looking for ways to reduce congestion and generate revenue from their existing infrastructure. I think that the trends in their business are favorable. It's a question [ph] of whether austerity overwhelms that, but I don't think it does. So I'm not going where you are as far as it being a flat business.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Brian, you mentioned some dynamics with China, Japan and Taiwan. Can you talk a little bit more about that, and specifically how it's impacting your business or how you expect it to impact your business?
componenttext: Brian, you mentioned some dynamics with China, Japan and Taiwan. Can you talk a little bit more about that, and specifically how it's impacting your business or how you expect it to impact your business?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really in a more on a academic and research arena, where we have -- a lot of our sales ultimately were going to China but through Japanese and Taiwanese distribution or technology companies. Certainly, the political situation that, that has esc
componenttext: Well, it's really in a more on a academic and research arena, where we have -- a lot of our sales ultimately were going to China but through Japanese and Taiwanese distribution or technology companies. Certainly, the political situation that, that has escalated on the revenue [ph] basis between Japanese and China is less than helpful for people. So we are -- we were curious as to whether that's going to get resolved anytime soon but that makes us a little more cautious about some of our end markets in that particular area. But remember, Matt, as you know it's a very small part of the overall company, but we do like to point out things. It seemed to be [ph], and that is a tough [indiscernible], we have not heard prior to the third quarter from people that I think are insightful, so just alluding [ph] you that it could be a headwind.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then I wanted to spend just a moment on your CCC business. It sounds like you have excellent visibility there, so please -- I mean, first, correct me if I'm wrong in thinking that. And then I want to make sure I understand what dictates kind o
componenttext: Got it. And then I wanted to spend just a moment on your CCC business. It sounds like you have excellent visibility there, so please -- I mean, first, correct me if I'm wrong in thinking that. And then I want to make sure I understand what dictates kind of the momentum and timing around your field service activity? And is this a business that is going to require some incremental internal investment near term?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: It doesn't really need -- its people related, so it's just a matter of -- we have seen an opportunity to expand our field service business for a lot of reasons. The people want to focus on capital equipment, which is very lumpy, and they're leaving behind
componenttext: It doesn't really need -- its people related, so it's just a matter of -- we have seen an opportunity to expand our field service business for a lot of reasons. The people want to focus on capital equipment, which is very lumpy, and they're leaving behind an opportunity to deal a lot of field service in these arena, which we're picking up at a fast pace. So that requires a little bit of investment for people, but not massive one. They are expensive people, because of where they're physically located. And then in terms of the order processes, they're always lumpy in CCC. There's not anything you could do about that. People order their technology from us with a long lead time, so it's not unusual to get an 18-month out order. We only book things that are shippable within 12 months, so we don't create a massive backlog and stuff that don't hit our next forward 12 months of activity. And we have a very strong knowledge about who we're working with in various CCC projects and what the likely outcome is going to be. Those tend not to be so much what equity projects. I mean you're kind of working with somebody from a design viewpoint, where you're likely get the order. We would not lose many orders that we're involved.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, one quick one. Captcha's [ph] decision to open source their technology, does that do anything to the tolling space at all?
componenttext: And then lastly, one quick one. Captcha's [ph] decision to open source their technology, does that do anything to the tolling space at all?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, I don't really think that's a change versus the status quo. I mean, those are -- I believe our understanding to that is that it's a number of patents that already expired. And frankly, we've been in the leading edge of an awful lot of those interopera
componenttext: No, I don't really think that's a change versus the status quo. I mean, those are -- I believe our understanding to that is that it's a number of patents that already expired. And frankly, we've been in the leading edge of an awful lot of those interoperable solutions. We were the first people to -- and TransCore we're the first people to  introduce the multi-protocol readers, so a tolling authority could have the opportunity of having their choice of the best tag technology, and we'd be able to read anyone's available. So I don't think that, that recent announcement really affects the competitive dynamic. I think it's just a reflection of today's environment already.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was away from the call for a minute, so I don't know if this was asked, but you mentioned in your opening remarks that August gets down a bit, and you were concerned and then things strengthened. What's the reason for that?  That's an odd fluctuation.
componenttext: I was away from the call for a minute, so I don't know if this was asked, but you mentioned in your opening remarks that August gets down a bit, and you were concerned and then things strengthened. What's the reason for that?  That's an odd fluctuation.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean that's -- I think August was an aberration. When you screw it out, the third quarter was maybe 2% below what we would have hoped for and we actually know that, that was more project oriented. But in the middle of the quarter, we were apprehen
componenttext: Well, I mean that's -- I think August was an aberration. When you screw it out, the third quarter was maybe 2% below what we would have hoped for and we actually know that, that was more project oriented. But in the middle of the quarter, we were apprehensive, because we thought well, maybe there is some kind of falloff. And we have really seen that. So we're kind of back to a reasonable September and a reasonable July.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's been an economic falloff since then that's pretty dramatic going into the fourth quarter here with a lot of companies reporting weakness and things below expectations. But you experienced that apparently in August and then recovered from it.
componenttext: There's been an economic falloff since then that's pretty dramatic going into the fourth quarter here with a lot of companies reporting weakness and things below expectations. But you experienced that apparently in August and then recovered from it.

componenttext: Well, I think if I remember, only a few of our businesses are going to bounce around like that. I mean, the medical business is -- are more secular in nature. Most of  our [indiscernible] lumpy side projects is pretty secular in nature would grow. So if you have a falloff in industrial energy, it's almost always rebounds in the fourth quarter in energy anyway. We'll have a lot of things that people want to invest within our budget.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And another thing I would add to that is that -- I mean, we don't report on -- there are some companies that actually report their orders and their activity on a monthly basis, because they're really better gauge and more tied to near-term macro-economic
componenttext: And another thing I would add to that is that -- I mean, we don't report on -- there are some companies that actually report their orders and their activity on a monthly basis, because they're really better gauge and more tied to near-term macro-economic activity. That's never really been our business profiles. So we're not really a good indicator for the macro world because of the niche markets that we serve and many of the things that have the secular growth tailwinds that Brian was talking about. So I think that -- I know a reason that we've mentioned it was a little bit of what we normally see, but we're not looking at month-to-month activity or week-to-week activity. We're not that type of macro business.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, KC, and thank you, all, for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Jason
componenttext:
Thank you, KC, and thank you, all, for joining us this morning as we discuss the results of our third quarter. Joining me this morning is Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Soni, Vice President and Controller; and Jason Conley, who heads our Planning  and Investor Relations for us. 
Earlier this morning, we issued a press release announcing our financial results. The press release also includes replay information for today's call. We prepared slides to accompany today's call, which are available through the webcast and also available on our website at www.roperind.com. 
Now if you please turn to slide 2. We begin with our Safe Harbor statement. During the course of today's call, we will be making forward-looking statements which are subject to risks and uncertainties, as described on this page, and as detailed in our SEC filings. You should listen to today's call in the context of that information. 
Now if you'll please turn to Slide 3. Today, we will be discussing our income statement results for the quarter, primarily on a non-GAAP basis. A full reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures was included in our press release this morning and is also a part of this presentation, which is available on our website. 
The difference between the GAAP and the non-GAAP measures as we'll be talking about them today is really made up of the following 3 discrete items: First, a fair value adjustment to acquire deferred revenue at Sunquest. For the quarter, this impact was $3.1 million to revenue and operating profit. This adjustment represents revenue that, absent our acquisition, Sunquest would have recognized. We believe showing our results on this basis provides additional insight into the ongoing and recurring results of the business.  Second, we incurred $6.3 million of acquisition-related costs specific to Sunquest.  Finally, we recorded a $1 million noncash charge to earnings in the quarter for the early termination of our credit facility.  We believe discussing our results, excluding these 3 discrete items, provide investors with additional insight and improves understanding of the trends of our business. 
And now if you'll please turn to Slide 4, I'll turn the call over to Brian Jellison, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer. And after his prepared remarks, we'll take questions from our telephone participants. Brian?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good morning, everyone. We'll go through the Q3 enterprise financial results, which were really quite good, look at the segment detail and then take a look at our Q4 guidance and what the implications are for the full year. I'll give you
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good morning, everyone. We'll go through the Q3 enterprise financial results, which were really quite good, look at the segment detail and then take a look at our Q4 guidance and what the implications are for the full year. I'll give you a summary, and then take questions from people. 
So next slide.  We look at the Q3 enterprise financial results, we had an all-time third quarter record for almost everything that counts, most orders in the history, highest level of revenue sales, biggest level of backlog, $1 billion almost again. Net earnings were an all-time record as well as EBITDA and cash flow both on an operating and a free cash flow basis. 
Our revenue was up 5%, but that included a $0.02 headwind on foreign exchange, otherwise revenue would have been up 7%, with organic growth up 3%. If you look at the operating margin expansion, it was really remarkable at 220 basis points, up from what already is the best-in-class operating margins to 25.7%. 
Our operating leverage was kind of beyond remarkable, and I have to put this in the spectacular category. If you look at incremental sales and incremental OP, operating leverage in the quarter was 67%. 
This really is a tribute to the nimble business model that we have with break-even analysis and various analysis. When we get to the end, we'll kind of talk about year-to-date, just how well our operating leverage is going, and why that's so important for the fourth quarter and in 2013. 
Our EBITDA in the quarter was $231 million. EBITDA margin was also up 220 basis points to 30.8% at the enterprise level. Our GAAP operating cash flow is $205 million or 27% of revenue, and it's also up 23% from the third quarter last year. And our diluted earnings per share were $1.24, up from $1.12 in the prior year.  Cash conversion was spectacular. We'll talk about that when we get into the balance sheet and cash flow, but really exceptional margin expansion throughout the enterprise. 
Next slide. If we look at the income statement in Q3, I start out with orders being basically flat to the prior year, up $1 million. And the reason for that is in -- we've had a lot of variability in book-to-bill over the last 2.5 years almost always due to just project pushouts coming in, plus we have that difficult gap to broad comp [ph], finally goes away in the fourth quarter. Year-to-date book-to-bill is the same as it generally is, and these quarterly variances we don't read much into, as long they're only driven by what happened with project bookings, which we rarely have any control over. So orders were probably better than they really look in this chart. 
Revenue at $751 million was up 3% organically. Our gross profit moved from 53.7% up to 55.9%, a remarkable 220 basis points improvement.  And our operating income went up from the same 23.5% to 25.7%, another 220 basis points with that 67% incremental leverage. 
Tax rate was worse in the third quarter than last year. Our cost is $0.03 a share compared to last year's baseline numbers because we had fewer FIN 48 roll offs than the third quarter of this year than we did last year. And our reported $1.24 includes about $2 million of restructuring expense in energy that would have added $0.01 if we would have excluded that to hit $1.25. 
Sort of a note to -- July was quite okay, and September was strong with August being kind of down within the quarter. We'll talk more about that when we get to the segment. So we actually feel better today than we did in the middle of the quarter. Our Q3 operating reviews were much more optimistic when we held those in October than our mid-quarter discussions in August. 
Next slide. Our EBITDA growth trend continues as you see. Our Q3 trailing 12 months EBITDA back in 2010 was $585 million. We've added $287 million to that to reach $872 million on a trailing 12-month basis now. And questions that we always get are, "How are you going to be able to hold this 25% EBITDA margins?" And our answer to our people and -- say everybody is, "We're not going to settle for 25% EBITDA margins. We don't have to settle for that kind of a number." And here you see, we're up another 390 basis points in the last 2 years to 29.8% EBITDA on a trailing 12-month basis, 49% over the last 2 years. 
Next slide. On our Q3 cash flow is -- it's just simply spectacular. $205 million of operating cash flow represents 27% of revenue. Our $197 million of free cash flow represents 26% of revenue. It's the 15th consecutive year where free cash flow has exceeded net earnings. You can see we've moved up here from $437 million of trailing cash flow in 2010's third quarter to $618 million now.  
Year-to-date, our cash conversion is quite strong, and will have an even stronger performance in the fourth quarter.  Our cash conversion in the third quarter was 176% on a GAAP basis. It was 166% on a non-GAAP basis. And all these numbers are all-time record numbers of cash flow. 
Next slide. If we look at the Q3 balance sheet, you'll see even after absorbing the $1.4 billion acquisition of Sunquest in August, we still have an exceptionally strong balance sheet. Cash has improved. Our undrawn revolver is less than it was -- or at about same as it was, down a little bit. 
Our trailing 12-month EBITDA that we're showing here at $779 million at September a year ago, $872 million now, that excludes any pro forma from Sunquest which would add dramatically to that number.  So when you look at the statistics around gross debt to cap, they're 37%. If we did net debt to net cap, it could be 32.8%.  
Our gross debt to EBITDA is only 2.4 and if you pro forma Sunquest, of course, it would be much closer to 2.  We really have ample capacity to do any kind of transaction that we'd like to do, and we still see a number of things in the pipeline that we're discussing look attractive to us. 
Next slide. We get into specifics around segment details here. Next slide.  In the third quarter, our segment performance was, again, remarkable. Across the board in all the segments, you can see gross margins at the 52%, 52%, 55% and 66%. And you can see EBITDA margins within each segment, they were all above 30%. And all of those are just leading us with a tremendous amount of flexibility with our balance sheet and ability to reinvest for growth in our existing business. 
Next slide. We start with RF Technology, which is our largest percentage of revenue at 29% within the quarter. You can see on an organic basis I had a modest fall off, 0.8% in revenue, which was really due to a specific pushout in a job we have and assets that we expected to start to deliver in the third quarter, which looks like it might even move in the first half of next year, but we had great margin expansion. As you can see, operating profit was up 10%, and operating profit margins were up 280 basis points. 
We had some project activity that we expected to come in at -- really cost us between $5 million and $10 million against what we thought was possible that we were kind of assuming is going to come in to the first half of next year. Some chance that it could move in to the fourth quarter of this year, some of that. 
Overall, the growth is really amassed by 5% headwind from Q3 projects last year that were unusual,  the onetime install trend [ph] and very large installation project that Miami University received. Our SaaS-based businesses continue to grow, in this quarter led by our Freight Matching subscriber base increase, which was quite substantial. 
These pushouts that we have had, we have very high confidence that they're going to be entering our order book within the next 6 months. So once again, we feel a bit better about orders than that book-to-bill flatline number looks like. 
In the fourth quarter, we have growth expected to improve in our toll and traffic project activity based on the timing that we have. And we know that our margin expansion as the SaaS business continues to grow as a portion of the business will continue to give us improved margins. That important job in the Middle East with one of  the airports, most of the other things we have going on, unfortunately, we just can't talk about it yet because they're not public. 
Next slide. On Industrial Technology, we had organic growth in Industrial Technology of 10%. So we continue to perform frankly better than our expectations. It did have 3% of foreign-currency headwind. The operating margin there is just amazing. I mean, our operating profit in the quarter was 30.8%. That's an all-time operating profit margin, which was driven by terrific execution, as people are prepared to take out costs if there's any kind of downturn and just on top of every one of their variances. 
The Neptune Toronto rollout continued, we're now about 25% complete with several years ahead of us. We have over 100,000 units installed in the field in Canada now.  Our Fluid Handling business remained very strong in the quarter. The oil shale activity that we have around directional drilling will simulate technology there, offset the expected reduced demand we had on pressure pumps and the natural gas application. So that really came in stronger than we might have guessed. 
And our Material Test business continued to grow both in North America and actually had modest improvement in Europe. And Europe, as a whole, for the enterprise, not just Industrial Technology, actually, on organic basis, was flat in the third quarter, where many people are reporting organic negative growth. 
In the fourth quarter, you'll see our outstanding margins in Industrial we expect to continue. We do have some growth comparisons that are going to become difficult for us in the fourth quarter. At Neptune, we get a benefit possibly from modest improvement in housing starts. However, in the fourth quarter, that tends not to help out much. That's going to have to be more of -- once you have or turn into better climate activity in 2013, but that's going to be offset by a 4-year-long program we've had with an individual customer that's rolling off. And that's going to be about a $5 million revenue headwind within the quarter.  And then we have, of course, the follow-up in shale activity for pressure pumps in the natural gas application. But the rest of the activity, Industrial looks strong in the quarter. 
Next slide. The Energy Systems & Controls segment. It had organic growth of 4%, but we've got of course, being generally a lot of non-U.S. activity there. FX sort of is like 3%. We had very solid margin expansion despite taking a $2 million charge in 2 of our businesses in energy for a little bit of retention. And they'll cost us $0.01 a share. It's certainly good investment, might be a tiny bit more of that even in fourth quarter.  Revenue was up 5%. Operating profit was up double digits at 11%. And the operating profit margin came in at 27.1%, up 140 basis points. 
The Compressor Controls business, which has always been project oriented and still is project oriented is growing its field service activity at such a fast cliff that the field service is beginning to change our book-to-bill ratio dynamics in the segment, because the field service is, while it's not subscription-based, it certainly is a continuous input around activity. And then kind of a fresh benefit is that we had nuclear plant inspections added to grow third quarter, which is the first time we could say something positive about VTech in a long time.  Refinery instrumentation demand though remain very weak, and that -- a lot of that's a European business activity. 
In the fourth quarter, we expect to have strong seasonal Q4 demand, and the nuclear inspection activity is going to continue as it’s already scheduled. And we expect to get margin expansion from both growth and some of the benefits of these cost actions that we've already taken. 
Next slide. In the fourth quarter, sorry -- in the Medical and Scientific Imaging business, you could see here -- this is where you're beginning to see the initial affect of Sunquest coming in. It'll be -- you'll see that in a much larger way, of course, in the fourth quarter and into 2013. But even given that, you can see revenue in the quarter was up 12%, operating profit was up 28%, and the operating profit margin was up 340 basis points to 28.1%.  Now acquisitions are 16% of that. We had actually a negative organic growth of 3% in the segment, because of the academic research markets being down double digits. 
The good news for us is that medical already represents more than 2/3 of the revenue in the segment and that Medical is approaching much higher percentage in total operating profit in the segment as the Imaging business has become far, far less important to our overall portfolio. 
The Sunquest acquisition's is completed. Off to a very good start around administrative and financial processes. It's absolutely been the easiest transition we've ever had with any acquisition in our history. We have very gifted organization of employees, not only from a marketplace and customer delivery perspective at Sunquest, but the administrative functions and processes are the best that we've seen in an acquisition any time in our history. 
We have mid single-digit organic growth in medical, driven mostly by OEM systems revenue out of our Northern Digital acquisition a couple of years ago and Verathon's GlidesScope demand, which continues to be quite substantial.  I mentioned the weakness that we had in the academic research markets, which primarily impact the camera businesses, but photonics in general down double digit. 
In the fourth quarter, those research markets are going to remain weak, but we finally lapped them, so the comparisons become easier. And some of those businesses actually have increased revenue in the fourth quarter over both the third quarter and the fourth quarter of the year ago. 
We'll have continued strength in the medical platform. We get the full quarter benefit as Sunquest acquisition coming in there. And quite a nice boost from Northern Digital on OEM products that we've introduced and arrangements that we've made with the important large brand key manufacturers. We get a little bit of benefit from our extension acquisition, which is getting nested inside Northern Digital and then a modest continued improvement out of Verathon.  We will have very dramatic margin expansion in the fourth quarter, as we get the benefit of some things we've done in the core businesses and then the much better margins that'll be added to us as a result of Sunquest. 
One little noise factor that we've seen in the administrative and the academic research market is around some people concerned about China, with the Japanese and Taiwanese customers who frequently export there. And the noise around that is something that's hard to calibrate, but does appear to be real. 
Next slide. So here we'll talk about the 2012 guidance and where we stand. Next slide. We look at the full year we've -- initiated a full year non-GAAP diluted earnings per share number of $4.91 to $4.97. This raises the midpoint to $4.94. The midpoint had been $4.92 on a $4 to $5 number. 
Last year, our non-GAAP EPS was $4.29 a share. Remember, we had a remeasurement of gain of a $0.05 that brought the GAAP numbers from $4.34 down to $4.29, so that midpoint represents more than a 15% increase in EPS but of course the real story for us is going to be the catch. 
Our Q4 non-GAAP DEPS number we've established at $1.43 to $1.49. That gives us an improvement over last year's $1.23, somewhere between 16% and 21% in the fourth quarter. That midpoint of $1.46 is higher than consensus. And if you only get the midpoint, you'd be about 19% above last year on a non-GAAP DEPS measurement and again, cash flow being more important, in our opinion, than the DEPS measurement. 
Very exciting thing about the fourth quarter for us is that we're going to hit a new milestone for Roper that we've never seen before, where in the fourth quarter our EBITDA will exceed $250 million in the quarter, meaning we'll have in excess of $1 billion EBITDA run rate in the fourth quarter, which we're quite excited about. 
Next slide. If we look at the summary of activity in the third quarter, you can see that we've got demonstrated all these records of delayed orders revenue backlog, net earnings, EBITDA and cash flow.  We had across-the-board margin expansion in all 4 segments, which was very comforting for us, given the uncertain economic environment. 
Organic revenue was plus 3%. We would have liked to -- seen that a little bit higher, but when you adjust for the Technolog gap fronts and the core and a little bit of pushout in tolling, I guess it was better than most. 
Gross margins spectacular, hit 55.9%. Our operating margins at 25.7%. Year-to-date if you take the first 9 months and you look at the revenue, you look at the OP, you do that calculation and you'll see that our operating leverage throughout the year is now above 50% of revenue. 
Now we used to talk about 25% to 30% leverage out of EBITDA, and then occasionally, we'd get up to say, well, maybe 305, maybe 35%. My goodness, it's above 50% throughout the entire year at this point.
 
Our free cash flow of $197 million was 26% of revenue. I don't think there's many people that could point to stuff like that. 
Sunquest we said very smooth transition, lots of exciting opportunities. We're already looking at some bolt-on things in that arena and doing some things we think will have big payoffs for 2013. 
Our balance sheet remains very strong. We have ample capacity to continue to invest in transactions. We've got not only a record year that we know will deliver in the 2012 year, but I think we can now say we're positioned for another record year in 2013. 
So with that, we'd like to open it up to questions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Brian, maybe first question, just pick up right where you left off. You bravely grossed 2013 in a pretty uncertain environment. Obviously you've got the Sunquest accretion, which would basically get you there, but if you think about the other businesses,
componenttext: Brian, maybe first question, just pick up right where you left off. You bravely grossed 2013 in a pretty uncertain environment. Obviously you've got the Sunquest accretion, which would basically get you there, but if you think about the other businesses, could you elaborate a little bit on kind of the trends you're expecting as you exit the year into next year?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we're not going to provide any real guidance until we've closed out the year. We generally do that with the year-end report, but I do think we were really taken by the -- we have a very formal quarterly review process. We talked to everyone o
componenttext: Yes. I think we're not going to provide any real guidance until we've closed out the year. We generally do that with the year-end report, but I do think we were really taken by the -- we have a very formal quarterly review process. We talked to everyone of our P&L people. And when we talked to them in August, we were actually down 9% in orders in August, and we were up late July and September, they were positive, obviously, or we wouldn't have the kind of performance you saw. And people were really apprehensive, I guess, and were -- that kind of behind DEPS, real people aren't worried about that all of the customer contacts relatively favorable. Europe's performed  a little better than we might have expected. The industrial business is the 10% organic growth in the third quarter, which is kind of comforting. We know what our challenges are in 2013, we’ll have some struggling activity unless housing starts picked up in Neptune that we need to overcome. But our toll and traffic businesses are going to be more robust next year than they have been. The medical scenario is going to be better. We have some great clarity around various things we're doing there. The CBORD's going to win a major northeastern university that we can't yet announced. It's a very important large opportunity for us. We have some things that are going on in projects that we know are going to come to fruition. So we -- all these things that are negative, we kind of have those scoped out in our opinion, unless there's some kind of much more precipitous fall off. And so we do feel more comfortable, I would say, going into 2013 than we have in any time this year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you elaborate a little bit more on what you see on the scientific and research side. You indicated the comp is easier in Q4, but do you have some thoughts on what sequester looks like for the business, for example, if it happens next year
componenttext: Great. And could you elaborate a little bit more on what you see on the scientific and research side. You indicated the comp is easier in Q4, but do you have some thoughts on what sequester looks like for the business, for example, if it happens next year? And what actions you might take?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we are taking some actions, but I don't think that the sequester would have much effect, because these are not really defense-related businesses. They're really research applications going mostly to university markets. I think that the U.S. is a fai
componenttext: Well, we are taking some actions, but I don't think that the sequester would have much effect, because these are not really defense-related businesses. They're really research applications going mostly to university markets. I think that the U.S. is a fairly small part of where those businesses serve. It's less than 1/3 of their revenue. So the sequester wouldn't have any effect as it relates to Europe and Asia, which is where the lion’s share of our revenue, where those camera businesses resides. The other thing is that they are, of course, better than other people's businesses. They're -- the worst portion of the margin side of our OP in the company. So if they're down, they don't have kind of negative spin. It's not quite having any of the other businesses have negative variances. So they're really getting to the point where they have very little effect on the overall enterprise.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, and I'll pass the call.  Since you were kind enough to give us a specific August order number in that number of down 9%, can you tell us what September was? And what you're seeing in October?
componenttext: And then just finally, and I'll pass the call.  Since you were kind enough to give us a specific August order number in that number of down 9%, can you tell us what September was? And what you're seeing in October?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: With a gifted statistician such as yourself, we’ll leave that to you to back into it. They were modestly favorable. Our overall health in the year, by the way, is 101, and so we're preparing for all this. We're looking at some cash [ph] as you know. In
componenttext: With a gifted statistician such as yourself, we’ll leave that to you to back into it. They were modestly favorable. Our overall health in the year, by the way, is 101, and so we're preparing for all this. We're looking at some cash [ph] as you know. In the last 5 or 6 quarters, we've been all over the map. We used to say that our book-to-bill would be 0.97% to 1.03%.  And so certainly, on a trailing basis, we're right in that sweet spot, but we've had a number of quirks in the last 6 where we've been sort of outside the margin, and so the projects stopped -- if we stop reporting orders, we wouldn't have to waste time talking about it.  But things are fine, they're going to continue to be good.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if you can talk about the medical segment, much higher operating profit than I think a lot of us had thought. How much of that is really due to Sunquest? And then also, did you have some pretty impressive cost actions? I mean, I know medica
componenttext: Okay. And then if you can talk about the medical segment, much higher operating profit than I think a lot of us had thought. How much of that is really due to Sunquest? And then also, did you have some pretty impressive cost actions? I mean, I know medical now above 2/3, but still 1/3 of the business is down double digits. To have margins expand that dramatically is pretty good. Can you dive down to that a little more?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I do I think you're right as far as the relative mix that we continue to grow with the higher-margin areas. Sunquest comes in above the company average operating profit margin. So that's given us a little bit of tailwind but even absent that, we sti
componenttext: Well, I do I think you're right as far as the relative mix that we continue to grow with the higher-margin areas. Sunquest comes in above the company average operating profit margin. So that's given us a little bit of tailwind but even absent that, we still saw margin expansion in the segment as we continue to grow in medical versus the lower-margin camera businesses. And the nice thing about those -- at least one of the nice things I think about those camera businesses is they do have variable cost structure, so there isn't a large amount of fixed costs that need to have restructuring actions, so they're able to flex some of their operating expenses revenue.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Deane Dray with Citi.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: We'd like to get some color regarding the restructuring actions taken in energy. You said there was a couple of projects, but -- and then suggest that you could do some more in the fourth quarter. Maybe can you expand on that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's largely severance-related actions. It was right at $2 million in the quarter. Once again, with the asset -- with this model, we don't really have the larger restructuring charges that take an awful lot of time to a, implement and b, realize th
componenttext: Yes. That's largely severance-related actions. It was right at $2 million in the quarter. Once again, with the asset -- with this model, we don't really have the larger restructuring charges that take an awful lot of time to a, implement and b, realize the benefits from, so those are severance-related actions with the couple of the businesses.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then Brian, I know you can't name names, but your comment about CBORD having a big northeast university win, these are always pretty important, and especially if you are displacing an incumbent. So maybe just give us a color -- you said that yo
componenttext: Great. And then Brian, I know you can't name names, but your comment about CBORD having a big northeast university win, these are always pretty important, and especially if you are displacing an incumbent. So maybe just give us a color -- you said that you can regarding the context of the win. What the opportunity was, the value that CBORD is bringing that the incumbent was not able to provide.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think this is somebody we've been working with for a while, and this is much larger rollout than what normally be the case in terms of the size, which would be apparent when we finally get around to announcing it, because it's not a small campus en
componenttext: Yes. I think this is somebody we've been working with for a while, and this is much larger rollout than what normally be the case in terms of the size, which would be apparent when we finally get around to announcing it, because it's not a small campus environment. And lot of -- there's going to be a lot of connectivity point. We continue to grow at the expense of the competitor in this arena. And anyone that's close to those market spaces know that we've been gaining share and expect to continue to gain share, because our folks are really focused on this space and are compromised with other possible things that this one competitor seems to be involved with. So it's really a beneficial competitive environment, if you will, for CBORD that they're seizing on. And we continue to beef up our delivery capability at CBORD. We had quite a bit of talent in the project management arena. We have promoted somebody into the key role there. And we're quite happy with the way they're focused. I think our new Software Executive and we have a Business Development Chief Architect that can help people think creatively about how to expand their existing product offerings as well. So I think it's going to be a long-term continuing contributor to the company.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And with that piece, just in terms of timing on that order, would that be in a -- would that be a summer time delivery? That's typically when CBORD does those transactions.
componenttext: And with that piece, just in terms of timing on that order, would that be in a -- would that be a summer time delivery? That's typically when CBORD does those transactions.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's still in our future to determine exactly what the rollout and the implementation schedule will be, because there are different parts of the CBORD project. There will be the software portion which, of course, that's a larger occurring n
componenttext: Yes, I think that's still in our future to determine exactly what the rollout and the implementation schedule will be, because there are different parts of the CBORD project. There will be the software portion which, of course, that's a larger occurring nature to that. And then also, in many cases, security systems, lab installation that has to be scheduled around other activity in the campus environment. So I think implementation schedule is still in front of us to be able to determine that with the customer.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Steve Tusa with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Steve Tusa with JPMorgan.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Really impressive margin results, RF Tech, up 300 basis points versus last year. Could you just maybe parse through the dynamics there, and what drove that?
componenttext: Really impressive margin results, RF Tech, up 300 basis points versus last year. Could you just maybe parse through the dynamics there, and what drove that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. A couple of different things. One, very good tag ship, that's what always helps our toll and traffic business, but also the addition of -- and the growth in our software businesses. They have a lot of recurring revenue, but they also come in general
componenttext: Sure. A couple of different things. One, very good tag ship, that's what always helps our toll and traffic business, but also the addition of -- and the growth in our software businesses. They have a lot of recurring revenue, but they also come in generally with a little better than the margin performance in our toll and traffic, and particularly the project side of our toll and traffic business. And so it's a combination of mix, plus also some cost actions and some other things that we had that were more expensive last year than they are this year. So we've had that tailwind through the first 3 quarters and expect that to continue into the fourth as well.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Europe was down, I guess, 20% in Energy in the second quarter. Can you maybe talk about how those dynamics change in third quarter? Has there been any kind of change in customer behavior? Any problems in financing or credit terms, anything like that?
componenttext: Europe was down, I guess, 20% in Energy in the second quarter. Can you maybe talk about how those dynamics change in third quarter? Has there been any kind of change in customer behavior? Any problems in financing or credit terms, anything like that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, the things that we're delivering are not highly expensive. They're really -- we don't even think of them as capital items at all. But it might be a capital project that's driving the purchase of the instrumentation software that we sell, but Europe in
componenttext: No, the things that we're delivering are not highly expensive. They're really -- we don't even think of them as capital items at all. But it might be a capital project that's driving the purchase of the instrumentation software that we sell, but Europe in total for the company, not just Energy, it's down to 15% of Q3 revenue. So the U.S. was just a little over 60%. Actually Europe, we've included some -- what the other people would call Middle Eastern market. Some of that goes through Europe because of arrangements we have in Italy with some people. And I don’t have the absolute number in front of me, John.  Maybe you’ve got a better number.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just checked, Steve.  So as far as energy is concerned, just in that segment, Europe was actually up almost 10% on an organic basis. Remember, I mean we do have some OEMs in there, so we're still generally weak on some of the refining in the market
componenttext: Yes, I just checked, Steve.  So as far as energy is concerned, just in that segment, Europe was actually up almost 10% on an organic basis. Remember, I mean we do have some OEMs in there, so we're still generally weak on some of the refining in the markets, but we have some OEMs there that serve a global marketplace. So our destination revenue goes to Europe, but their destination revenue we're fairly confident goes all over the world and is continued to be driven by North America and Middle East activity, more so than Europe. And so Europe, when we look at it across the entire company, was kind of flat on an organic basis versus last year. We'll have the next headwind of 5% or 6%. So on a reported basis it was down, but you strip out that FX impact, we were kind of the same as last year. And we still are fighting with the headwind, of course, from the Gaz de France. So our review would be that Europe was a little bit better than what we saw in the second year quarter. Having said that, second quarter was a pretty low bar to be able to jump over.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then one last question is on the compressor control stuff. It's been pretty good on the LNG-related demand. Maybe some of the order slipping. I think you said it was going to kind of ramp in the fourth quarter. Any other comments, details there
componenttext: Right. And then one last question is on the compressor control stuff. It's been pretty good on the LNG-related demand. Maybe some of the order slipping. I think you said it was going to kind of ramp in the fourth quarter. Any other comments, details there to help paint a more visible picture on what's going on there?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I think I mentioned in the segment comment, the thing that's really on changing our compressor control businesses, that in addition to project work, we're hitting this very high level of field service, which is becoming more of an annuity on a continu
componenttext: No. I think I mentioned in the segment comment, the thing that's really on changing our compressor control businesses, that in addition to project work, we're hitting this very high level of field service, which is becoming more of an annuity on a continuing basis. And we outweigh more resources than we ever had to do that. That actually, hit the press as what you perceive is organic growth, of course, because it's just normalized in here, more like one of our software businesses. Other than that, we haven't seen any falloff in what people want to do around compressor controls. We continue to have a couple of bolt-on acquisitions. We did United Controls and Trinity software that had one of our -- they could be doing more roles than they have in the past. And I think we'll see some spike up, and that'll help us too. We would probably expect a little better orders over the next 6 months than we've had in the last 6.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Richard Eastman with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions, I guess maybe a little bit of follow up on that last one. But both the -- what we think of it as maybe the shorter-terms businesses, the industrial tech and the energy systems business, just in general, had -- the book-to-bill in the qua
componenttext: Just 2 questions, I guess maybe a little bit of follow up on that last one. But both the -- what we think of it as maybe the shorter-terms businesses, the industrial tech and the energy systems business, just in general, had -- the book-to-bill in the quarter for both of those business was below one and certainly below a seasonal pickup, seasonal expectation. And is that -- is the way you're thinking about that, that the damage was done kind of maybe in the month of August. And again, shorter-terms businesses, but we saw a recovery in September?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's -- I mean that's generally the case, Rick, but also as we look at the book-to-bill ratio inside the company, the major drivers are really our project-driven businesses, not the things that were more book and turn inside of a shorter wi
componenttext: Yes, I think that's -- I mean that's generally the case, Rick, but also as we look at the book-to-bill ratio inside the company, the major drivers are really our project-driven businesses, not the things that were more book and turn inside of a shorter window. And as you know, we always keep a close eye on some of our, as we think of them, our leading indicator businesses, our Strewers [ph] Material Tests business, our Janisco [ph] business, serving a number of process industries, as well as a couple of the other sensor and businesses and energy. And those continue to perform well. Their book-to-bill ratio was solid in the quarter. And other than -- August was tough, but September was better for them. So I think that, that commentary that Brian was talking about is largely around the book and ship businesses than we have the project timing things that will overlay against that.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one follow -- my follow-up. There was some -- I think, Brian, you had mentioned that there was some project activity the RF Tech, the segment that was pushed from maybe the second half of this year into the first half of next year. Is
componenttext: Okay. And then just one follow -- my follow-up. There was some -- I think, Brian, you had mentioned that there was some project activity the RF Tech, the segment that was pushed from maybe the second half of this year into the first half of next year. Is it -- where did that fall? Is that the Tolling business, or where is that?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Toll stuff in Texas. We had a very large contract that we won in the second quarter, and we expect that we would have been doing some delivery by now. And there are some things going on with the holding authority that they're moving things around, and the
componenttext: Toll stuff in Texas. We had a very large contract that we won in the second quarter, and we expect that we would have been doing some delivery by now. And there are some things going on with the holding authority that they're moving things around, and they're not ready for delivery yet. So that's getting pushed out to probably first quarter of next year, tiny chance we might get a little bit of that here in the fourth quarter. But we're assuming it's more of a 2013. That actually did benefit to us, because it helps like any falloff that might occur in 2013 in some of these other areas.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And the pushout. I think you had mentioned $5 million to $10 million. Is that kind of an annualized number? Or are we suggesting that was pushed out of the back half of this year.
componenttext: And the pushout. I think you had mentioned $5 million to $10 million. Is that kind of an annualized number? Or are we suggesting that was pushed out of the back half of this year.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is just -- when we were preparing our guidance for the third quarter, we were thinking we'd get $5 million to $10 million out of this particular project. And we didn't get anything that we -- that's why we're not at all worried about our book-to-bill
componenttext: This is just -- when we were preparing our guidance for the third quarter, we were thinking we'd get $5 million to $10 million out of this particular project. And we didn't get anything that we -- that's why we're not at all worried about our book-to-bill, 9.96 [ph].

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Heard the comments on tolling being a little stronger next year, but just trying to think about how to frame up the segment in RF, longer-term. It looks like maybe the traffic and tolling side is kind of a flatline business. You get some growth out of the
componenttext: Heard the comments on tolling being a little stronger next year, but just trying to think about how to frame up the segment in RF, longer-term. It looks like maybe the traffic and tolling side is kind of a flatline business. You get some growth out of the software side, so it kind of low growth longer-term, but a margin melt up on mix shift. Is that -- anything wrong with that thinking?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: If that's what happens, then you're right with respect to margin benefit. I'm not at all going where you are as far as toll and traffic being a flat business. They have a lot of opportunities in front of them. They have a number of solutions that they con
componenttext: If that's what happens, then you're right with respect to margin benefit. I'm not at all going where you are as far as toll and traffic being a flat business. They have a lot of opportunities in front of them. They have a number of solutions that they continue to deploy. People around the world are looking for ways to reduce congestion and generate revenue from their existing infrastructure. I think that the trends in their business are favorable. It's a question [ph] of whether austerity overwhelms that, but I don't think it does. So I'm not going where you are as far as it being a flat business.

componenttext: I wasn't necessarily there, just wanted to bounce that off of you. That was very helpful. And then on the regions, John, did the U.S. deviate at all from monthly trends that you talked about?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Not materially the strength to mine, no.
componenttext: Not materially the strength to mine, no.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Matt Summerville with KeyBanc.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Brian, you mentioned some dynamics with China, Japan and Taiwan. Can you talk a little bit more about that, and specifically how it's impacting your business or how you expect it to impact your business?
componenttext: Brian, you mentioned some dynamics with China, Japan and Taiwan. Can you talk a little bit more about that, and specifically how it's impacting your business or how you expect it to impact your business?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's really in a more on a academic and research arena, where we have -- a lot of our sales ultimately were going to China, but through Japanese and Taiwanese distribution or technology companies. Certainly, the political situation that, that has es
componenttext: Well, it's really in a more on a academic and research arena, where we have -- a lot of our sales ultimately were going to China, but through Japanese and Taiwanese distribution or technology companies. Certainly, the political situation that, that has escalated on the revenue [ph] basis between Japanese and China is less than helpful for people. So we are -- we were curious as to whether that's going to get resolved anytime soon, but that makes us a little more cautious about some of our end markets in that particular area. But remember, Matt, as you know it's a very small part of the overall company, but we do like to point out things. It seemed to be trend changers, and that is a tough one we had not heard prior to the third quarter from people that I think are insightful, so we’re kind of just alluring you that it could be a headwind.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then I wanted to spend just a moment on your CCC business. It sounds like you have excellent visibility there, so please -- I mean first, correct me if I'm wrong in thinking that. And then I want to make sure I understand what dictates kind of
componenttext: Got it. And then I wanted to spend just a moment on your CCC business. It sounds like you have excellent visibility there, so please -- I mean first, correct me if I'm wrong in thinking that. And then I want to make sure I understand what dictates kind of the momentum and timing around your field service activity? And is this a business that is going to require some incremental internal investment near term?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: It doesn't really need – it’s people related, so it's just a matter of -- we have seen an opportunity to expand our field service business for a lot of reasons. The people want to focus on capital equipment, which is very lumpy, and they're leaving be
componenttext: It doesn't really need – it’s people related, so it's just a matter of -- we have seen an opportunity to expand our field service business for a lot of reasons. The people want to focus on capital equipment, which is very lumpy, and they're leaving behind an opportunity to deal a lot of field service in these arena, which we're picking up at a fast pace. So that requires a little bit of investment for people, but not massive one. They are expensive people, because of where they're physically located. And then in terms of the order processes, they're always lumpy in CCC. There's not anything you could do about that. People order their technology from us with a long lead time, so it's not unusual to get an 18-month out order. We only book things that are shippable within 12 months, so we don't create a massive backlog and stuff that don't hit our next forward 12 months of activity. And we have a very strong knowledge about who we're working with in various CCC projects and what the likely outcome is going to be. Those tend not to be so much what equity projects. I mean you're kind of working with somebody from a design viewpoint, where you're likely to get the order. We would not lose many orders that we're involved.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, one quick one. Captcha's [ph] decision to open source their technology, does that do anything to the tolling space at all?
componenttext: And then lastly, one quick one. Captcha's [ph] decision to open source their technology, does that do anything to the tolling space at all?

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, I don't really think that's a change versus the status quo. I mean, those are -- I believe our understanding to that is that it's a number of patents that have already expired. And frankly, we've been on the leading edge of an awful lot of those inter
componenttext: No, I don't really think that's a change versus the status quo. I mean, those are -- I believe our understanding to that is that it's a number of patents that have already expired. And frankly, we've been on the leading edge of an awful lot of those interoperable solutions. We were the first people to -- and TransCore we're the first people to  introduce the multi-protocol readers, so a tolling authority could have the opportunity of having their choice of the best tag technology, and we'd be able to read anyone's available. So I don't think that, that recent announcement really affects the competitive dynamic. I think it's just a reflection of today's environment already.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was away from the call for a minute, so I don't know if this was asked, but you mentioned in your opening remarks that August gets down a bit, and you were concerned and then things strengthened. What's the reason for that?  That's an odd fluctuation.
componenttext: I was away from the call for a minute, so I don't know if this was asked, but you mentioned in your opening remarks that August gets down a bit, and you were concerned and then things strengthened. What's the reason for that?  That's an odd fluctuation.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean that's -- I think August was an aberration. When you SKU that out, the third quarter was maybe 2% below what we would have hoped for and we actually know that, that was more project oriented. But in the middle of the quarter we were apprehens
componenttext: Well, I mean that's -- I think August was an aberration. When you SKU that out, the third quarter was maybe 2% below what we would have hoped for and we actually know that, that was more project oriented. But in the middle of the quarter we were apprehensive, because we thought well maybe there is some kind of falloff. And we haven’t really seen that. So we're kind of back to a reasonable September and a reasonable July.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's been an economic falloff since then that's pretty dramatic going into the fourth quarter here with a lot of companies reporting weakness and things below expectations. But you experienced that apparently in August and then recovered from it.
componenttext: There's been an economic falloff since then that's pretty dramatic going into the fourth quarter here with a lot of companies reporting weakness and things below expectations. But you experienced that apparently in August and then recovered from it.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if I remember, only a few of our businesses are going to bounce around like that. I mean, the medical business is -- are more secular in nature. Most of our [indiscernible] lumpy side projects is pretty secular in nature with growth.  So if
componenttext: Well, I think if I remember, only a few of our businesses are going to bounce around like that. I mean, the medical business is -- are more secular in nature. Most of our [indiscernible] lumpy side projects is pretty secular in nature with growth.  So if you have a falloff in industrial energy, it's almost always rebounds in the fourth quarter in energy anyway. We'll have a lot of things that people want to invest in within our budget.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And another thing I would add to that is that -- I mean, we don't report on -- there are some companies that actually report their orders and their activity on a monthly basis, because they're really better gauge and more tied to near-term macro-economic
componenttext: And another thing I would add to that is that -- I mean, we don't report on -- there are some companies that actually report their orders and their activity on a monthly basis, because they're really better gauge and more tied to near-term macro-economic activity. That's never really been our business profile. So we're not really a good indicator for the macro world because of the niche markets that we serve and many of the things that have the secular growth tailwinds that Brian was talking about. So I think that -- I know a reason that we've mentioned it was a little bit of what we normally see, but we're not looking at month-to-month activity or week-to-week activity. We're not that type of macro business.

headline: Roper Industries Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. I realize that. And in looking at next year -- well right now, investment is lagging, investors are really on strike, capital goods investment, I'm talking about -- could even be down here in the fourth quarter.[Technical Difficulty]
componenttext:
Right. I realize that. And in looking at next year -- well right now, investment is lagging, investors are really on strike, capital goods investment, I'm talking about -- could even be down here in the fourth quarter.
